[MAJIDBENAM_REF_177_FmTrukL] 'All lineage buildings normally stand on land to whose soil the lineage, or some member of it, holds provisional or full title. If this is not feasible, the jimw may be built by the husbands of the lineage women on land held by one of them. In such a case his children acquire provisional title to the house and land on which it stands, receiving them as a niffag from their father. With the mwääniici of their lineage acting as guardian, the house and its site became a part of the property of the lineage whose women live there. Dwelling sites used to be shifted about once in a generation’s time, if the lineage had sufficient lands at its disposal. The purpose was to keep its house near breadfruit trees which were bearing well, so that a good supply of this staple food would always be near at hand. In the old days an jimw was sometimes surrounded by a stone wall for defensive purposes.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_178_FmTrukL] We have assumed non-mortared walls for the time being.
♠ Stone walls (mortared) ♣ inferred absent ♥ See above.
♠ Fortified camps ♣ inferred absent ♥ Stone walls surrounded settlements rather than military camps on the move (see above).
♠ Complex fortifications ♣ inferred absent ♥ We have provisionally assumed that stone walls around settlements were built in one row only.
♠ Long walls ♣ 0 ♥ km.
♠ Modern fortifications ♣ absent ♥Islanders also developed a system of martial arts for hand-to-hand combat: 'Fighting skills in aboriginal times included knowledge of the manufacture as well [Page 54] as of the use of the various weapons: the club, spear, sling, knuckle-duster, and in more recent time the knife and rifle. Of great importance, too, was a knowledge of the various holds in a system of hand-to-hand encounter remotely reminiscent of Japanese jiujitsu. To acquire these skills required considerable practice. In aboriginal times the various lineages used to hold periodic month-long training course in their respective meeting houses. Although each political district fought engagements as a united military group, training was given independently by the various lineages. Those present were the men of the lineage, the husbands of its women, and the sons of its men, in conformance with the pattern of confining the transmission of knowledge to one’s children and one’s lineage mates. It is said that by no means everyone knew all of the various weapons nor all of the tricks of hand-to-hand fighting. Knowledge of the proper magic was required in the manufacture of the several weapons and also to increase the effectiveness of their use thereafter. It is not surprising, therefore, that fighting skills were treated in the same way as other types of incorporeal property.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_179_FmTrukL] During World War II, islanders and Japenese troops were affected by air raids conducted by American aircraft: 'The Japanese constructed an elementary school in Peniyesene during the early 1930s to serve several villages and this meant that many of Peniyesene’s school-age children obtained at least three years of Japanese education during the 1930s. By the end of that decade, however, the ridges and hilltops near Peniyesene were being fortified by the Japanese military and with the outbreak of World War II a large concentration of Japanese troops was [Page 5] billeted in the village. To make way for them, village people were forcibly relocated and the school ceased to function. The classroom building subsequently was destroyed by Allied bombs and has not been rebuilt. Informal classes were held in Peniyesene early in the American period but subsequently all school children from the village have attended public or parochial schools located elsewhere.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_180_FmTrukL] 'As the Japanese military presence became dominant in the late 1930s, village life was disrupted. During World War II, many Peniyesene residents were relocated to make way for a large contingent of Japanese troops billeted in the area adjacent to the Wiichen River which flows through the village. Much of Peniyesene was destroyed in heavy bombing by Allied aircraft during the latter part of World War II and many local residents were killed or injured.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_181_FmTrukL] 'Several Japanese men moved into Peniyesene during the 1930s, married Peniyesene women, and fathered children who have remained in the community. During World War II large numbers of Japanese soldiers were sent to Truk, and Peniyesene became a major billet for army troops. Barracks were built, fortifications were installed, air raid shelters were blasted into the basalt bedrock along the valley’s edges, and as the war progressed, gardens were appropriated and the population of Peniyesene was removed, some to Wütëët Island and others to the back side of Mt. Wiitipwen. The Japanese troop concentration made the village a prime [Page 26] target for American bombers late in the war. Several Peniyesene persons were killed in the bombings, others sustained injuries, and most families lost their belongings and homes.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_182_FmTrukL]

Military Organization[edit]

♠ Standing armies ♣ absent ♥ There were no troops or police forces in the native system: 'There were no police. A chief's brothers or sons might act on his behalf to intimidate or attack someone who had offended him. But it was control of magical power, either by the chief or one his brothers or sons, that made improper conduct liable to punishment. Major craft specialists could also make ill those who violated the taboos of their craft. Finally, members of chiefly lineages and their close associates were likely to have knowledge of sorcery. All such knowledge gave punitive power to chiefs and important specialists. People stressed maintaining the appearance of propriety in behavior so as not to give just cause for offense.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_183_FmTrukL] Prior to 'pacification', violent conflict played out in raids and battles between rival groups of armed men: 'Within districts, conflict arose over land, succession to chiefship, theft, adultery, and avenging homicide. Between districts, it arose over attentions to local women by outside men, the status of one district as subordinate to another, and rights of access to fishing areas. Formal procedures for terminating conflict between districts involved payments of valuables and land by the loosing to the winning side. Fighting involved surprise raids and prearranged meetings on a field of battle. Principle weapons were slings, spears, and clubs. Firearms, introduced late in the nineteenth century, were confiscated by German authorities in 1903. Martial arts included an elaborate system of throws and holds by which an unarmed man could kill, maim or disarm an armed opponent.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_184_FmTrukL] Competition between rival chiefs over the control of land and people was a major factor: 'Traditional Micronesian life was characterized by a belief in the stability of society and culture. People suffered occasional natural disasters, such as cyclones or droughts, but their goal after encountering one of these was to reconstitute the previous state of affairs. Wars occurred in most areas from time to time, mainly at the instigation of competing chiefs. At stake was the control of land—a limited resource—and followers, but there were usually few casualties. Living in small communities on small territories, Micronesians learned to adjust to their neighbours, to remain on good terms with most of them most of the time, and to develop techniques of reconciliation when fights did break out. Micronesians traditionally depended on the cultivation of plant crops and on fishing in shallow reef waters. Because arable land was in short supply for the relatively dense population, Micronesians had a strong practical basis for their attachment to locality and lands. Land rights were usually held through lineages or extended family groups, often backed up by traditions of ancestral origins on the land.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_185_FmTrukL] Conflict among chiefs and their followers did not terminate entirely with 'pacification', although the population was disarmed in the early 20th century: 'In 1904 the disarming of the Truk people was undertaken by the “Kondor.” There were 436 guns and 2,531 cartridges confiscated. For better control the government appointed six head-chiefs, banished some swashbucklers who did not want to submit, and turned out the Japanese. With this a peaceful development was initiated. The missions (Protestant mission since 1879, Catholic mission since 1912) were able to work undisturbed. Unfortunately, the German government took little notice of Truk, since it was too preoccupied with the other islands. Yet many things were accomplished. Under the last director of the station, A. Überhorst, the lagoon was given new impetus in every respect. The relationship between officials and the population was usually a good one, under Mr. Überhorst even a cordial one. Anyone who was on Truk in those years certainly did not see any bad treatment of the natives. Much was done also with regard to health; in particular Dr. Mayer and his wife traveled from island to island without rest in order to take care of the sick. If during the Japanese occupation a young naval officer was not ashamed to assert that the Germans had done nothing for the islands, anyone who lived on the islands during the Japanese period can only say from the heart: “God protect the poor Truk people under the Japanese.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_186_FmTrukL] 'On the main islands the German government introduced head chiefs (somol lap) who carried the flag. There were six of them, one each on Poloas, Uman, Fefan, Wöla, Udot, and Pol /Pul/. The smaller islands likewise belonged to the sphere of power of the head chiefs. But even this institution could not link the tribes together within themselves or with one another. Some of the lower chiefs sympathize with the head chief for egotistical reasons; others fight against him violently for the same reasons. One who is with him today might be against him tomorrow because he somehow stepped on his toes. It is often enough for the subchief to fight the head chief if his neighboring chief supports him. Thus the picture is constantly changing. [Page 125] There is a continuous, sometimes quiet, sometimes open, warfare of the subchiefs against the head chiefs, the lower chiefs among themselves, the common people against the chiefs. The main reason for this disagreeable phenomenon is the limitless egotism of the Truk people. Everyone strives more or less to be something of a chief also. Strong families who do not like the chief attempt to isolate themselves and choose one from their midst. In addition to this, there are also old family enmities and disputes about land. It is obvious that the islands will never be able to achieve peaceful development in this manner. It is difficult to say who is most to blame for it. In any case the chiefs are not to be pitied, because they behave themselves accordingly. They are to be blamed mostly for the exploitation of the people, their corruptibility, and partiality. Many of them unhesitatingly accept money and objects and help the giver, no matter how many times he is in the wrong.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_187_FmTrukL] The Japanese army constructed military installations and stationed troops on the islands, especially in World War II: 'The Japanese constructed an elementary school in Peniyesene during the early 1930s to serve several villages and this meant that many of Peniyesene’s school-age children obtained at least three years of Japanese education during the 1930s. By the end of that decade, however, the ridges and hilltops near Peniyesene were being fortified by the Japanese military and with the outbreak of World War II a large concentration of Japanese troops was [Page 5] billeted in the village. To make way for them, village people were forcibly relocated and the school ceased to function. The classroom building subsequently was destroyed by Allied bombs and has not been rebuilt. Informal classes were held in Peniyesene early in the American period but subsequently all school children from the village have attended public or parochial schools located elsewhere.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_188_FmTrukL] 'As the Japanese military presence became dominant in the late 1930s, village life was disrupted. During World War II, many Peniyesene residents were relocated to make way for a large contingent of Japanese troops billeted in the area adjacent to the Wiichen River which flows through the village. Much of Peniyesene was destroyed in heavy bombing by Allied aircraft during the latter part of World War II and many local residents were killed or injured.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_189_FmTrukL] We have assumed that native islanders were not recruited into the Japanese miltiary. This remains in need of confirmation. Accordingly, the code may need changing if this assumption is proven incorrect.
♠ Uniformity of equipment ♣ inferred absent ♥ See above.
♠ Total army ♣ suspected unknown ♥ So far, no information on the typical size of a war party was found.
♠ Professional army ♣ suspected unknown ♥ So far, no information on the typical size of a war party was found.
♠ Largest fielded army ♣ suspected unknown ♥ So far, no information on the typical size of a war party was found.
♠ Maximum logistical lag ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Sources of recruits ♣ mass mobilization ♥
♠ Procurement of equipment and animals ♣ by soldiers ♥

General Characteristics of Warfare[edit]

♠ Inter-polity wars ♣ present ♥The islands were sold to German colonial authorities in the late 19th century. The Germans were replaced by the Japanese after World War I: "Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_190_FmTrukL] Accordingly, the islands were affected by World War II as they formed part of the Pacific Theatre: "Chuuk’s lagoon, for instance, holds an entire Japanese fleet that sank in 1944. Complete with human skeletons, dishes, and even fighter planes and tanks that had been tied on deck, the fleet has been declared an underwater museum and has become a popular tourist destination."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_191_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]"During World War II large numbers of Japanese soldiers were sent to Truk, and Peniyesene became a major billet for army troops. Barracks were built, fortifications were installed, air raid shelters were blasted into the basalt bedrock along the valley’s edges, and as the war progressed, gardens were appropriated and the population of Peniyesene was removed, some to Wütëët Island and others to the back side of Mt. Wiitipwen. The Japanese troop concentration made the village a prime target for American bombers late in the war. Several Peniyesene persons were killed in the bombings, others sustained injuries, and most families lost their belongings and homes."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_192_FmTrukL]
♠ Internal wars ♣ present ♥Conflict among chiefs and their followers did not terminate entirely with 'pacification', although the population was disarmed in the early 20th century: "In 1904 the disarming of the Truk people was undertaken by the 'Kondor.' There were 436 guns and 2,531 cartridges confiscated. For better control the government appointed six head-chiefs, banished some swashbucklers who did not want to submit, and turned out the Japanese.”[MAJIDBENAM_REF_193_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]"On the main islands the German government introduced head chiefs (somol lap) who carried the flag. There were six of them, one each on Poloas, Uman, Fefan, Wöla, Udot, and Pol /Pul/. The smaller islands likewise belonged to the sphere of power of the head chiefs. But even this institution could not link the tribes together within themselves or with one another. Some of the lower chiefs sympathize with the head chief for egotistical reasons; others fight against him violently for the same reasons."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_194_FmTrukL]
♠ Intra-elite conflicts ♣ present ♥Conflict among chiefs and their followers did not terminate entirely with 'pacification', although the population was disarmed in the early 20th century: "In 1904 the disarming of the Truk people was undertaken by the 'Kondor.' There were 436 guns and 2,531 cartridges confiscated. For better control the government appointed six head-chiefs, banished some swashbucklers who did not want to submit, and turned out the Japanese.”[MAJIDBENAM_REF_195_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]"On the main islands the German government introduced head chiefs (somol lap) who carried the flag. There were six of them, one each on Poloas, Uman, Fefan, Wöla, Udot, and Pol /Pul/. The smaller islands likewise belonged to the sphere of power of the head chiefs. But even this institution could not link the tribes together within themselves or with one another. Some of the lower chiefs sympathize with the head chief for egotistical reasons; others fight against him violently for the same reasons."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_196_FmTrukL]
♠ Popular uprisings ♣ inferred absent ♥
♠ Military revolts ♣ inferred absent ♥
♠ Separatist rebellions ♣ inferred absent ♥
♠ Wars within same ethnic group ♣ present ♥Conflict among chiefs and their followers did not terminate entirely with 'pacification', although the population was disarmed in the early 20th century: "In 1904 the disarming of the Truk people was undertaken by the 'Kondor.' There were 436 guns and 2,531 cartridges confiscated. For better control the government appointed six head-chiefs, banished some swashbucklers who did not want to submit, and turned out the Japanese."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_197_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]"On the main islands the German government introduced head chiefs (somol lap) who carried the flag. There were six of them, one each on Poloas, Uman, Fefan, Wöla, Udot, and Pol /Pul/. The smaller islands likewise belonged to the sphere of power of the head chiefs. But even this institution could not link the tribes together within themselves or with one another. Some of the lower chiefs sympathize with the head chief for egotistical reasons; others fight against him violently for the same reasons. ... There is a continuous, sometimes quiet, sometimes open, warfare of the subchiefs against the head chiefs, the lower chiefs among themselves, the common people against the chiefs. ... there are also old family enmities and disputes about land."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_198_FmTrukL]
♠ Wars involving groups with different dialects ♣ absent ♥ This code may be in need of review. We have provisionally assumed no major differences in dialect.
♠ Wars involving groups with different languages ♣ absent ♥
♠ Wars involving groups with different language families ♣ present ♥The islands were affected by World War II as they formed part of the Pacific Theatre: "During World War II, many Micronesian islands were heavily contested; major military engagements took place between Japanese and American forces in Palau, Guam, the northern Marianas, Chuuk (then known as Truk), the Marshalls, and parts of the Gilberts." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_199_FmTrukL] World War II saw countries speaking from different language families fighting over the Chuuk islands.
♠ Wars between groups from different archaeological cultures ♣ absent ♥
♠ Wars between different religious sects ♣ absent ♥
♠ Wars between different world religions ♣ present ♥The islands were affected by World War II as they formed part of the Pacific Theatre: "During World War II, many Micronesian islands were heavily contested; major military engagements took place between Japanese and American forces in Palau, Guam, the northern Marianas, Chuuk (then known as Truk), the Marshalls, and parts of the Gilberts." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_200_FmTrukL] World War II saw countries speaking from different language families fighting over the Chuuk islands.
♠ Wars of world religion against tribal religion ♣ inferred present ♥ Japanese (Buddhism, Shintoism?) versus Truk.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]"If during the Japanese occupation a young naval officer was not ashamed to assert that the Germans had done nothing for the islands, anyone who lived on the islands during the Japanese period can only say from the heart: 'God protect the poor Truk people under the Japanese.'"[MAJIDBENAM_REF_201_FmTrukL]
♠ Wars on Urbanism-Literacy frontier ♣ absent ♥
♠ Wars on steppe frontier ♣ absent ♥
♠ Wars on agricultural frontier ♣ absent ♥
♠ Annexation ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]The Japanese military appropriated lands for military purposes and removed the native population: "Several Japanese men moved into Peniyesene during the 1930s, married Peniyesene women, and fathered children who have remained in the community. During World War II large numbers of Japanese soldiers were sent to Truk, and Peniyesene became a major billet for army troops."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_202_FmTrukL] We don't code for the Japanese polity. Do the codes for FmTrukE still apply?
♠ Looting ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Sack ♣ inferred present ♥ When it comes to 'native' warfare, we coded for annexation, sack, expulsion, torture, mutilation, imprisonment, and targeted massacres in FmTrukE (see data sheet for the pre-colonial period). We are unsure whether these still apply to the seemingly rarer conflicts of the colonial period. We have provisionally coded them 'inferred present'. Expert feedback is needed.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]"The islanders’ main method of fighting, however, was surprise attack and stealing up in the night. ... Houses were set afire, trees cut down, animals killed; in short, each side sought to do as much harm to the other one as possible.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_203_FmTrukL]
♠ Rape ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.
♠ Deportation ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]The islands were contested in World War II: "During World War II, many Micronesian islands were heavily contested; major military engagements took place between Japanese and American forces in Palau, Guam, the northern Marianas, Chuuk (then known as Truk), the Marshalls, and parts of the Gilberts."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_204_FmTrukL] We don't code for the Japanese polity. Do the codes for FmTrukE still apply?
♠ Expulsion ♣ inferred present ♥ When it comes to 'native' warfare, we coded for annexation, sack, expulsion, torture, mutilation, imprisonment, and targeted massacres in FmTrukE (see data sheet for the pre-colonial period). We are unsure whether these still apply to the seemingly rarer conflicts of the colonial period. We have provisionally coded them 'inferred present'. Expert feedback is needed.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]"If during the Japanese occupation a young naval officer was not ashamed to assert that the Germans had done nothing for the islands, anyone who lived on the islands during the Japanese period can only say from the heart: 'God protect the poor Truk people under the Japanese.'"[MAJIDBENAM_REF_205_FmTrukL] We don't code for the Japanese polity. Do the codes for FmTrukE still apply?
♠ Enslavement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.
♠ Imprisonment ♣ inferred present ♥ When it comes to 'native' warfare, we coded for annexation, sack, expulsion, torture, mutilation, imprisonment, and targeted massacres in FmTrukE (see data sheet for the pre-colonial period). We are unsure whether these still apply to the seemingly rarer conflicts of the colonial period. We have provisionally coded them 'inferred present'. Expert feedback is needed.
♠ Destruction ♣ present ♥ "Houses were set afire, trees cut down, animals killed; in short, each side sought to do as much harm to the other one as possible.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_206_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]The islands were contested in World War II. Native settlements and Japanese military installations were subjected to American air raids: "Several Japanese men moved into Peniyesene during the 1930s, married Peniyesene women, and fathered children who have remained in the community. During World War II large numbers of Japanese soldiers were sent to Truk, and Peniyesene became a major billet for army troops. Barracks were built, fortifications were installed, air raid shelters were blasted into the basalt bedrock along the valley’s edges, and as the war progressed, gardens were appropriated and the population of Peniyesene was removed, some to Wütëët Island and others to the back side of Mt. Wiitipwen. The Japanese troop concentration made the village a prime [Page 26] target for American bombers late in the war. Several Peniyesene persons were killed in the bombings, others sustained injuries, and most families lost their belongings and homes."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_207_FmTrukL] We don't code for the Japanese polity. Do the codes for FmTrukE still apply?
♠ Torture ♣ inferred present ♥ When it comes to 'native' warfare, we coded for annexation, sack, expulsion, torture, mutilation, imprisonment, and targeted massacres in FmTrukE (see data sheet for the pre-colonial period). We are unsure whether these still apply to the seemingly rarer conflicts of the colonial period. We have provisionally coded them 'inferred present'. Expert feedback is needed.
♠ Mutilation ♣ inferred present ♥ When it comes to 'native' warfare, we coded for annexation, sack, expulsion, torture, mutilation, imprisonment, and targeted massacres in FmTrukE (see data sheet for the pre-colonial period). We are unsure whether these still apply to the seemingly rarer conflicts of the colonial period. We have provisionally coded them 'inferred present'. Expert feedback is needed.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]"Whether man, woman, or child, his throat was cut without mercy. It is told about one warrior that while on an expedition he encountered on the way a child from the enemy tribe. He took it by the legs and struck its head against a tree so that blood and brains spurted about.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_208_FmTrukL]
♠ Targeted massacre ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.
♠ General massacre ♣ present ♥ "The islanders’ main method of fighting, however, was surprise attack and stealing up in the night. Woe to the one who fell into the hands of such who were sneaking about. Whether man, woman, or child, his throat was cut without mercy.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_209_FmTrukL]
♠ Extermination ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.
♠ Ethnocide ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

List of Wars[edit]

A collective ritual is a ritual in which two or more people participate. With the official cult we refer to the set of collective ritual practices that are most closely associated with legitimation of the power structure (including elites, if any).
♠ RA ♣ Enrico Cioni ♥
♠ Editor ♣ Daniel Mullins ♥
♠ Expert ♣ ♥

Largest scale collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ ouonu dances ♥ "During this time also moonlight dances in honor of Inemes are performed. They are the notorious ouonu dances. [...] What a corrupting effect the singing of such texts must have! [...] The entire tribe, men, women, boys, and girls, without distinction, takes part in these dances. Whoever knows how to dance, dances, the others watch. The dancers are separated according to sex. The fire burns between them. Those who have definite arrangements with each other exchange their head wreaths without embarrassment before the dance, although everybody present knows what that means. The chief is often forced to forbid individual exchange in order to avoid jealous scenes. Then all put their wreaths down together. The men take those of the women, the women those of the men. Now there is dancing, hour after hour, for half the night. When everybody is in the right mood, the fire is extinguished at the chief's command, whereupon lewdness is granted every freedom."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_210_FmTrukL] Bollig also provides the text of one of the less explicit licentious songs sung during these dances.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_211_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ ♥ Bollig does not provide this information.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_212_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ ♥ Bollig does not provide this information.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_213_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ ♥ Bollig does not provide this information.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_214_FmTrukL]
♠ Duration ♣ [8-10] ♥ Participants spend "half the night" dancing,[MAJIDBENAM_REF_215_FmTrukL] implying that the subsequent orgy takes place the rest of the night is.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ ♥ The "whole tribe" participates.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_216_FmTrukL] According to Ethnographic Atlas variable 31 'Mean Size of Local Communities', the Trukese possess groups of '3' or '100-199', smaller than 200-399, 400-1000, any town of more than 5,000, Towns of 5,000-50,000 (one or more), and Cities of more than 50,000 (one or more).
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ ♥ Bollig does not mention ritual specialists.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ "The entire tribe, men, women, boys, and girls, without distinction, takes part in these dances. Whoever knows how to dance, dances, the others watch."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_217_FmTrukL]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ "The entire tribe, men, women, boys, and girls, without distinction, takes part in these dances. Whoever knows how to dance, dances, the others watch."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_218_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_219_FmTrukL]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ present ♥ The whole night is spent dancing and having sex.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_220_FmTrukL]
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_221_FmTrukL]
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_222_FmTrukL]
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_223_FmTrukL]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_224_FmTrukL]
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_225_FmTrukL]
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_226_FmTrukL]
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_227_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥
[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_228_FmTrukL]
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on drunkenness if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_229_FmTrukL]
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on drug use if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_230_FmTrukL]
♠ sex ♣ present ♥ "When everybody is in the right mood, the fire is extinguished at the chief's command, whereupon lewdness is granted every freedom."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_231_FmTrukL]
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ "During this time also moonlight dances in honor of Inemes are performed. They are the notorious ouonu dances."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_232_FmTrukL]
♠ synchronous movement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Dancing is described, but not its particulars.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_233_FmTrukL]
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ Bollig provides the text of one of the less explicit licentious songs sung during these dances.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_234_FmTrukL]
♠ entertainment ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_235_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥
[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_236_FmTrukL]
♠ oath taking ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_237_FmTrukL]
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_238_FmTrukL]
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_239_FmTrukL]
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_240_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ present ♥ "The chief is often forced to forbid individual exchange in order to avoid jealous scenes. [...] When everybody isin the right mood, the fire is extinguished at the chief's command, whereupon lewdness is granted every freedom."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_241_FmTrukL]
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_242_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_243_FmTrukL]
♠ property/valuable items ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_244_FmTrukL]
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on health costs if he had perceived any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_245_FmTrukL]
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on animal sacrifice if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_246_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on human sacrifice if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_247_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on human sacrifice if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_248_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on human sacrifice if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_249_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most widespread collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Breadfruit ceremony ♥ 'Breadfruit ceremony, to increase fertility of breadfruit. Involves the repeated sailing and racing of toy boats on the sea.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_250_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ weekly ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_251_FmTrukL] variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as '2 = less often than daily but more often than monthly'
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ weekly ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_252_FmTrukL] variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as '2 = less often than daily but more often than monthly'
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ weekly ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_253_FmTrukL] variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as '2 = less often than daily but more often than monthly'
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_254_FmTrukL], this ritual is coded as 's(2) = 1 to 6 hours/ long'
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 38 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_255_FmTrukL], 'Some members of community (<50% where that is more than 15 persons)' participate. According to Ethnographic Atlas variable 31 'Mean Size of Local Communities', the Trukese possess groups of '3' or '100-199', smaller than 200-399, 400-1000, any town of more than 5,000, Towns of 5,000-50,000 (one or more), and Cities of more than 50,000 (one or more). Citing a community of size of roughly 150 persons and estimating a .25 percent participation rate, I estimate that roughly 38 people are involved in this ritual.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ whole polity ♥ There doesn't appear to be any clear limitations about who can perform this ritual in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_256_FmTrukL].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ There doesn't appear to be any clear limitations about who can participate this ritual in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_257_FmTrukL].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ There doesn't appear to be any clear limitations about who can observe this ritual in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_258_FmTrukL].[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ present ♥ 'Fasting' is coded as '1 present' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_259_FmTrukL].
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ 'Sleep deprivation' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_260_FmTrukL].
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ 'Threats or actions that evince fear' and 'Dramatic acts evincing displays of emotion from participants (tears, laughter, rage, fear etc.)' are both coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_261_FmTrukL].
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ 'Humiliation of participants' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_262_FmTrukL].
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ 'Mention of disgust' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_263_FmTrukL].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_264_FmTrukL].
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_265_FmTrukL] as 'absent'. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_266_FmTrukL] is 0, the lowest possible score.
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_267_FmTrukL] as 'absent'.
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_268_FmTrukL], including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'.
♠ other ♣ present ♥ 'Long periods of immobility or maintenance of uncomfortable body position' is coded as 'present' for this ritual in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_269_FmTrukL]
[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_270_FmTrukL] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ alcohol ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_271_FmTrukL] variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'absent'.
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_272_FmTrukL].
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_273_FmTrukL].
♠ dancing ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_274_FmTrukL] variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'absent'.
♠ synchronous movement ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. dancing or marching in unison) Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_275_FmTrukL] variable 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as 'present', but this appears to be a procession, not synchronous marching.
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_276_FmTrukL] variable 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as 'present'.

Most frequent collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Breadfruit ceremony ♥ 'Breadfruit ceremony, to increase fertility of breadfruit. Involves the repeated sailing and racing of toy boats on the sea.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_287_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ weekly ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_288_FmTrukL] variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as '2 = less often than daily but more often than monthly'
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ weekly ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_289_FmTrukL] variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as '2 = less often than daily but more often than monthly'
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ weekly ♥ Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_290_FmTrukL] variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as '2 = less often than daily but more often than monthly'
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_291_FmTrukL], this ritual is coded as 's(2) = 1 to 6 hours/ long'
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 38 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_292_FmTrukL], 'Some members of community (<50% where that is more than 15 persons)' participate. According to Ethnographic Atlas variable 31 'Mean Size of Local Communities', the Trukese possess groups of '3' or '100-199', smaller than 200-399, 400-1000, any town of more than 5,000, Towns of 5,000-50,000 (one or more), and Cities of more than 50,000 (one or more). Citing a community of size of roughly 150 persons and estimating a .25 percent participation rate, I estimate that roughly 38 people are involved in this ritual.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ whole polity ♥ There doesn't appear to be any clear limitations about who can perform this ritual in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_293_FmTrukL].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ There doesn't appear to be any clear limitations about who can participate this ritual in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_294_FmTrukL].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ There doesn't appear to be any clear limitations about who can observe this ritual in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_295_FmTrukL].[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ present ♥ 'Fasting' is coded as '1 present' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_296_FmTrukL].
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ 'Sleep deprivation' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [MAJIDBENAM_REF_297_FmTrukL].

Most euphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ ouonu dances ♥ "During this time also moonlight dances in honor of Inemes are performed. They are the notorious ouonu dances. [...] What a corrupting effect the singing of such texts must have! [...] The entire tribe, men, women, boys, and girls, without distinction, takes part in these dances. Whoever knows how to dance, dances, the others watch. The dancers are separated according to sex. The fire burns between them. Those who have definite arrangements with each other exchange their head wreaths without embarrassment before the dance, although everybody present knows what that means. The chief is often forced to forbid individual exchange in order to avoid jealous scenes. Then all put their wreaths down together. The men take those of the women, the women those of the men. Now there is dancing, hour after hour, for half the night. When everybody is in the right mood, the fire is extinguished at the chief's command, whereupon lewdness is granted every freedom."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_324_FmTrukL] Bollig also provides the text of one of the less explicit licentious songs sung during these dances.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_325_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ ♥ Bollig does not provide this information.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_326_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ ♥ Bollig does not provide this information.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_327_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ ♥ Bollig does not provide this information.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_328_FmTrukL]
♠ Duration ♣ [8-10] ♥ Participants spend "half the night" dancing,[MAJIDBENAM_REF_329_FmTrukL] implying that the subsequent orgy takes place the rest of the night is.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ ♥ The "whole tribe" participates.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_330_FmTrukL] According to Ethnographic Atlas variable 31 'Mean Size of Local Communities', the Trukese possess groups of '3' or '100-199', smaller than 200-399, 400-1000, any town of more than 5,000, Towns of 5,000-50,000 (one or more), and Cities of more than 50,000 (one or more).
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ ♥ Bollig does not mention ritual specialists.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ "The entire tribe, men, women, boys, and girls, without distinction, takes part in these dances. Whoever knows how to dance, dances, the others watch."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_331_FmTrukL]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ "The entire tribe, men, women, boys, and girls, without distinction, takes part in these dances. Whoever knows how to dance, dances, the others watch."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_332_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_333_FmTrukL]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ present ♥ The whole night is spent dancing and having sex.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_334_FmTrukL]
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_335_FmTrukL]
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_336_FmTrukL]
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_337_FmTrukL]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_338_FmTrukL]
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_339_FmTrukL]
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_340_FmTrukL]
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Not described by our main source, Laurentius Bollig. Moreover, this appears to be a mostly euphoric ritual.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_341_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥
[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_342_FmTrukL]
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on drunkenness if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_343_FmTrukL]
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on drug use if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_344_FmTrukL]
♠ sex ♣ present ♥ "When everybody is in the right mood, the fire is extinguished at the chief's command, whereupon lewdness is granted every freedom."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_345_FmTrukL]
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ "During this time also moonlight dances in honor of Inemes are performed. They are the notorious ouonu dances."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_346_FmTrukL]
♠ synchronous movement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Dancing is described, but not its particulars.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_347_FmTrukL]
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ Bollig provides the text of one of the less explicit licentious songs sung during these dances.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_348_FmTrukL]
♠ entertainment ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_349_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥
[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_350_FmTrukL]
♠ oath taking ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_351_FmTrukL]
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_352_FmTrukL]
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_353_FmTrukL]

♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ present ♥ "The chief is often forced to forbid individual exchange in order to avoid jealous scenes. [...] When everybody isin the right mood, the fire is extinguished at the chief's command, whereupon lewdness is granted every freedom."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_355_FmTrukL]
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_356_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Costs of participation

♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on health costs if he had perceived any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_359_FmTrukL]
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on animal sacrifice if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_360_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on human sacrifice if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_361_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on human sacrifice if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_362_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ Our main source, Laurentius Bollig, does not mention this. Indeed, he is sufficiently disapproving of the ritual that he probably would have commented on human sacrifice if he had witnessed any.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_363_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most dysphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ mourning ritual ♥ "The time from the death to about eight days or longer afterwards, depending on the degree of love, is called the mourning period. The mourners may not bathe or comb themselves and must fast. They sit in the house and from time to time utter their mourning wail (tulemumu). Apart from this conventional mourning period, one soon notices the truth of the saying: 'Out of sight, out of mind.' The dead person is soon forgotten. The relatives quarrel about his estate. Nobody takes care of his grave; indeed, everybody walks around it in as large a curve as possible. Even his parents or his children no longer dare say his name. If somebody has to mention it, he uses other words for it. [...] The correct name is absolutely avoided. It takes much effort to drive out the natives their superstitious fear of a dead person's name. [...] The fear of his soul, which might possibly become dangerous for them, dominates all their thinking and acting."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_364_FmTrukL]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ ♥ Probably relatively frequent, since this happened every time someone died.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ ♥ Probably relatively frequent, since this happened every time someone died.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ ♥ Probably relatively frequent, since this happened every time someone died.
♠ Duration ♣ 192 ♥ hours. About 8 days.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_365_FmTrukL]
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_366_FmTrukL]
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_367_FmTrukL]
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_368_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ present ♥ "The mourners may not bathe or comb themselves and must fast."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_369_FmTrukL]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_370_FmTrukL]
♠ fear ♣ present ♥ "The dead person is soon forgotten. The relatives quarrel about his estate. Nobody takes care of his grave; indeed, everybody walks around it in as large a curve as possible. Even his parents or his children no longer dare say his name. If somebody has to mention it, he uses other words for it. [...] The correct name is absolutely avoided. It takes much effort to drive out the natives their superstitious fear of a dead person's name. [...] The fear of his soul, which might possibly become dangerous for them, dominates all their thinking and acting."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_371_FmTrukL]
♠ humiliation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_372_FmTrukL]
♠ disgust ♣ inferred present ♥ The deceased's corpse is often exposed and even kept in the house some time after death; and sometimes, the Trukese used unguents on its skin to mask the smell. However, Bollig's account suggests there was much variety on how the corpse was treated before burial.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_373_FmTrukL]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_374_FmTrukL]
♠ pain ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_375_FmTrukL]
♠ mutilation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_376_FmTrukL]
♠ risk of death ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_377_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥
[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ "The mourners may not bathe or comb themselves and must fast."[MAJIDBENAM_REF_378_FmTrukL]
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_379_FmTrukL]
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_380_FmTrukL]
♠ sex ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_381_FmTrukL]
♠ dancing ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_382_FmTrukL]
♠ synchronous movement ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_383_FmTrukL]
♠ singing ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_384_FmTrukL]
♠ entertainment ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_385_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥
[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_386_FmTrukL]
♠ oath taking ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_387_FmTrukL]
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_388_FmTrukL]
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_389_FmTrukL]
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_390_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_391_FmTrukL]
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_392_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_393_FmTrukL]
♠ property/valuable items ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_394_FmTrukL]
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_395_FmTrukL]
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_396_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig, who does mention human sacrifice in connection to other Trukese rituals.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_397_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig, who does mention human sacrifice in connection to other Trukese rituals.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_398_FmTrukL]
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by Bollig, who does mention human sacrifice in connection to other Trukese rituals.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_399_FmTrukL]
♠ other ♣ ♥

Phase II Variables (polity-based)[edit]

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥
♠ Expert ♣ ♥
♠ Editor ♣ ♥

Limits on Power of the Chief Executive[edit]

♠ Executive power is separate or independent from military ♣ absent ♥ 'There were no police. A chief's brothers or sons might act on his behalf to intimidate or attack someone who had offended him. But it was control of magical power, either by the chief or one his brothers or sons, that made improper conduct liable to punishment. Major craft specialists could also make ill those who violated the taboos of their craft. Finally, members of chiefly lineages and their close associates were likely to have knowledge of sorcery. All such knowledge gave punitive power to chiefs and important specialists. People stressed maintaining the appearance of propriety in behavior so as not to give just cause for offense.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_400_FmTrukL]
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from legislative ♣ absent ♥ Writing in the colonial period, Bollig describes the resolution of disputes in public meetings: 'The chief does all these duties in the kobu[unknown], the public meeting. Men as well as women are invited to this kobu[unknown]. All the participants are called together by the blowing of the large shell from the chief’s house. The kobu[unknown] takes place in the udd, the large men’s house. All the dealings of the tribe are discussed in it, marital matters, land matters, quarrels, in short, all the linen, whether clean or dirty, is spread out before all eyes. Everybody is allowed to talk and present his complaints. Of course there is no lack of amusing scenes too. Sometimes the people become so excited that the parties insult each other, grab each other, and come to blows, so that the meeting has to be dissolved. The following remark was made in a kobu[unknown] which I attended: “He is a bad fellow because he stole my log.” The person insulted in such a manner jumped up angrily and defended himself so convincingly that the accuser let his head sink and replied dejectedly: “ Kinisou, mei bu[unknown]me rem, excuse me, you are right.” In another kobu[unknown] a subchief said to the head chief: “I do not like you as head chief, for you put some into paradise, others into hell.” With this plain allusion to his partiality, the head chief became very excited, while the audience laughed. From the same chief came the familiar quotation: “ siwilin ni efot, ni efot; siwilim mas eu, mas eu, ina Lamalamen Moses, /116/ tooth for tooth, eye for eye, that is the religion of Moses.” As one sees, the chief concerned had not read the Protestant Bible in vain and knew very well how to cloak his thirst for revenge very nicely. Things go along quite pleasantly in the kobu[unknown] of the Truk people. Each one chatters as long and as [Page 127] much as he likes. If he uses sharp, objectionable expressions, wiser ones will certainly call out to him: “ a emuen, it is enough.” Some smoke, some eat. One sits on the floor, another one on an upturned bowl, or anywhere else. Here and there one also sees some who are asleep, tired from listening for a long time. In short it goes along in true Kanaka fashion, and the result of the kobu[unknown], usually lasting for hours, is “much ado about nothing.” The matter at issue remains as it was, or it has become even more complicated. The government has often tried to give the kobu[unknown] a more serious air, but quite in vain. The main person at the kobu[unknown] is the chief, who makes the decision in the individual cases. Formerly his decision was absolutely decisive for all questions. In more recent times appeal to a higher authority, to the head chief and the government, has been possible. The government has also pruned the jurisdiction of the chief. Some things are reserved solely for the head chief, some solely for the government representative. During the kobu[unknown], the chief is surrounded by his relatives and advisors who watch over him. If he wants to say something that does not suit them, they call out to him: “ a niku[unknown], that is too much.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_401_FmTrukL]
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from judiciary ♣ absent ♥ SCCS variable 89 'Judiciary' is coded as ‘1’ or 'absent'. Chiefs served as primary judicial authorities. Writing in the colonial period, Bollig describes the resolution of disputes in public meetings: 'The chief does all these duties in the kobu[unknown], the public meeting. Men as well as women are invited to this kobu[unknown]. All the participants are called together by the blowing of the large shell from the chief’s house. The kobu[unknown] takes place in the udd, the large men’s house. All the dealings of the tribe are discussed in it, marital matters, land matters, quarrels, in short, all the linen, whether clean or dirty, is spread out before all eyes. Everybody is allowed to talk and present his complaints. Of course there is no lack of amusing scenes too. Sometimes the people become so excited that the parties insult each other, grab each other, and come to blows, so that the meeting has to be dissolved. The following remark was made in a kobu[unknown] which I attended: “He is a bad fellow because he stole my log.” The person insulted in such a manner jumped up angrily and defended himself so convincingly that the accuser let his head sink and replied dejectedly: “ Kinisou, mei bu[unknown]me rem, excuse me, you are right.” In another kobu[unknown] a subchief said to the head chief: “I do not like you as head chief, for you put some into paradise, others into hell.” With this plain allusion to his partiality, the head chief became very excited, while the audience laughed. From the same chief came the familiar quotation: “ siwilin ni efot, ni efot; siwilim mas eu, mas eu, ina Lamalamen Moses, /116/ tooth for tooth, eye for eye, that is the religion of Moses.” As one sees, the chief concerned had not read the Protestant Bible in vain and knew very well how to cloak his thirst for revenge very nicely. Things go along quite pleasantly in the kobu[unknown] of the Truk people. Each one chatters as long and as [Page 127] much as he likes. If he uses sharp, objectionable expressions, wiser ones will certainly call out to him: “ a emuen, it is enough.” Some smoke, some eat. One sits on the floor, another one on an upturned bowl, or anywhere else. Here and there one also sees some who are asleep, tired from listening for a long time. In short it goes along in true Kanaka fashion, and the result of the kobu[unknown], usually lasting for hours, is “much ado about nothing.” The matter at issue remains as it was, or it has become even more complicated. The government has often tried to give the kobu[unknown] a more serious air, but quite in vain. The main person at the kobu[unknown] is the chief, who makes the decision in the individual cases. Formerly his decision was absolutely decisive for all questions. In more recent times appeal to a higher authority, to the head chief and the government, has been possible. The government has also pruned the jurisdiction of the chief. Some things are reserved solely for the head chief, some solely for the government representative. During the kobu[unknown], the chief is surrounded by his relatives and advisors who watch over him. If he wants to say something that does not suit them, they call out to him: “ a niku[unknown], that is too much.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_402_FmTrukL] The judicial powers of the chiefs were diminished somewhat in the colonial period: 'The chief’s authority to punish no longer goes very far. Once master over life and death, now he can only order imprisonment or hard labor. The hard labor usually consists of pulling grass on public roads or carrying stones to canoe wharves. Nevertheless the people do not hurt themselves at this work and get out of it whenever they can. Instead of pulling grass, they sit smoking and talking on the road. They also know how to appear sick in order to be left completely free. The feeding of condemned persons is a matter for his relatives. For the duration of the punishment the natives live in the jail ( kalapus) . Each head chief has two kalapus, one for men and the other for women. On some islands the kalapus contributed greatly to the depravity of morals, since both sexes were housed in the same room. Similarly the wardens of the prisoners used the opportunity to satisfy their passions and to do business on the side by hiring out the imprisoned women.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_403_FmTrukL] 'On the other hand, the chief acquired a number of restrictions on the exercise of his power which either did not exist before, or which had not been so clear and consistent. It was not possible to appeal a chief’s judicial decisions, or to go to higher authority to change or reverse a chief’s plans for coordinated activity. With the coming of the American administration a further restriction appeared in the, theoretically at least, independent community legislature to whose laws even the chief is subject. Under the Americans there is also an independent judiciary, so that the chief is no longer allowed, in theory, to mediate interlineage disputes. On balance, however, it would seem that the chiefs’ coordinating and planning powers were increased despite the new restrictions. The provision of effective and usable sanctions probably outweighs all the new limits imposed on the chiefs’ powers.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_404_FmTrukL] But colonial forces also backed chiefly resolutions in a manner not possible in the pre-colonial period: 'The Germans also provided effective force to support the chief’s decisions. Anyone refusing to obey a chief’s orders or rejecting his decision in a dispute was liable to internment in the “calaboose” spoken of so approvingly by the old man at the beginning of this paper. The might of the German, and, in turn, the Japanese and American administrations stood behind a chief’s words; and although some kind of appeal from his decisions was usually possible, the likelihood of anyone refusing to obey his clearly expressed mandates and escaping unscathed had become rather small.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_405_FmTrukL] [MAJIDBENAM_BR] ♠ Right to petition executive ♣ ♥
♠ Critique of executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Critique of executive by non-government ♣ ♥ ♠ Sanction of executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Sanction of executive by non-government ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by non-government ♣ ♥
♠ Impeachment ♣ ♥ ♠ Informal critique of executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal sanction of executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal constraint on executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal impeachment ♣ ♥ ♠ Critique of executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Sanction of executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by religious institutions ♣ ♥
♠ Impeachment by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Subordination of the chief executive to a religious agent ♣ ♥
♠ Motivation by belief in supernatural agent ♣ ♥ ♠ Customary mechanism ♣ inferred present ♥ State-level administration was introduced in the colonial period: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_406_FmTrukL] The colonial governments appointed a number of head-chiefs and superimposed a colonial administration onto the native system: 'In 1904 the disarming of the Truk people was undertaken by the “Kondor.” There were 436 guns and 2,531 cartridges confiscated. For better control the government appointed six head-chiefs, banished some swashbucklers who did not want to submit, and turned out the Japanese. With this a peaceful development was initiated. The missions (Protestant mission since 1879, Catholic mission since 1912) were able to work undisturbed. Unfortunately, the German government took little notice of Truk, since it was too preoccupied with the other islands. Yet many things were accomplished. Under the last director of the station, A. Überhorst, the lagoon was given new impetus in every respect. The relationship between officials and the population was usually a good one, under Mr. Überhorst even a cordial one. Anyone who was on Truk in those years certainly did not see any bad treatment of the natives. Much was done also with regard to health; in particular Dr. Mayer and his wife traveled from island to island without rest in order to take care of the sick. If during the Japanese occupation a young naval officer was not ashamed to assert that the Germans had done nothing for the islands, anyone who lived on the islands during the Japanese period can only say from the heart: “God protect the poor Truk people under the Japanese.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_407_FmTrukL] We have inferred a 'customary' mechanism for local chiefs and a 'legal' mechanism for government-appointed head chiefs.
♠ Legal mechanism ♣ inferred present ♥ State-level administration was introduced in the colonial period: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_408_FmTrukL] The colonial governments appointed a number of head-chiefs and superimposed a colonial administration onto the native system: 'In 1904 the disarming of the Truk people was undertaken by the “Kondor.” There were 436 guns and 2,531 cartridges confiscated. For better control the government appointed six head-chiefs, banished some swashbucklers who did not want to submit, and turned out the Japanese. With this a peaceful development was initiated. The missions (Protestant mission since 1879, Catholic mission since 1912) were able to work undisturbed. Unfortunately, the German government took little notice of Truk, since it was too preoccupied with the other islands. Yet many things were accomplished. Under the last director of the station, A. Überhorst, the lagoon was given new impetus in every respect. The relationship between officials and the population was usually a good one, under Mr. Überhorst even a cordial one. Anyone who was on Truk in those years certainly did not see any bad treatment of the natives. Much was done also with regard to health; in particular Dr. Mayer and his wife traveled from island to island without rest in order to take care of the sick. If during the Japanese occupation a young naval officer was not ashamed to assert that the Germans had done nothing for the islands, anyone who lived on the islands during the Japanese period can only say from the heart: “God protect the poor Truk people under the Japanese.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_409_FmTrukL] We have inferred a 'customary' mechanism for local chiefs and a 'legal' mechanism for government-appointed head chiefs.
♠ Number of power transitions ♣ ♥
♠ Number of contested transitions ♣ ♥
♠ Number of successful overturns ♣ ♥

Central Bureaucracy[edit]

♠ State-level administrators ♣ present ♥ Chuukese lineages and chiefs were not organized bureaucratically: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_410_FmTrukL] 'The domestic unit was an extended family, based on the women of a lineage or sublineage. It consisted of at least one experienced older woman and two more younger women of childbearing age together with their husbands. Unmarried sons and brothers slept apart in their lineage's meeting house. Extended family households continued through the periods of foreign administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_411_FmTrukL] 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_412_FmTrukL] 'A district chiefship was divided between the oldest man in the senior female line in the chiefly lineage and the oldest man in the lineage generally. The latter was executive chief, or "chief of talk," and the former symbolic chief, or "chief of food." Food presentations were made to the symbolic chief. Sometimes the symbolic and executive functions fell to the same individual; often they did not. The symbolic chief was surrounded by his lineage brothers and by his sons, who acted as his agents. These followers and his sisters and daughters were of chiefly rank, distinct from commoners. Through conquest, a lineage might gain the chiefship in more than one district and establish a junior branch as the chiefly lineage in the conquered district. The now subordinate district rendered food presentations to the superordinate one. Most districts were linked in two rival leagues based on competing schools of magic and ritual relating to war, politics, and rhetoric. A chief's authority derived from two things. His lineage's ownership of the district's space entitled him to presentations of first fruits at stated times of the year. More importantly, it gave him authority over the conservation and use of the district's food resources. His authority also derived from his connection with the sky world, its gods, and their superhuman power to accomplish purposes. There was, therefore, a degree of sacredness associated with chiefs.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_413_FmTrukL] The colonial government appointed head chiefs for the main islands: 'On the main islands the German government introduced head chiefs (somol lap) who carried the flag. There were six of them, one each on Poloas, Uman, Fefan, Wöla, Udot, and Pol /Pul/. The smaller islands likewise belonged to the sphere of power of the head chiefs. But even this institution could not link the tribes together within themselves or with one another. Some of the lower chiefs sympathize with the head chief for egotistical reasons; others fight against him violently for the same reasons. One who is with him today might be against him tomorrow because he somehow stepped on his toes. It is often enough for the subchief to fight the head chief if his neighboring chief supports him. Thus the picture is constantly changing. [Page 125] There is a continuous, sometimes quiet, sometimes open, warfare of the subchiefs against the head chiefs, the lower chiefs among themselves, the common people against the chiefs. The main reason for this disagreeable phenomenon is the limitless egotism of the Truk people. Everyone strives more or less to be something of a chief also. Strong families who do not like the chief attempt to isolate themselves and choose one from their midst. In addition to this, there are also old family enmities and disputes about land. It is obvious that the islands will never be able to achieve peaceful development in this manner. It is difficult to say who is most to blame for it. In any case the chiefs are not to be pitied, because they behave themselves accordingly. They are to be blamed mostly for the exploitation of the people, their corruptibility, and partiality. Many of them unhesitatingly accept money and objects and help the giver, no matter how many times he is in the wrong.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_414_FmTrukL] However, these head chiefs were not bureaucrats. Some islanders were recruited by the colonial administration as petty officials: 'The purpose of the schools for natives, judging from both reported policies and the Japanese school regulations was to civilize the natives and make them into loyal and economically useful citizens of the Japanese empire.
