While there was theoretically no limit to the higher education which the native child with sufficient ability and financial support might obtain, in actual fact only a minority of Trukese children attended the fourth and fifth grades, and only a minority of those completing fifth grade obtained further education at the vocational schools. Apparently no Trukese native obtained any academic education beyond fifth grade, except incidentally along with vocational training. The system was geared in effect to produce a supply of general laborers and domestic servants who understood the Japanese language, plus a small elite of skilled laborers and petty officials.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_415_FmTrukL] State-level administrators were probably drawn from the German and Japanese military. We have coded colonial officials as 'state-level administrators' and native petty officials as 'local administrators'. As the material incorporated into the data sheet so far does not address the colonial administration in detail, many of the below codes are based on inference and are thus in need of confirmation.
♠ Prestige of state-level bureaucracy ♣ higher ♥ Higher-ranking colonial officials were drawn from the German and Japanese military, not the native population (see above).[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Authority over state-level administrators
♠ Direct ♣ absent ♥
♠ Indirect ♣ absent ♥
♠ Diffused ♣ absent ♥
♠ Mixed ♣ absent ♥
♠ Governmental control ♣ present ♥ We have assumed governmental control over German and Japanese colonial officials (see above).
♠ Non-governmental oversight ♣ absent ♥Source of Support of state-level officials
♠ State salary ♣ inferred present ♥ We have assumed that colonial administrators and native petty officials were compensated in the form of a state salary. Government chiefs received a share in the taxes they collected for the government: 'Upon the delivery of the head tax the chiefs were given a few marks back from the German government as gratification. All in all the chief’s office is not a position which can make the possessor rich. It is understandable if the chief further bleeds his people somewhat on the side, especially since often enough he must draw on his purse in their behalf. If two families quarrel on account of something and the one must pay compensation, it is advanced by the chief if the family cannot pay. If someone from a foreign tribe has a claim on a member of his tribe, the chief is responsible for it. All creditors depend on him. Afterwards he can see to getting it back from the debtors. It is strange that the chief is even obliged to distribute gifts here and there. If he sees that one of his people is stirred up about something and he fears disagreeable /118/ scenes, he calms him with little gifts. [Page 129] He knows from experience that the subjects are able to annoy the chief more than he them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_416_FmTrukL] Native officials were coded as 'local administrators'.
♠ Governed population ♣ absent ♥
♠ Land ♣ absent ♥
♠ None ♣ absent ♥
♠ Other ♣ absent ♥Pathologies
♠ Corruption ♣ ♥ We have found no material on pathologies so far, although this cannot be ruled out.
♠ Bribery ♣ ♥
♠ Abuse of power ♣ ♥
♠ Professionalization of state-level bureaucracy ♣ present ♥ We have assumed that German and Japanese members of the colonial military administration were professionals and eligible for promotion.
♠ modal number of years state-level bureaucrats spend in service ♣ ♥ We have found no figures on this.
♠ Promotion of state-level officials to other positions ♣ present ♥ We have assumed that German and Japanese members of the colonial military administration were professionals and eligible for promotion.
♠ Frequency of promotion of state-level officials to other positions ♣ ♥ We have found no figures on this.
♠ Promotion from lower ranks ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of native petty officials being promoted into higher-level positions within the colonial military administration.
♠ Frequency of promotion of state-level officials from lower ranks ♣ ♥

Local-level officials (provincial, regional, civic administration)[edit]

♠ Number of regional administrative units ♣ ♥ This might correspond to the number of district or head chiefs.
♠ Local-level administrators ♣ present ♥ Chuukese lineages and chiefs were not organized bureaucratically: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_417_FmTrukL] 'The domestic unit was an extended family, based on the women of a lineage or sublineage. It consisted of at least one experienced older woman and two more younger women of childbearing age together with their husbands. Unmarried sons and brothers slept apart in their lineage's meeting house. Extended family households continued through the periods of foreign administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_418_FmTrukL] 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_419_FmTrukL] 'A district chiefship was divided between the oldest man in the senior female line in the chiefly lineage and the oldest man in the lineage generally. The latter was executive chief, or "chief of talk," and the former symbolic chief, or "chief of food." Food presentations were made to the symbolic chief. Sometimes the symbolic and executive functions fell to the same individual; often they did not. The symbolic chief was surrounded by his lineage brothers and by his sons, who acted as his agents. These followers and his sisters and daughters were of chiefly rank, distinct from commoners. Through conquest, a lineage might gain the chiefship in more than one district and establish a junior branch as the chiefly lineage in the conquered district. The now subordinate district rendered food presentations to the superordinate one. Most districts were linked in two rival leagues based on competing schools of magic and ritual relating to war, politics, and rhetoric. A chief's authority derived from two things. His lineage's ownership of the district's space entitled him to presentations of first fruits at stated times of the year. More importantly, it gave him authority over the conservation and use of the district's food resources. His authority also derived from his connection with the sky world, its gods, and their superhuman power to accomplish purposes. There was, therefore, a degree of sacredness associated with chiefs.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_420_FmTrukL] The colonial government appointed head chiefs for the main islands: 'On the main islands the German government introduced head chiefs (somol lap) who carried the flag. There were six of them, one each on Poloas, Uman, Fefan, Wöla, Udot, and Pol /Pul/. The smaller islands likewise belonged to the sphere of power of the head chiefs. But even this institution could not link the tribes together within themselves or with one another. Some of the lower chiefs sympathize with the head chief for egotistical reasons; others fight against him violently for the same reasons. One who is with him today might be against him tomorrow because he somehow stepped on his toes. It is often enough for the subchief to fight the head chief if his neighboring chief supports him. Thus the picture is constantly changing. [Page 125] There is a continuous, sometimes quiet, sometimes open, warfare of the subchiefs against the head chiefs, the lower chiefs among themselves, the common people against the chiefs. The main reason for this disagreeable phenomenon is the limitless egotism of the Truk people. Everyone strives more or less to be something of a chief also. Strong families who do not like the chief attempt to isolate themselves and choose one from their midst. In addition to this, there are also old family enmities and disputes about land. It is obvious that the islands will never be able to achieve peaceful development in this manner. It is difficult to say who is most to blame for it. In any case the chiefs are not to be pitied, because they behave themselves accordingly. They are to be blamed mostly for the exploitation of the people, their corruptibility, and partiality. Many of them unhesitatingly accept money and objects and help the giver, no matter how many times he is in the wrong.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_421_FmTrukL] However, head chiefs were not bureaucrats. In the colonial period, some islanders were recruited by the colonial administration as petty officials: 'The purpose of the schools for natives, judging from both reported policies and the Japanese school regulations was to civilize the natives and make them into loyal and economically useful citizens of the Japanese empire. While there was theoretically no limit to the higher education which the native child with sufficient ability and financial support might obtain, in actual fact only a minority of Trukese children attended the fourth and fifth grades, and only a minority of those completing fifth grade obtained further education at the vocational schools. Apparently no Trukese native obtained any academic education beyond fifth grade, except incidentally along with vocational training. The system was geared in effect to produce a supply of general laborers and domestic servants who understood the Japanese language, plus a small elite of skilled laborers and petty officials.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_422_FmTrukL] More information is needed.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Authority over local-level administrators
♠ Direct ♣ absent ♥
♠ Indirect ♣ absent ♥
♠ Diffused ♣ absent ♥
♠ Mixed ♣ absent ♥
♠ Governmental control ♣ present ♥ We have assumed that petty officials were under direct governmental control (see above).
♠ Non-governmental oversight ♣ absent ♥Source of Support of local-level officials
♠ State salary ♣ present ♥ Government chiefs received a share in the taxes they collected for the government: 'Upon the delivery of the head tax the chiefs were given a few marks back from the German government as gratification. All in all the chief’s office is not a position which can make the possessor rich. It is understandable if the chief further bleeds his people somewhat on the side, especially since often enough he must draw on his purse in their behalf. If two families quarrel on account of something and the one must pay compensation, it is advanced by the chief if the family cannot pay. If someone from a foreign tribe has a claim on a member of his tribe, the chief is responsible for it. All creditors depend on him. Afterwards he can see to getting it back from the debtors. It is strange that the chief is even obliged to distribute gifts here and there. If he sees that one of his people is stirred up about something and he fears disagreeable /118/ scenes, he calms him with little gifts. [Page 129] He knows from experience that the subjects are able to annoy the chief more than he them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_423_FmTrukL] We have assumed that native petty officials were compensated in the form of a state salary.
♠ Governed population ♣ absent ♥ Government chiefs received a share in the taxes they collected for the government (see above). However, we have coded for petty officials here, not government chiefs.
♠ Land ♣ absent ♥
♠ None ♣ absent ♥
♠ Other ♣ absent ♥Pathologies
♠ Corruption ♣ ♥ We have found no evidence of pathologies so far, but this cannot be ruled out.
♠ Bribery ♣ ♥
♠ Abuse of power ♣ ♥
♠ Professionalization of local bureaucracy ♣ present ♥ It is unclear from the above description whether native officals were employed on a part-time or full-time basis. We have assumed full-time for the time being. Given the purpose of the emerging education system as a supplier of future administrators, petty officials may have been professionals.
♠ modal number of years local bureaucrats spend in service ♣ ♥ We have found no figures on this.
♠ Multiple legal systems ♣ present ♥ SCCS variable 89 'Judiciary' is coded as ‘1’ or 'absent'. Chiefs served as primary judicial authorities on the local level: 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_424_FmTrukL] 'A district chiefship was divided between the oldest man in the senior female line in the chiefly lineage and the oldest man in the lineage generally. The latter was executive chief, or "chief of talk," and the former symbolic chief, or "chief of food." Food presentations were made to the symbolic chief. Sometimes the symbolic and executive functions fell to the same individual; often they did not. The symbolic chief was surrounded by his lineage brothers and by his sons, who acted as his agents. These followers and his sisters and daughters were of chiefly rank, distinct from commoners. Through conquest, a lineage might gain the chiefship in more than one district and establish a junior branch as the chiefly lineage in the conquered district. The now subordinate district rendered food presentations to the superordinate one. Most districts were linked in two rival leagues based on competing schools of magic and ritual relating to war, politics, and rhetoric. A chief's authority derived from two things. His lineage's ownership of the district's space entitled him to presentations of first fruits at stated times of the year. More importantly, it gave him authority over the conservation and use of the district's food resources. His authority also derived from his connection with the sky world, its gods, and their superhuman power to accomplish purposes. There was, therefore, a degree of sacredness associated with chiefs.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_425_FmTrukL] Writing in the colonial period, Bollig describes the resolution of disputes in public meetings: 'The chief does all these duties in the kobu[unknown], the public meeting. Men as well as women are invited to this kobu[unknown]. All the participants are called together by the blowing of the large shell from the chief’s house. The kobu[unknown] takes place in the udd, the large men’s house. All the dealings of the tribe are discussed in it, marital matters, land matters, quarrels, in short, all the linen, whether clean or dirty, is spread out before all eyes. Everybody is allowed to talk and present his complaints. Of course there is no lack of amusing scenes too. Sometimes the people become so excited that the parties insult each other, grab each other, and come to blows, so that the meeting has to be dissolved. The following remark was made in a kobu[unknown] which I attended: “He is a bad fellow because he stole my log.” The person insulted in such a manner jumped up angrily and defended himself so convincingly that the accuser let his head sink and replied dejectedly: “ Kinisou, mei bu[unknown]me rem, excuse me, you are right.” In another kobu[unknown] a subchief said to the head chief: “I do not like you as head chief, for you put some into paradise, others into hell.” With this plain allusion to his partiality, the head chief became very excited, while the audience laughed. From the same chief came the familiar quotation: “ siwilin ni efot, ni efot; siwilim mas eu, mas eu, ina Lamalamen Moses, /116/ tooth for tooth, eye for eye, that is the religion of Moses.” As one sees, the chief concerned had not read the Protestant Bible in vain and knew very well how to cloak his thirst for revenge very nicely. Things go along quite pleasantly in the kobu[unknown] of the Truk people. Each one chatters as long and as [Page 127] much as he likes. If he uses sharp, objectionable expressions, wiser ones will certainly call out to him: “ a emuen, it is enough.” Some smoke, some eat. One sits on the floor, another one on an upturned bowl, or anywhere else. Here and there one also sees some who are asleep, tired from listening for a long time. In short it goes along in true Kanaka fashion, and the result of the kobu[unknown], usually lasting for hours, is “much ado about nothing.” The matter at issue remains as it was, or it has become even more complicated. The government has often tried to give the kobu[unknown] a more serious air, but quite in vain. The main person at the kobu[unknown] is the chief, who makes the decision in the individual cases. Formerly his decision was absolutely decisive for all questions. In more recent times appeal to a higher authority, to the head chief and the government, has been possible. The government has also pruned the jurisdiction of the chief. Some things are reserved solely for the head chief, some solely for the government representative. During the kobu[unknown], the chief is surrounded by his relatives and advisors who watch over him. If he wants to say something that does not suit them, they call out to him: “ a niku[unknown], that is too much.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_426_FmTrukL] The judicial powers of the chiefs were diminished somewhat in the colonial period: 'The chief’s authority to punish no longer goes very far. Once master over life and death, now he can only order imprisonment or hard labor. The hard labor usually consists of pulling grass on public roads or carrying stones to canoe wharves. Nevertheless the people do not hurt themselves at this work and get out of it whenever they can. Instead of pulling grass, they sit smoking and talking on the road. They also know how to appear sick in order to be left completely free. The feeding of condemned persons is a matter for his relatives. For the duration of the punishment the natives live in the jail ( kalapus) . Each head chief has two kalapus, one for men and the other for women. On some islands the kalapus contributed greatly to the depravity of morals, since both sexes were housed in the same room. Similarly the wardens of the prisoners used the opportunity to satisfy their passions and to do business on the side by hiring out the imprisoned women.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_427_FmTrukL] 'On the other hand, the chief acquired a number of restrictions on the exercise of his power which either did not exist before, or which had not been so clear and consistent. It was not possible to appeal a chief’s judicial decisions, or to go to higher authority to change or reverse a chief’s plans for coordinated activity. With the coming of the American administration a further restriction appeared in the, theoretically at least, independent community legislature to whose laws even the chief is subject. Under the Americans there is also an independent judiciary, so that the chief is no longer allowed, in theory, to mediate interlineage disputes. On balance, however, it would seem that the chiefs’ coordinating and planning powers were increased despite the new restrictions. The provision of effective and usable sanctions probably outweighs all the new limits imposed on the chiefs’ powers.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_428_FmTrukL] But colonial forces also backed chiefly resolutions in a manner not possible in the pre-colonial period: 'The Germans also provided effective force to support the chief’s decisions. Anyone refusing to obey a chief’s orders or rejecting his decision in a dispute was liable to internment in the “calaboose” spoken of so approvingly by the old man at the beginning of this paper. The might of the German, and, in turn, the Japanese and American administrations stood behind a chief’s words; and although some kind of appeal from his decisions was usually possible, the likelihood of anyone refusing to obey his clearly expressed mandates and escaping unscathed had become rather small.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_429_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, tribal laws were fluid rather than fixed, although the colonial administration increasingly sought to impose its own regulations: 'The main task of the chief is the laying down and execution of the bu[unknown]un fanu, that is, the tribal laws. In practice the bu[unknown] is usually illusory, since nobody wants to follow it. Not for nothing do the Truk people say sarcastically about the conditions on their islands: “ en sob me bu[unknown]un, each district has its own laws,” or what is even worse: “ en me bu[unknown]un,” freely translated: “So many heads, so many meanings.” Moreover, it is a duty of the chief to communicate to the people the regulations of the government, to see that they are carried out, and to collect the head tax.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_430_FmTrukL] Apparently, many customary regulations were no longer enforced under foreign administration: The effect of this ruling was to deprive the granting corporation of its residual title; once the grant was made, the grantee had full title. The grantee need not now render first fruits or obtain the grantor’s approval for transactions he wished to arrange. The head of the granting corporation could no longer claim to be sowuppwún; this title now belonged to the head of the recipient corporation if he wished to claim it. Some people on Romónum continue to follow traditional practice and continue to render gifts of first fruits to the traditional sowuppwún as a matter of courtesy, and there are some who still try to assert their right to first fruits under the traditional system. No one is compelled to follow traditional practice and a number of people no longer do so. It is my impression that scarcely anyone would do so if he felt that he would be seriously inconvenienced by it.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_431_FmTrukL] Goodenough mentions colonial courts that dealt with issues that could not be resolved on the local level: 'As soon as courts were re-established, they were deluged with property disputes. The Japanese had treated grants of corporation land to the children of one of its men as if they were an inheritance by a man’s children of his individually owned land. The result was that many disputes coming before the American high court were between the members of a corporation and the children of its men. The latter were disputing the residual title of the former and claiming full title for themselves, and the former were asserting their confiscatory and reversionary rights under traditional residual title. The court undertook seriously to follow local custom, but some witnesses presented the rulings of the Japanese courts as representing local custom whereas others presented the traditional system as local custom, depending on which representation was to their immediate advantage.The high court, I am told, chose to follow the precedent set by the Japanese and ruled that if it could be established that a corporation grant to the children of one of its men had been made with the consent of the corporation’s members, then the children had [Page 80] the same rights as if it had been their father’s personal property.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_432_FmTrukL] Accordingly, native systems of dispute resolution coexisted with formal colonial courts.
♠ Courts are supported by the state ♣ present ♥ Colonial courts were supported by the colonial military administration.
♠ Criminal Prosecution ♣ ♥ We are unsure whether colonial courts enforced criminal prosecution. It appears that they mostly dealth with litigation. Confirmation is needed.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Accessibility of the Legal System
♠ ruling elite ♣ present ♥ We have assumed that the general population (including natives) had access to colonial courts, given their role in adjudicating property disputes. This remains in need of confirmation.
♠ non-ruling elite ♣ present ♥
♠ general population ♣ present ♥
♠ foreign groups ♣ present ♥
♠ ethnic groups ♣ present ♥Accessibility of Trials
♠ ruling elite ♣ present ♥ We have assumed that the general population (including natives) had access to colonial courts, given their role in adjudicating property disputes. This remains in need of confirmation.
♠ non-ruling elite ♣ present ♥
♠ general population ♣ present ♥
♠ foreign groups ♣ present ♥
♠ ethnic groups ♣ present ♥Accessibility of Courts
♠ Courts in polity capital ♣ ♥ We are unsure how colonial courts were distributed across islands. Expert input may be needed.
♠ Courts in regional capitals ♣ ♥
♠ Courts in provincial towns ♣ ♥
♠ Typical speed of judicial proceedings in criminal cases ♣ ♥ We have found no figures on this.
♠ Typical speed of judicial proceedings in civil cases ♣ ♥ We have found no figures on this.

Informal Justice[edit]

♠ Non-state judiciary ♣ present ♥ SCCS variable 89 'Judiciary' is coded as ‘1’ or 'absent'. Chiefs served as primary judicial authorities on the local level: 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_433_FmTrukL] 'A district chiefship was divided between the oldest man in the senior female line in the chiefly lineage and the oldest man in the lineage generally. The latter was executive chief, or "chief of talk," and the former symbolic chief, or "chief of food." Food presentations were made to the symbolic chief. Sometimes the symbolic and executive functions fell to the same individual; often they did not. The symbolic chief was surrounded by his lineage brothers and by his sons, who acted as his agents. These followers and his sisters and daughters were of chiefly rank, distinct from commoners. Through conquest, a lineage might gain the chiefship in more than one district and establish a junior branch as the chiefly lineage in the conquered district. The now subordinate district rendered food presentations to the superordinate one. Most districts were linked in two rival leagues based on competing schools of magic and ritual relating to war, politics, and rhetoric. A chief's authority derived from two things. His lineage's ownership of the district's space entitled him to presentations of first fruits at stated times of the year. More importantly, it gave him authority over the conservation and use of the district's food resources. His authority also derived from his connection with the sky world, its gods, and their superhuman power to accomplish purposes. There was, therefore, a degree of sacredness associated with chiefs.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_434_FmTrukL] Writing in the colonial period, Bollig describes the resolution of disputes in public meetings: 'The chief does all these duties in the kobu[unknown], the public meeting. Men as well as women are invited to this kobu[unknown]. All the participants are called together by the blowing of the large shell from the chief’s house. The kobu[unknown] takes place in the udd, the large men’s house. All the dealings of the tribe are discussed in it, marital matters, land matters, quarrels, in short, all the linen, whether clean or dirty, is spread out before all eyes. Everybody is allowed to talk and present his complaints. Of course there is no lack of amusing scenes too. Sometimes the people become so excited that the parties insult each other, grab each other, and come to blows, so that the meeting has to be dissolved. The following remark was made in a kobu[unknown] which I attended: “He is a bad fellow because he stole my log.” The person insulted in such a manner jumped up angrily and defended himself so convincingly that the accuser let his head sink and replied dejectedly: “ Kinisou, mei bu[unknown]me rem, excuse me, you are right.” In another kobu[unknown] a subchief said to the head chief: “I do not like you as head chief, for you put some into paradise, others into hell.” With this plain allusion to his partiality, the head chief became very excited, while the audience laughed. From the same chief came the familiar quotation: “ siwilin ni efot, ni efot; siwilim mas eu, mas eu, ina Lamalamen Moses, /116/ tooth for tooth, eye for eye, that is the religion of Moses.” As one sees, the chief concerned had not read the Protestant Bible in vain and knew very well how to cloak his thirst for revenge very nicely. Things go along quite pleasantly in the kobu[unknown] of the Truk people. Each one chatters as long and as [Page 127] much as he likes. If he uses sharp, objectionable expressions, wiser ones will certainly call out to him: “ a emuen, it is enough.” Some smoke, some eat. One sits on the floor, another one on an upturned bowl, or anywhere else. Here and there one also sees some who are asleep, tired from listening for a long time. In short it goes along in true Kanaka fashion, and the result of the kobu[unknown], usually lasting for hours, is “much ado about nothing.” The matter at issue remains as it was, or it has become even more complicated. The government has often tried to give the kobu[unknown] a more serious air, but quite in vain. The main person at the kobu[unknown] is the chief, who makes the decision in the individual cases. Formerly his decision was absolutely decisive for all questions. In more recent times appeal to a higher authority, to the head chief and the government, has been possible. The government has also pruned the jurisdiction of the chief. Some things are reserved solely for the head chief, some solely for the government representative. During the kobu[unknown], the chief is surrounded by his relatives and advisors who watch over him. If he wants to say something that does not suit them, they call out to him: “ a niku[unknown], that is too much.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_435_FmTrukL] The judicial powers of the chiefs were diminished somewhat in the colonial period: 'The chief’s authority to punish no longer goes very far. Once master over life and death, now he can only order imprisonment or hard labor. The hard labor usually consists of pulling grass on public roads or carrying stones to canoe wharves. Nevertheless the people do not hurt themselves at this work and get out of it whenever they can. Instead of pulling grass, they sit smoking and talking on the road. They also know how to appear sick in order to be left completely free. The feeding of condemned persons is a matter for his relatives. For the duration of the punishment the natives live in the jail ( kalapus) . Each head chief has two kalapus, one for men and the other for women. On some islands the kalapus contributed greatly to the depravity of morals, since both sexes were housed in the same room. Similarly the wardens of the prisoners used the opportunity to satisfy their passions and to do business on the side by hiring out the imprisoned women.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_436_FmTrukL] 'On the other hand, the chief acquired a number of restrictions on the exercise of his power which either did not exist before, or which had not been so clear and consistent. It was not possible to appeal a chief’s judicial decisions, or to go to higher authority to change or reverse a chief’s plans for coordinated activity. With the coming of the American administration a further restriction appeared in the, theoretically at least, independent community legislature to whose laws even the chief is subject. Under the Americans there is also an independent judiciary, so that the chief is no longer allowed, in theory, to mediate interlineage disputes. On balance, however, it would seem that the chiefs’ coordinating and planning powers were increased despite the new restrictions. The provision of effective and usable sanctions probably outweighs all the new limits imposed on the chiefs’ powers.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_437_FmTrukL] But colonial forces also backed chiefly resolutions in a manner not possible in the pre-colonial period: 'The Germans also provided effective force to support the chief’s decisions. Anyone refusing to obey a chief’s orders or rejecting his decision in a dispute was liable to internment in the “calaboose” spoken of so approvingly by the old man at the beginning of this paper. The might of the German, and, in turn, the Japanese and American administrations stood behind a chief’s words; and although some kind of appeal from his decisions was usually possible, the likelihood of anyone refusing to obey his clearly expressed mandates and escaping unscathed had become rather small.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_438_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, tribal laws were fluid rather than fixed, although the colonial administration increasingly sought to impose its own regulations: 'The main task of the chief is the laying down and execution of the bu[unknown]un fanu, that is, the tribal laws. In practice the bu[unknown] is usually illusory, since nobody wants to follow it. Not for nothing do the Truk people say sarcastically about the conditions on their islands: “ en sob me bu[unknown]un, each district has its own laws,” or what is even worse: “ en me bu[unknown]un,” freely translated: “So many heads, so many meanings.” Moreover, it is a duty of the chief to communicate to the people the regulations of the government, to see that they are carried out, and to collect the head tax.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_439_FmTrukL] Apparently, many customary regulations were no longer enforced under foreign administration: The effect of this ruling was to deprive the granting corporation of its residual title; once the grant was made, the grantee had full title. The grantee need not now render first fruits or obtain the grantor’s approval for transactions he wished to arrange. The head of the granting corporation could no longer claim to be sowuppwún; this title now belonged to the head of the recipient corporation if he wished to claim it. Some people on Romónum continue to follow traditional practice and continue to render gifts of first fruits to the traditional sowuppwún as a matter of courtesy, and there are some who still try to assert their right to first fruits under the traditional system. No one is compelled to follow traditional practice and a number of people no longer do so. It is my impression that scarcely anyone would do so if he felt that he would be seriously inconvenienced by it.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_440_FmTrukL] Goodenough mentions colonial courts that dealt with issues that could not be resolved on the local level: 'As soon as courts were re-established, they were deluged with property disputes. The Japanese had treated grants of corporation land to the children of one of its men as if they were an inheritance by a man’s children of his individually owned land. The result was that many disputes coming before the American high court were between the members of a corporation and the children of its men. The latter were disputing the residual title of the former and claiming full title for themselves, and the former were asserting their confiscatory and reversionary rights under traditional residual title. The court undertook seriously to follow local custom, but some witnesses presented the rulings of the Japanese courts as representing local custom whereas others presented the traditional system as local custom, depending on which representation was to their immediate advantage.The high court, I am told, chose to follow the precedent set by the Japanese and ruled that if it could be established that a corporation grant to the children of one of its men had been made with the consent of the corporation’s members, then the children had [Page 80] the same rights as if it had been their father’s personal property.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_441_FmTrukL] We have coded chiefs and headmen as 'non-state judiciary'.
♠ Religious judiciary ♣ absent ♥

Property Rights[edit]

♠ Private property (land) ♣ present ♥ Land was held by both individuals and corporate descent groups: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_442_FmTrukL] 'Individually-owned property was inherited by the owner's children. Corporately-owned property was inherited by the corporation's 'children' (the children of its men) when the corporation's membership died out.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_443_FmTrukL] Women commonly held property, but husbands and children retained usufruct rights over the property of mothers and wives: 'The right to private property exists among the Truk natives. Everyone of them, be it man or woman, adult or child, can own property, for example, land, houses, cattle, money, etc. Whatever the wife brings into the marriage remains wholly at her disposal.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_444_FmTrukL] 'The husband and children, however, do have usufruct rights to her property. If she goes back to her family because of death or divorce, then she takes her property with her again. In practice a certain communism prevails, since siblings, members of the same kin group, often live together and cultivate their lands and enjoy the fruits together. This, however, lasts only as long as there are no quarrels among the families.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_445_FmTrukL] Elder brothers held supervision rights over property owned by the sib: 'In contrast to this indirectly communistic property, there is also that which is directly communistic, for example, land. They call it fanu uon ar puipui, land of their brotherhood. Yet the oldest brother plays a special part in connection with all the property. He not only has the supervision and usufruct right to the property of the younger siblings, which goes back to the common [Page 132] father, but he can also withdraw it from them. Since this not infrequently happens, the oldest is usually also the richest in each family. /121/ The oldest has no rights over the property which the younger ones have obtained from other sources. To make up for the fact that the oldest has such extensive rights, he has the obligation to care for his siblings in certain ways.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_446_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, disputes over land rights were common: 'The land rights of the Truk people are not based on justice, but on the right of the stronger, the cleverer. There is hardly a plot of land with a clear legal history, and for that reason there are the constant assertions of legal claims, the eternal lawsuits over land. The boldest and most cunning persons always have the best land on Truk. Pretenses for bringing legal claims to foreign property before the chief are easily found in the confused conditions. And once they are found, the Kanakas’ inexhaustible power of invention and art of lying take care of making them convincing to others. That briberies of chiefs, interpreters, and witnesses play a tremendous part in this is obvious, considering the character of the Truk people. No means is too wicked for them in order to “profit. ”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_447_FmTrukL] 'A source of land disputes is the exchange of lands. For example: Soni and Soledon exchange two pieces of land. Soni now cultivates his land, while Soledon lets it lie fallow. Soledon dies. His children, who are not on good terms with Soni, cancel the exchange and take possession of the productive piece of land as property of their deceased father. Soni resists. The parties quarrel for years. Sometimes the one wins, sometimes the other, but no one yields.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_448_FmTrukL] In practice, the boundaries between land owned by different individuals could be vague: 'The boundaries of the lands are very vague. They change continually under the hands of both neighbors. Sometimes the one, sometimes the other one, goes beyond them. Then they quarrel. What A has planted B tears out, with the argument that it is already on his territory. What B has planted A tears out, with the same argument. Now which of the two is right?' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_449_FmTrukL] 'With such uncertain legal conditions it is not at all surprising that quarrels over land are daily events on Truk. Every death, every divorce, every new marriage has a coil of rats’ tails in quarrels as a result. The boundless egotism of the Truk natives is responsible for all this. Everybody wants to have as much as possible. A Trukese can quarrel for years about a tree, a plant, or a foot of land, even though he has plenty of trees that are not producing anything because of lack of care. The German government gave the natives land documents on which the owner, along with all his pieces of land, was recorded. /123/ The hopes placed on this have not been fulfilled. Today everything is as confused as before.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_450_FmTrukL] Rights in land were differentiated from rights in plantings: 'The Truk people are familiar with a distinction of the ground from what is planted on it. Thus, somebody may possess a piece of land, but the trees that stand on it belong to other people. They or their parents once planted the trees on his property, which is permissible according to Truk customs. If the owners of the trees are dishonest, they need only clear the field beginning from the trees, continue to cultivate, and the poor owner is dispossessed. What confused situations that causes in the case of an eventual transfer of the piece of land to another is easily understandable. I myself have had difficulties for years, since certain people still held on to “their” trees after the piece of land had long been the property of the mission. Only the felling of the trees put an end to all claims.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_451_FmTrukL] Ownership was claimed and asserted through material markings: 'The natives try to document their right of ownership to pieces of land by clearing something on it from time to time, or they build huts on the individual pieces of land, which they then inhabit temporarily. Dying fathers give their children directions to bury them on their pieces of land so that their grave might thus be proof of ownership for the future. One can often hear in the kobu[unknown] that this is precisely what the people refer to.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_452_FmTrukL] 'The riri, that is, to bind, forms a strange title deed on the Truk Islands. For example, somebody sees a tree which bears many fruits. Since he would like some too, he takes the ubud of a coconut palm and wraps it around a branch of the tree in order to make his intention known publicly. In many cases the owner resists such oppression and tears off the ubud. But also in many cases he keeps quiet in order to avoid bigger quarrels.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_453_FmTrukL] 'I myself have had experiences with the riri in that the girls “bound” pineapples for themselves on my plot of land, which I did not allow, of course. The riri is also done in connection with animals, only by words here, of course. They say, for example: “ A riri lon lelugei enan tugo, it is bound in my heart, this chicken, ” that is, it is my property. Then they also further take the wor d riri with a moral obligation. One says, for example: [Page 135] “U a riri uon enan a[unknown]a[unknown], I am bound to that work, ” that is, I am obliged to do it. In any case the former riri is the root of the latter.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_454_FmTrukL] Land could be transferred through barter in the manner of other goods; it appears that barter was widely used even in the colonial period: 'The acquisition of property on Truk is usually done by means of barter. Lands, houses, and canoes are bartered. Smaller units of exchange are sebi (wooden bowls), deig (curcuma), faupar (red shell disks), hip mats, modesty bands, fishing nets, aromatic oils, coconut cord, home-grown tobacco, and sleeping mats. These products of native industry are not present in like quantity or in like quality on all the islands. Thus, Sapesis on Fefan is famous for its fine bowls, Pol for curcuma and oils, Iluk for its fine hip mats.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_455_FmTrukL] Bollig claims that vague and flexible property arrangements among islanders impacted the management of plantations in the colonial period: 'A few decades ago the sandy shore was wilderness. Only gradually, under the influence of Europeans, were coconuts planted,for only this kind of cultivation is possible in the sand. Regular, clean grounds, however, are not to the taste of the Truk people. Coconut trees, breadfruit trees, and forest trees stand higgledy-piggledy, usually so densely that some of them never bear. The confused legal conditions of the natives are shown most glaringly on the shore. Thirty trees, which stand side by side, belong to several owners, for example: coconut tree No. 1 [Page 157] belongs to A, Nos. 2 and 3 to B, No. 4 to A again, etc. One can imagine how many quarrels about the falling fruit result from that.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_456_FmTrukL]
♠ Usufruct ♣ present ♥ Women commonly held property, but husbands and children retained usufruct rights over the property of mothers and wives: 'The right to private property exists among the Truk natives. Everyone of them, be it man or woman, adult or child, can own property, for example, land, houses, cattle, money, etc. Whatever the wife brings into the marriage remains wholly at her disposal.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_457_FmTrukL] 'The husband and children, however, do have usufruct rights to her property. If she goes back to her family because of death or divorce, then she takes her property with her again. In practice a certain communism prevails, since siblings, members of the same kin group, often live together and cultivate their lands and enjoy the fruits together. This, however, lasts only as long as there are no quarrels among the families.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_458_FmTrukL]
♠ Exclusivity ♣ present ♥ Land was held by both individuals and corporate descent groups: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_459_FmTrukL] 'Individually-owned property was inherited by the owner's children. Corporately-owned property was inherited by the corporation's 'children' (the children of its men) when the corporation's membership died out.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_460_FmTrukL] Elder brothers held supervision rights over inherited land held by the sib, but land obtained from other sources was the exclusive property of younger siblings: 'In contrast to this indirectly communistic property, there is also that which is directly communistic, for example, land. They call it fanu uon ar puipui, land of their brotherhood. Yet the oldest brother plays a special part in connection with all the property. He not only has the supervision and usufruct right to the property of the younger siblings, which goes back to the common [Page 132] father, but he can also withdraw it from them. Since this not infrequently happens, the oldest is usually also the richest in each family. /121/ The oldest has no rights over the property which the younger ones have obtained from other sources. To make up for the fact that the oldest has such extensive rights, he has the obligation to care for his siblings in certain ways.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_461_FmTrukL] Males could exclude children from inherited land: 'If a man dies, the lands which belonged to him personally pass on to his children. Such land is called fanuei me uon semei, my land from my father. The particulars of the distribution are left completely to his discretion. He can also exclude one child or another, as he likes. The lands that he has jointly with his brothers, however, are taken by them. It frequently happens that the brothers, in case the children are minors, take all the lands in order to administer them, whereby one piece or another remains in their hands forever. In general the father considers only the children from the present marriage. Children from former marriages, who live with the mother’s relatives, are not considered. For that they would have had to rejoin him again later. The mother’s property too only in part passes to the children, since her brothers and sisters likewise do not want to come out short.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_462_FmTrukL]
♠ Partibility ♣ present ♥ Inheritance was partible: 'If a man dies, the lands which belonged to him personally pass on to his children. Such land is called fanuei me uon semei, my land from my father. The particulars of the distribution are left completely to his discretion. He can also exclude one child or another, as he likes. The lands that he has jointly with his brothers, however, are taken by them. It frequently happens that the brothers, in case the children are minors, take all the lands in order to administer them, whereby one piece or another remains in their hands forever. In general the father considers only the children from the present marriage. Children from former marriages, who live with the mother’s relatives, are not considered. For that they would have had to rejoin him again later. The mother’s property too only in part passes to the children, since her brothers and sisters likewise do not want to come out short.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_463_FmTrukL]
♠ Lease ♣ present ♥ Prior to colonization, senior lineages and dominant clans could grant residential and usufruct rights to junior groups on a provisional basis: 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_464_FmTrukL] Individuals could also grant provisional land rights to other individuals: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_465_FmTrukL] We are unsure whether this constitutes lease according to our Code Book, but have assumed so for the time being. Monetized lease arrangements were introduced in the colonial period:: 'Rent for money is purely a foreign introduction and is still poorly understood on some of the outer islands. On Puluwat recently the owner of the plot on which the sub-dispensary stands was worried about accepting rent from the island. He believed that after a number of years as he gradually received the full value of the land in money his title to the land would inexorably slip away from him. On the other hand, he did want to be paid for the food trees cleared away to prepare the site of the building.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_466_FmTrukL]
♠ Lease Rights ♣ ♥ However, chiefs occasionally confiscated property granted to junior lineages and provisional title holders in case of disobedience (such as failure to deliver food prestations on the occasion of feasts): 'As noted above, the relations between a chief and the people of his district are patterned largely after the relations between the parties in divided ownership. As provisional title holders to territory, the various lineages owe the chief periodic gifts of produce from the land. These gifts are rendered at stated times in connection with feasts given in the chief’s honor. He fixes the time for these feasts in accordance with a seasonal calendar: two feasts during the breadfruit season, and two more during the turmeric season. The men of the various lineages prepare breadfruit in giant wooden bowls while the women fish. Other types of food are also collected. On the day of the feast each lineage brings its food in a procession, the men carrying the giant bowls on frames and chanting as they walk. The food is carried into the meeting house of the chief’s lineage. The chief then selects the largest bowl for himself and his lineage mates and redistributes the rest of the food to the assembled population. The distribution is made according to lineage and is roughly proportional to the size of each lineage. The contributions which each lineage makes are also proportional to the size of its membership and the amount of productive land which it controls. If a lineage fails in this obligation, the chief has the right to confiscate its holdings. Should he indicate dissatisfaction with the contribution of a particular lineage, its members will hasten to prepare additional food and other gifts to mollify him.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_467_FmTrukL] More information about the enforcement of monetized lease arrangements is needed.
♠ Transfer of property ♣ present ♥ Land was held by both individuals and corporate descent groups: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_468_FmTrukL] 'Individually-owned property was inherited by the owner's children. Corporately-owned property was inherited by the corporation's 'children' (the children of its men) when the corporation's membership died out.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_469_FmTrukL] Land was heritable: 'If a man dies, the lands which belonged to him personally pass on to his children. Such land is called fanuei me uon semei, my land from my father. The particulars of the distribution are left completely to his discretion. He can also exclude one child or another, as he likes. The lands that he has jointly with his brothers, however, are taken by them. It frequently happens that the brothers, in case the children are minors, take all the lands in order to administer them, whereby one piece or another remains in their hands forever. In general the father considers only the children from the present marriage. Children from former marriages, who live with the mother’s relatives, are not considered. For that they would have had to rejoin him again later. The mother’s property too only in part passes to the children, since her brothers and sisters likewise do not want to come out short.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_470_FmTrukL] Land could be transferred through barter in the manner of other goods: 'The acquisition of property on Truk is usually done by means of barter. Lands, houses, and canoes are bartered. Smaller units of exchange are sebi (wooden bowls), deig (curcuma), faupar (red shell disks), hip mats, modesty bands, fishing nets, aromatic oils, coconut cord, home-grown tobacco, and sleeping mats. These products of native industry are not present in like quantity or in like quality on all the islands. Thus, Sapesis on Fefan is famous for its fine bowls, Pol for curcuma and oils, Iluk for its fine hip mats.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_471_FmTrukL] Both men and women commonly bought and sold property: 'The position of the Truk woman in legal respects is not degrading. They are not weakly in the hands of the husband. I have seen men who were terribly henpecked. The women have their property, are able to acquire, buy, and sell without the husband’s consent. The children also belong exclusively to them. They have little work and for the most part are treated well, even if only to prevent them from running away. It is considered wrong to beat women.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_472_FmTrukL] 'The right to private property exists among the Truk natives. Everyone of them, be it man or woman, adult or child, can own property, for example, land, houses, cattle, money, etc. Whatever the wife brings into the marriage remains wholly at her disposal.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_473_FmTrukL] 'The husband and children, however, do have usufruct rights to her property. If she goes back to her family because of death or divorce, then she takes her property with her again. In practice a certain communism prevails, since siblings, members of the same kin group, often live together and cultivate their lands and enjoy the fruits together. This, however, lasts only as long as there are no quarrels among the families.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_474_FmTrukL] Property acquired through barter was treated differently from property acquired through inheritance: 'In contrast to this indirectly communistic property, there is also that which is directly communistic, for example, land. They call it fanu uon ar puipui, land of their brotherhood. Yet the oldest brother plays a special part in connection with all the property. He not only has the supervision and usufruct right to the property of the younger siblings, which goes back to the common [Page 132] father, but he can also withdraw it from them. Since this not infrequently happens, the oldest is usually also the richest in each family. /121/ The oldest has no rights over the property which the younger ones have obtained from other sources. To make up for the fact that the oldest has such extensive rights, he has the obligation to care for his siblings in certain ways.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_475_FmTrukL]
♠ Use of property ♣ ♥ We have found no evidence for specific uses of property poscribed for land owned by individuals. We have yet to confirm whether colonial administrators interfered with cultivation in this way.
♠ Property market ♣ ♥ We are unsure whether a true property market emerged in the colonial period.
♠ Other property ownership ♣ present ♥ 'The right to private property exists among the Truk natives. Everyone of them, be it man or woman, adult or child, can own property, for example, land, houses, cattle, money, etc. Whatever the wife brings into the marriage remains wholly at her disposal.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_476_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Inheritance System
♠ partible inheritance ♣ present ♥ Inheritance was partible: 'If a man dies, the lands which belonged to him personally pass on to his children. Such land is called fanuei me uon semei, my land from my father. The particulars of the distribution are left completely to his discretion. He can also exclude one child or another, as he likes. The lands that he has jointly with his brothers, however, are taken by them. It frequently happens that the brothers, in case the children are minors, take all the lands in order to administer them, whereby one piece or another remains in their hands forever. In general the father considers only the children from the present marriage. Children from former marriages, who live with the mother’s relatives, are not considered. For that they would have had to rejoin him again later. The mother’s property too only in part passes to the children, since her brothers and sisters likewise do not want to come out short.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_477_FmTrukL]
♠ patrilineal inheritance ♣ present ♥ Land held by corporate descent groups was transmitted matrilineally, but fathers also transmitted land to their own children: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_478_FmTrukL] 'Individually-owned property was inherited by the owner's children. Corporately-owned property was inherited by the corporation's 'children' (the children of its men) when the corporation's membership died out.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_479_FmTrukL] 'If a man dies, the lands which belonged to him personally pass on to his children. Such land is called fanuei me uon semei, my land from my father. The particulars of the distribution are left completely to his discretion. He can also exclude one child or another, as he likes. The lands that he has jointly with his brothers, however, are taken by them. It frequently happens that the brothers, in case the children are minors, take all the lands in order to administer them, whereby one piece or another remains in their hands forever. In general the father considers only the children from the present marriage. Children from former marriages, who live with the mother’s relatives, are not considered. For that they would have had to rejoin him again later. The mother’s property too only in part passes to the children, since her brothers and sisters likewise do not want to come out short.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_480_FmTrukL]
♠ matrilineal inheritance ♣ present ♥ Land held by corporate descent groups was transmitted matrilineally, but fathers also transmitted land to their own children: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_481_FmTrukL] 'Individually-owned property was inherited by the owner's children. Corporately-owned property was inherited by the corporation's 'children' (the children of its men) when the corporation's membership died out.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_482_FmTrukL] Husbands and children retained usufruct rights over land held by mothers and wives; sharing and cooperation within the sib was common: 'The right to private property exists among the Truk natives. Everyone of them, be it man or woman, adult or child, can own property, for example, land, houses, cattle, money, etc. Whatever the wife brings into the marriage remains wholly at her disposal.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_483_FmTrukL] 'The husband and children, however, do have usufruct rights to her property. If she goes back to her family because of death or divorce, then she takes her property with her again. In practice a certain communism prevails, since siblings, members of the same kin group, often live together and cultivate their lands and enjoy the fruits together. This, however, lasts only as long as there are no quarrels among the families.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_484_FmTrukL] Elder brothes held supervision rights over property owned by the sib: 'In contrast to this indirectly communistic property, there is also that which is directly communistic, for example, land. They call it fanu uon ar puipui, land of their brotherhood. Yet the oldest brother plays a special part in connection with all the property. He not only has the supervision and usufruct right to the property of the younger siblings, which goes back to the common [Page 132] father, but he can also withdraw it from them. Since this not infrequently happens, the oldest is usually also the richest in each family. /121/ The oldest has no rights over the property which the younger ones have obtained from other sources. To make up for the fact that the oldest has such extensive rights, he has the obligation to care for his siblings in certain ways.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_485_FmTrukL] The presence of both individually-held property and matrilineal descent groups affected the treatment of womens' property after their passing: 'If a man dies, the lands which belonged to him personally pass on to his children. Such land is called fanuei me uon semei, my land from my father. The particulars of the distribution are left completely to his discretion. He can also exclude one child or another, as he likes. The lands that he has jointly with his brothers, however, are taken by them. It frequently happens that the brothers, in case the children are minors, take all the lands in order to administer them, whereby one piece or another remains in their hands forever. In general the father considers only the children from the present marriage. Children from former marriages, who live with the mother’s relatives, are not considered. For that they would have had to rejoin him again later. The mother’s property too only in part passes to the children, since her brothers and sisters likewise do not want to come out short.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_486_FmTrukL]
♠ primogeniture inheritance by only males ♣ absent ♥ Elder brothers held supervision rights over property owned by the sib: 'In contrast to this indirectly communistic property, there is also that which is directly communistic, for example, land. They call it fanu uon ar puipui, land of their brotherhood. Yet the oldest brother plays a special part in connection with all the property. He not only has the supervision and usufruct right to the property of the younger siblings, which goes back to the common [Page 132] father, but he can also withdraw it from them. Since this not infrequently happens, the oldest is usually also the richest in each family. /121/ The oldest has no rights over the property which the younger ones have obtained from other sources. To make up for the fact that the oldest has such extensive rights, he has the obligation to care for his siblings in certain ways.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_487_FmTrukL] However, this does not amount to primogeniture inheritance.
♠ primogeniture inheritance by males and females ♣ absent ♥
♠ other inheritance practices ♣ present ♥ Corporate descent groups held land transmitted through matrilineal inheritance: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_488_FmTrukL] 'Individually-owned property was inherited by the owner's children. Corporately-owned property was inherited by the corporation's 'children' (the children of its men) when the corporation's membership died out.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_489_FmTrukL] Elder brothers held supervision rights over property owned by the sib: 'In contrast to this indirectly communistic property, there is also that which is directly communistic, for example, land. They call it fanu uon ar puipui, land of their brotherhood. Yet the oldest brother plays a special part in connection with all the property. He not only has the supervision and usufruct right to the property of the younger siblings, which goes back to the common [Page 132] father, but he can also withdraw it from them. Since this not infrequently happens, the oldest is usually also the richest in each family. /121/ The oldest has no rights over the property which the younger ones have obtained from other sources. To make up for the fact that the oldest has such extensive rights, he has the obligation to care for his siblings in certain ways.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_490_FmTrukL] Cooperation and sharing within the sib was common: 'The husband and children, however, do have usufruct rights to her property. If she goes back to her family because of death or divorce, then she takes her property with her again. In practice a certain communism prevails, since siblings, members of the same kin group, often live together and cultivate their lands and enjoy the fruits together. This, however, lasts only as long as there are no quarrels among the families.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_491_FmTrukL]
♠ Trusts ♣ absent ♥
♠ State expropriation ♣ absent ♥ We are as yet unsure whether the colonial state expropriated any inherited land. This seems likely, but remains in need of confirmation.
♠ Non-state expropriation ♣ absent ♥

Sex Class and Race[edit]

Marriage
♠ Monogamy ♣ ♥ The Chuukese were organized according to membership in matrilineal clans: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_492_FmTrukL] 'The domestic unit was an extended family, based on the women of a lineage or sublineage. It consisted of at least one experienced older woman and two more younger women of childbearing age together with their husbands. Unmarried sons and brothers slept apart in their lineage's meeting house. Extended family households continued through the periods of foreign administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_493_FmTrukL] According to Goodenough, levirate/sororate marriages were practiced: 'Marriage took place for women a bit before and for men a bit after the age of 20. Premarital courtship was covert and included sexual relations. Residence was usually matrilocal. Divorce, common before the birth of children, was rare thereafter. It could be initiated by either spouse and was often instigated by the wife's brothers. Levirate and sororate remarriages were valued. To keep soil and trees that had been granted to the children of a lineage's men circulating back, marriage preferences with one or another kind of cousin, varying from locality to locality, were widespread.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_494_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, polygyny was fairly widespread, partly as a result of levirate/sororate marriages: 'Polygamy (1) 1 a akaruu, he has two wives; a akaulu[unknown]at, he has three wives, etc. is very widespread on Truk. Men with two to nine wives are numerous. One becomes polygamous through the death of his brother, for out of brotherly love he has an obligation to take the widow for himself (levirate marriage). Another one marries a widow with daughters and takes the latter, as soon as they are old enough, as secondary wives. A third takes the sisters of his wife for himself, which is the case for most polygamous situations. The reasons for polygamy vary. One wants to keep landed property together by this means, or to concentrate it in his hands; another wants to have workers, since the secondary wives fish for him. Strangely enough, the motive forces for polygamy are said to be mostly the women themselves. They offer their daughters, sisters, [Page 109] and nieces to their husbands as secondary wives, in order that no strange family come in. This happens especially if they have no children, for if a strange woman comes in and gives birth to children, they will be pushed aside. They try to prevent this by means of the above measure. If polygamy has come about in this way, a peaceful life together is possible, for the women stay together in their own interests. But if the women come from different families or tribes, living together is out of the question. They live apart, and the man has the pleasant task of going back and forth. Unpleasantness and jealousy between the rivals are the order of the day. First one and then the other thinks she is being slighted. First one is tired, then the other. And the husband must always be on the move in order to keep everybody happy. Some polygamous situations which I knew were changing constantly. At one time the husband had four, then some ran away, later they increased to six, etc. A somewhat decent family life is inconceivable. The eventual /101/ children always go with the mother, but the father knows the means for drawing them to him when they are older, so that he will have a work force. Some polygamists are very generous with their wives. They are quickly ready to hand them over to their unmarried relatives, because it gives them advantages. They are able to take a new one and still consider the old one indirectly as their own.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_495_FmTrukL] Bollig claims that polyandry was rare: 'Polyandry seems to be rarer. I knew of only one case, in which two brothers had a common wife.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_496_FmTrukL] But Caughey claims that while polygamy was present, monogamy was the norm for most: 'In the traditional society polygynous marriages rarely occurred. Since marriage sets up heavy obligations to the wife’s lineage, most men did not want to increase this burden, especially by marrying into different lineages. Interpreted differently, the same reasons provided the rationale for those few cases of polygny that did occur. A man who married more than one wife demonstrated his importance and power. It showed that he was capable of engaging in burdensome social relationships with more than one lineage or that he was able to turn this subordinate relationship into one where he dominated. A famous man of bravery on Fáánakkar was once married at the same time to five wives from four different lineages. Later, in a grand gesture of kindness, he gave one of them away to a wifeless brother.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_497_FmTrukL] Expert confirmation is needed on the matter. Information on a possible decline of polygyny in favour of monogamy after Christianization may also be needed.
♠ Formal Elite Polygamy ♣ present ♥ The classification of variables here is slightly misleading. Polygamy was practiced among both chiefs and followers according to some writers, while others claim that polygyny was associated with greater wealth and power (see above).
♠ Informal Elite Polygamy ♣ absent ♥
♠ Elite Concubinage ♣ absent ♥
♠ Typical number of extramarital partners ♣ ♥ The classification of variables is slightly misleading here as some writers claim that extramarital sexual relations were somewhat common. Goodenough provides a general description of courtship and sexual relations: 'Marriage took place for women a bit before and for men a bit after the age of 20. Premarital courtship was covert and included sexual relations. Residence was usually matrilocal. Divorce, common before the birth of children, was rare thereafter. It could be initiated by either spouse and was often instigated by the wife's brothers. Levirate and sororate remarriages were valued. To keep soil and trees that had been granted to the children of a lineage's men circulating back, marriage preferences with one or another kind of cousin, varying from locality to locality, were widespread.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_498_FmTrukL] According to Goodenough, premarital sexual relations were common: 'LIKE many other Oceanic peoples, the natives of Truk allow their adolescents considerable freedom in sexual matters. There is no stigma of any kind attached to young men or women who have sexual relations before marriage. No value whatsoever is attributed to virginity in girls or boys. All informants agree that girls normally start having intercourse when, at about the age of fourteen, their breasts become fairly well developed. The initial sexual experiences of boys occur at a somewhat later age, between the ages of sixteen and seventeen.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_499_FmTrukL] Bollig claims that 'licentious' behavior was common and tolerated: 'Inemes, the Venus of the Truk people, has to be mentioned separately, because her cult is very different in character from that of the other spirits. She is the protectress of lechery, and everything that goes with it is dedicated to her. None of the gods and spirits has as extensive a circle of worshipers as Inemes. This fact alone is proof of the low moral position of the Truk people, who know no distinction between licit and illicit sexual intercourse and who, despite the oloudd have no conception of chastity and even less of virginity.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_500_FmTrukL] 'There is another detestable custom which likewise derives its origin from Inemes. It is the puanelö or nadelö (1). A number of young fellows get together and announce their licentiousness. They hang up the faren I[unknown]emes, decorate it with wreaths, necklaces, etc., paint themselves yellow from head to foot, and roam about to find companions in their lechery. Women and girls who do not want to co-operate are sprinkled with “magic oil” so that their hair falls out and ugly wounds and boils appear.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_501_FmTrukL] 'During this time also moonlight dances in honor of Inemes are performed. They are the notorious ouönu dances.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_502_FmTrukL] 'It is not surprising that so many marriages break up as a consequence of these ouönu dances. The licentiousness of the women is worst during this time. Since it is forbidden to pick coconuts, they lie in wait for the men so as to catch any in the act of violating the prohibition. If they have happily found one, they tear his clothes, scratch him, take away his food, etc. That is the detestable worship of Inemes, a dark point in the lives of the Truk natives, who otherwise are so congenial.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_503_FmTrukL] 'Jealousy among the women is in general not very great. It is worse among some men, who on account of it treat their wives like slaves. Wherever the wives go, they accompany them. They never make long trips, in order always to be able to be home at night. At the slightest suspicion, they beat their wives. Men of this type are not popular. Their jealousy is smiled at pityingly by the more liberal-minded. It is worthless, for the women are slier than the men in this respect. A word, a glance, a movement, a dropped stone, the flashing of a mirror reveals the intentions of the faithless one to her lover, without the neighborhood noticing anything. Even the harmless smoking is used in reaching an understanding. The woman rubs the tip of the cigarette with some aromatic oil and hands it to the man she desires to win. He immediately tastes the oil and knows what the woman wants of him. Thus, there are innumerable ways of reaching an understanding between those who have bad intentions. This refined system of adultery is not surprising, however, in the case of a people among whom Inemes, the goddess of lechery, swings her scepter.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_504_FmTrukL] Writing in the colonial period, Gladwin claims that children conceived through adultery were integrated into matrilineal kin groups without much consternation: 'Another aspect of kinship deserves mention. As we have seen this is a matrilineal society, which means that the social placement of a child in the lineage and wider social groupings depends in most respects upon his tie with his mother.
