The Trukese take this quite literally and therefore pay little or no attention to who may [Page 51] be the child’s actual biological father, even though this may be perfectly obvious. While the unmarried mother may find herself in a somewhat embarrassing social position, as far as can be determined no stigma whatsoever attaches to the child. Children of adulterous unions similarly are simply considered to be the children of the man to whom their mother was married at the time of their birth. Perhaps most important of the problems resolved by this device is that of children fathered by foreigners. At the present time there are literally hundreds of children whose appearance unmistakably shows them to have had Japanese fathers, and who in another society could readily form a class of half-breeds or mestizos with highly disruptive effects for themselves and the society as a whole. But on Truk they are simply Trukese children, treated no differently from any others, and properly furnished with mothers and fathers. Those who have seen the deep cleavage formed in societies elsewhere by mestizo groups can readily appreciate the degree of the good fortune of the Trukese in this regard. There are a few true half-castes on Truk, descendents of early traders who married Trukese women and raised their children themselves; these people consider themselves half-castes and are treated as such. But because this limited group can expand only slightly, not being augmented by further foreign transgressions, they can have little harmful effect and, in fact, have used the business knowledge passed down to them from their fathers or grandfathers to make major contributions to the economic adjustment of Truk under American administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_505_FmTrukL] It is difficult to quantify a 'typical number of extramarital partners' from these descriptions. It is also difficult to determine whether high-status men had more sexual partners than others.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Legal rights are different on the basis of:
♠ Gender ♣ present ♥ 'Chuukese followed a gendered division of labour: 'Traditionally, men gardened, cooked and processed food in bulk (in the earth oven), did deep-water fishing, engaged in war and public affairs, and practiced the arts of canoe and house building and of wood, shell, and stone working. Women wove, plaited mats, prepared meals (as distinct from food in bulk), did inshore fishing, and took main responsibility for child care. Men and women have both entered into school teaching, clerical work, and administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_506_FmTrukL] Women were excluded from some ceremonial activities due to gendered ritual taboos: 'A few dances are also connected with the worship of the spirits. These are the dugia (dance with kurukur, that is, staffs of orange wood) and the älimod, a dance which is performed in a sitting position. The former is a men’s dance; the latter may be performed by both sexes. During the entire dancing period the dancers are shut up in the udd. This is surrounded by a fence which no unbidden person, especially no woman, may approach. No indecent word occurs in these spirit dances, in contrast to the other dances. They say that the spirits do not like indecent things in connection with the men, a statement which does not correspond with their views on other occasions.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_507_FmTrukL] 'The pue is handled in different ways. The most important and solemn pue is the girot. The soupue makes the girot in the udd in the /66/ presence of his pupils. Women are not allowed to watch. As a matter of fact no woman is allowed to make any kind of pue.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_508_FmTrukL] 'After the apu[unknown]etou, the canoe, which is called faremai (= önumai) if it is a rowing canoe, is tested. It goes out on the sea for the kitir (rowing or sailing race). No woman is allowed to board the faremai, and no food may be put in it. The food must go with the other canoes. In the center of the new canoe sits the souatomai, who caresses the canoe and invokes the spirits. Having reached water favorable for navigation, the crew starts to row, and the vessels shoot across the broad surface with the speed of arrows. The invocations of the suatomai become more and more animated; the iéfot, iéfot of the rowers, wilder and wilder. Strange /74/ canoes passing by must be careful about coming too close to the faremai, for it is sacred.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_509_FmTrukL] Men in turn were excluded from some female-gendered activities, such as childbirth: 'It is not so simple for a child to be born on Truk. One can call it a near miracle if a child escapes all who struggle for its life before and after birth. The woman in childbirth is separated from the other occupants of the house. She often occupies a little house built especially for the birth. One or another older woman from among the relatives, called soufam or souetikar (midwives), is to be found with her. Entrance is forbidden to all men.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_510_FmTrukL] According to Caughey, lineage leaders were usually male and brothers had authority over sisters: 'A lineage is conceived of as a group of siblings ( pwiipwi). In a group of real siblings, males have authority over females and the “eldest brother” ( mwaaniichi) is the leader. Within the lineage, the oldest male of the oldest generation is usually the “lineage leader” ( mmwen noon eterekes, [Page 65] “first inside of the lineage”).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_511_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, brothers were owed respect by sisters: 'As long as the children are small, they run around completely naked. When they become bigger and approach maturity, the boys receive their akadöwar (modesty band), the girls their atok (hip mat). From the day when the boy has his band he is considered a youth. The sister, when meeting him, must aporo, that is, bow. An old custom to indicate the age of a boy is connected with this modesty band. To the question, “How old is the boy?” comes the answer, for example, “ etö efärin” (= akadöwar), that is, a modesty band, which means that he has grown beyond the age of a boy. The natives do not have any precise estimate of their age. None of them is able [Page 99] to say how old he is with any exactness. To designate the stages of age, they have mönukol (1) 1 Literally: the conceived. , sediben (2) 2 “It has no will.” semirid (3) 3 “It cannot think.” = child, that is, very small children. For somewhat bigger ones, the expressions äd, säri (boy), le[unknown]in (girl) are used; at maturity, whether married or not, öluöl (youth), fabul (young woman). Adult persons are called muan (man), fefin (woman).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_512_FmTrukL] However, women could hold property even without the husband's consent (Chuukese lineages were matrilineal): 'The position of the Truk woman in legal respects is not degrading. They are not weakly in the hands of the husband. I have seen men who were terribly henpecked. The women have their property, are able to acquire, buy, and sell without the husband’s consent. The children also belong exclusively to them. They have little work and for the most part are treated well, even if only to prevent them from running away. It is considered wrong to beat women.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_513_FmTrukL] We are unsure whether the above examples constitute differences in 'legal rights', but have assumed so for the time being.
♠ Social class ♣ present ♥ As a clan-based society, the Chuukese were stratified according to lineage rather than social class: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_514_FmTrukL] 'The domestic unit was an extended family, based on the women of a lineage or sublineage. It consisted of at least one experienced older woman and two more younger women of childbearing age together with their husbands. Unmarried sons and brothers slept apart in their lineage's meeting house. Extended family households continued through the periods of foreign administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_515_FmTrukL] Chiefly status was tied to lineages in full ownership of territorial districts: 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_516_FmTrukL] Male chiefs were attached to the senior lineages of matrilineal descent groups: 'A district chiefship was divided between the oldest man in the senior female line in the chiefly lineage and the oldest man in the lineage generally. The latter was executive chief, or "chief of talk," and the former symbolic chief, or "chief of food." Food presentations were made to the symbolic chief. Sometimes the symbolic and executive functions fell to the same individual; often they did not. The symbolic chief was surrounded by his lineage brothers and by his sons, who acted as his agents. These followers and his sisters and daughters were of chiefly rank, distinct from commoners. Through conquest, a lineage might gain the chiefship in more than one district and establish a junior branch as the chiefly lineage in the conquered district. The now subordinate district rendered food presentations to the superordinate one. Most districts were linked in two rival leagues based on competing schools of magic and ritual relating to war, politics, and rhetoric. A chief's authority derived from two things. His lineage's ownership of the district's space entitled him to presentations of first fruits at stated times of the year. More importantly, it gave him authority over the conservation and use of the district's food resources. His authority also derived from his connection with the sky world, its gods, and their superhuman power to accomplish purposes. There was, therefore, a degree of sacredness associated with chiefs.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_517_FmTrukL] Bollig claims that members of chiefly lineages received preferential treatment in judicial matters due to nepotism: 'Another weak point of the chiefs is partiality. Members of the chief’s kin group, blood relatives, and friends are not readily punished, not even for serious crimes. On the other hand, poor devils whom the chief cannot bear are sentenced to hard labor for the slightest reason or are reported to the government as “disobedient ones” or “rebels.” In the old days the Truk chiefs did away with troublesome persons by means of the knife; today they do it by means of lies and false denunciations.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_518_FmTrukL] Socioeconomic stratification along class lines emerged in the colonial period: 'Substantial differences in monetary and material wealth exist among Peniyesene’s population, as evidenced in everything from housing to transportation to clothing and diet. Some residents are, by Micronesian standards, rich; others are abysmally poor. Considerable evidence exists that these differences in wealth are giving rise to emergent social classes. Some residents of Peniyesene own two cars and live in new cement homes with linoleum floors, glass louvred windows, kerosene refrigerators or freezers, western-style furniture, and electricity (from small diesel generators), which is used to run electric lights, fans, and, in at least one case, a washing machine. These same wealthy families operate one or two motorboats equipped with 25 horsepower Johnson or Evinrude outboard engines, dress in stylish clothing, purchase fancy toys for their children, and [Page 29] [Page 30] diaper their babies with disposable diapers. Family meals regularly include frozen Australian beef, chicken from the United States, and such delicacies as cinnamon rolls flown in fresh on Air Mike from Tommy’s Bakery on Guam.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_519_FmTrukL] 'At the other end of the village economic scale, several large families have no member employed for wages and continue to subsist on a traditional Trukese diet of breadfruit, taro, and fresh fish, supplemented by small amounts of imported food, such as rice and flour. Their minimal monetary resources derive from the sale of copra to the TTC or from occasional part-time labor for wealthier members of the community. They own neither car nor motorboat and are lucky to own a canoe. Their homes are either single-room plywood boxes or small structures made piecemeal from corrugated tin, old packing crates, and random pieces of lumber. Their clothing is old and tattered and their children have no fine toys with which to amuse themselves.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_520_FmTrukL] 'These large differences in wealth and life-style are galling to many Trukese who hold egalitarianism as a fundamental ethic; the drunken behavior of many young men in the community is not unrelated to perceived class differences. Several of the wealthier individuals in Peniyesene keep.22 caliber rifles to deal with persons who might try to break into their homes at night.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_521_FmTrukL] Ethnic and class hierarchies intersected to an extent, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent often belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_522_FmTrukL] Access to schooling was distributed unequally in the post-colonial period: 'Many elite couples on Moen in 1985 enrolled their children in one of the church-run private schools because they could afford the tuition and [Page 23] because the students were believed to get a better education there, particularly in mastery of the English language. Education, employment, financial capital, and travel experiences all have equipped elites for leadership positions in the modern political system, bringing their power and prestige full circle. Those Trukese aspiring to elite status harbor dreams and ambitions not unlike those of upwardly mobile young Americans. They want a piece of land on Moen on which to build a nice house and enough money to afford a car. The port town’s rapid growth from immigration has fueled land speculation, and today a small plot on which to build a home may sell for several thousand dollars.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_523_FmTrukL] However, Marshall writes that kinship remained important: 'We have some misgivings about using class labels derived from the American system to describe Trukese society, and we are convinced that a class analysis by itself cannot explain the reality of modern Trukese social organization. For Truk remains a society organized primarily and fundamentally along kinship lines, and the lineages and clans still serve as the [Page 22] basis for the social structure, whether in the realm of politics or of economics. What we label “incipient social classes” overlay and crosscut the undergirding kinship structure in significant ways, and failing to discuss these emergent differences would produce an inaccurate picture of life in the islands today. A recognition of nascent social classes in Truk is also essential to an understanding of women’s involvement in the prohibition movement over the past decade. In Truk, as in the United States a century ago, middle-class women provided the leadership and the energy to launch and sustain prohibition (see Chapter Seven).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_524_FmTrukL] We are unsure whether the above examples constitute different 'legal rights' stratified according to 'social class', but have assumed so for the time being, given the differential treatment of elites and commoners in judicial matters handled by chiefs. This remains in need of further confirmation.
♠ Ethnicity or race ♣ absent ♥ Writing in the colonial period, Gladwin claims that 'mixed-race' individuals were readily integrated into matrilineal kin groups: 'Another aspect of kinship deserves mention. As we have seen this is a matrilineal society, which means that the social placement of a child in the lineage and wider social groupings depends in most respects upon his tie with his mother. The Trukese take this quite literally and therefore pay little or no attention to who may [Page 51] be the child’s actual biological father, even though this may be perfectly obvious. While the unmarried mother may find herself in a somewhat embarrassing social position, as far as can be determined no stigma whatsoever attaches to the child. Children of adulterous unions similarly are simply considered to be the children of the man to whom their mother was married at the time of their birth. Perhaps most important of the problems resolved by this device is that of children fathered by foreigners. At the present time there are literally hundreds of children whose appearance unmistakably shows them to have had Japanese fathers, and who in another society could readily form a class of half-breeds or mestizos with highly disruptive effects for themselves and the society as a whole. But on Truk they are simply Trukese children, treated no differently from any others, and properly furnished with mothers and fathers. Those who have seen the deep cleavage formed in societies elsewhere by mestizo groups can readily appreciate the degree of the good fortune of the Trukese in this regard. There are a few true half-castes on Truk, descendents of early traders who married Trukese women and raised their children themselves; these people consider themselves half-castes and are treated as such. But because this limited group can expand only slightly, not being augmented by further foreign transgressions, they can have little harmful effect and, in fact, have used the business knowledge passed down to them from their fathers or grandfathers to make major contributions to the economic adjustment of Truk under American administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_525_FmTrukL] We have found no evidence of discrimination against mixed-race individuals within Chuuk communities. Ethnic and class hierarchies intersected to an extent, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent often belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_526_FmTrukL] Accordingly, Chuukese communities became incorporated into a colonial ethnic hierarchy, even though their own society was not ethnically stratified. These issues are in need of a resolution in our coding approach.

Discrimination[edit]

Discrimination on the basis of gender (include de facto discrimination even when there are no explicit legal restrictions)
♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to both males and females ♣ present ♥ The following general introduction by Goodenough seems to indicate that bureaucratic and administrative positions were open to both men and women: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_527_FmTrukL] 'Traditionally, men gardened, cooked and processed food in bulk (in the earth oven), did deep-water fishing, engaged in war and public affairs, and practiced the arts of canoe and house building and of wood, shell, and stone working. Women wove, plaited mats, prepared meals (as distinct from food in bulk), did inshore fishing, and took main responsibility for child care. Men and women have both entered into school teaching, clerical work, and administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_528_FmTrukL] However, it remains to be confirmed when Chuukese first entered these positions.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to both males and females ♣ present ♥ The following general introduction by Goodenough seems to indicate that bureaucratic and administrative positions were open to both men and women: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_529_FmTrukL] 'Traditionally, men gardened, cooked and processed food in bulk (in the earth oven), did deep-water fishing, engaged in war and public affairs, and practiced the arts of canoe and house building and of wood, shell, and stone working. Women wove, plaited mats, prepared meals (as distinct from food in bulk), did inshore fishing, and took main responsibility for child care. Men and women have both entered into school teaching, clerical work, and administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_530_FmTrukL] However, it remains to be confirmed when Chuukese first entered these positions.
♠ Education is available to both males and females ♣ present ♥ The following general introduction by Goodenough seems to indicate that schools were open to both girls and boys: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_531_FmTrukL] 'Traditionally, men gardened, cooked and processed food in bulk (in the earth oven), did deep-water fishing, engaged in war and public affairs, and practiced the arts of canoe and house building and of wood, shell, and stone working. Women wove, plaited mats, prepared meals (as distinct from food in bulk), did inshore fishing, and took main responsibility for child care. Men and women have both entered into school teaching, clerical work, and administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_532_FmTrukL]
♠ Property can be owned by both males and females ♣ present ♥ Land was held by both individuals and matrilineal descent groups: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_533_FmTrukL] 'Individually-owned property was inherited by the owner's children. Corporately-owned property was inherited by the corporation's 'children' (the children of its men) when the corporation's membership died out.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_534_FmTrukL] Women commonly held property, but husbands and children retained usufruct rights over the property of mothers and wives: 'The position of the Truk woman in legal respects is not degrading. They are not weakly in the hands of the husband. I have seen men who were terribly henpecked. The women have their property, are able to acquire, buy, and sell without the husband’s consent. The children also belong exclusively to them. They have little work and for the most part are treated well, even if only to prevent them from running away. It is considered wrong to beat women.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_535_FmTrukL] 'The right to private property exists among the Truk natives. Everyone of them, be it man or woman, adult or child, can own property, for example, land, houses, cattle, money, etc. Whatever the wife brings into the marriage remains wholly at her disposal.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_536_FmTrukL] 'The husband and children, however, do have usufruct rights to her property. If she goes back to her family because of death or divorce, then she takes her property with her again. In practice a certain communism prevails, since siblings, members of the same kin group, often live together and cultivate their lands and enjoy the fruits together. This, however, lasts only as long as there are no quarrels among the families.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_537_FmTrukL] However, elder brothers usually held supervision rights over property owned by the sib: 'In contrast to this indirectly communistic property, there is also that which is directly communistic, for example, land. They call it fanu uon ar puipui, land of their brotherhood. Yet the oldest brother plays a special part in connection with all the property. He not only has the supervision and usufruct right to the property of the younger siblings, which goes back to the common [Page 132] father, but he can also withdraw it from them. Since this not infrequently happens, the oldest is usually also the richest in each family. /121/ The oldest has no rights over the property which the younger ones have obtained from other sources. To make up for the fact that the oldest has such extensive rights, he has the obligation to care for his siblings in certain ways.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_538_FmTrukL] The differentiation between individual and communal property and the practice of matriliny affected the transmission of property by men and women: 'If a man dies, the lands which belonged to him personally pass on to his children. Such land is called fanuei me uon semei, my land from my father. The particulars of the distribution are left completely to his discretion. He can also exclude one child or another, as he likes. The lands that he has jointly with his brothers, however, are taken by them. It frequently happens that the brothers, in case the children are minors, take all the lands in order to administer them, whereby one piece or another remains in their hands forever. In general the father considers only the children from the present marriage. Children from former marriages, who live with the mother’s relatives, are not considered. For that they would have had to rejoin him again later. The mother’s property too only in part passes to the children, since her brothers and sisters likewise do not want to come out short.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_539_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Discrimination on the basis of social class (include de facto limitations even when there are no explicit legal restrictions)
♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to people from all social classes ♣ present ♥ Socioeconomic differentiation along class lines emerged in the colonial and post-colonial periods: 'Substantial differences in monetary and material wealth exist among Peniyesene’s population, as evidenced in everything from housing to transportation to clothing and diet. Some residents are, by Micronesian standards, rich; others are abysmally poor. Considerable evidence exists that these differences in wealth are giving rise to emergent social classes. Some residents of Peniyesene own two cars and live in new cement homes with linoleum floors, glass louvred windows, kerosene refrigerators or freezers, western-style furniture, and electricity (from small diesel generators), which is used to run electric lights, fans, and, in at least one case, a washing machine. These same wealthy families operate one or two motorboats equipped with 25 horsepower Johnson or Evinrude outboard engines, dress in stylish clothing, purchase fancy toys for their children, and [Page 29] [Page 30] diaper their babies with disposable diapers. Family meals regularly include frozen Australian beef, chicken from the United States, and such delicacies as cinnamon rolls flown in fresh on Air Mike from Tommy’s Bakery on Guam.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_540_FmTrukL] 'At the other end of the village economic scale, several large families have no member employed for wages and continue to subsist on a traditional Trukese diet of breadfruit, taro, and fresh fish, supplemented by small amounts of imported food, such as rice and flour. Their minimal monetary resources derive from the sale of copra to the TTC or from occasional part-time labor for wealthier members of the community. They own neither car nor motorboat and are lucky to own a canoe. Their homes are either single-room plywood boxes or small structures made piecemeal from corrugated tin, old packing crates, and random pieces of lumber. Their clothing is old and tattered and their children have no fine toys with which to amuse themselves.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_541_FmTrukL] 'These large differences in wealth and life-style are galling to many Trukese who hold egalitarianism as a fundamental ethic; the drunken behavior of many young men in the community is not unrelated to perceived class differences. Several of the wealthier individuals in Peniyesene keep.22 caliber rifles to deal with persons who might try to break into their homes at night.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_542_FmTrukL] Ethnic and economic hierarchies overlapped somewhat, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent generally belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_543_FmTrukL] Kinship nevertheless remained important: 'We have some misgivings about using class labels derived from the American system to describe Trukese society, and we are convinced that a class analysis by itself cannot explain the reality of modern Trukese social organization. For Truk remains a society organized primarily and fundamentally along kinship lines, and the lineages and clans still serve as the [Page 22] basis for the social structure, whether in the realm of politics or of economics. What we label “incipient social classes” overlay and crosscut the undergirding kinship structure in significant ways, and failing to discuss these emergent differences would produce an inaccurate picture of life in the islands today. A recognition of nascent social classes in Truk is also essential to an understanding of women’s involvement in the prohibition movement over the past decade. In Truk, as in the United States a century ago, middle-class women provided the leadership and the energy to launch and sustain prohibition (see Chapter Seven).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_544_FmTrukL] In post-colonial times, elite families had access to higher-quality private education: 'Many elite couples on Moen in 1985 enrolled their children in one of the church-run private schools because they could afford the tuition and [Page 23] because the students were believed to get a better education there, particularly in mastery of the English language. Education, employment, financial capital, and travel experiences all have equipped elites for leadership positions in the modern political system, bringing their power and prestige full circle. Those Trukese aspiring to elite status harbor dreams and ambitions not unlike those of upwardly mobile young Americans. They want a piece of land on Moen on which to build a nice house and enough money to afford a car. The port town’s rapid growth from immigration has fueled land speculation, and today a small plot on which to build a home may sell for several thousand dollars.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_545_FmTrukL] However, it appears that bureaucratic and administratve positions were open to islanders regardless of wealth in principle: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_546_FmTrukL] 'Traditionally, men gardened, cooked and processed food in bulk (in the earth oven), did deep-water fishing, engaged in war and public affairs, and practiced the arts of canoe and house building and of wood, shell, and stone working. Women wove, plaited mats, prepared meals (as distinct from food in bulk), did inshore fishing, and took main responsibility for child care. Men and women have both entered into school teaching, clerical work, and administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_547_FmTrukL] The extent to which positions in the administration were made available to the populations remains in need of further confirmation.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to people from all social classes ♣ present ♥ Socioeconomic differentiation along class lines emerged in the colonial and post-colonial periods: 'Substantial differences in monetary and material wealth exist among Peniyesene’s population, as evidenced in everything from housing to transportation to clothing and diet. Some residents are, by Micronesian standards, rich; others are abysmally poor. Considerable evidence exists that these differences in wealth are giving rise to emergent social classes. Some residents of Peniyesene own two cars and live in new cement homes with linoleum floors, glass louvred windows, kerosene refrigerators or freezers, western-style furniture, and electricity (from small diesel generators), which is used to run electric lights, fans, and, in at least one case, a washing machine. These same wealthy families operate one or two motorboats equipped with 25 horsepower Johnson or Evinrude outboard engines, dress in stylish clothing, purchase fancy toys for their children, and [Page 29] [Page 30] diaper their babies with disposable diapers. Family meals regularly include frozen Australian beef, chicken from the United States, and such delicacies as cinnamon rolls flown in fresh on Air Mike from Tommy’s Bakery on Guam.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_548_FmTrukL] 'At the other end of the village economic scale, several large families have no member employed for wages and continue to subsist on a traditional Trukese diet of breadfruit, taro, and fresh fish, supplemented by small amounts of imported food, such as rice and flour. Their minimal monetary resources derive from the sale of copra to the TTC or from occasional part-time labor for wealthier members of the community. They own neither car nor motorboat and are lucky to own a canoe. Their homes are either single-room plywood boxes or small structures made piecemeal from corrugated tin, old packing crates, and random pieces of lumber. Their clothing is old and tattered and their children have no fine toys with which to amuse themselves.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_549_FmTrukL] 'These large differences in wealth and life-style are galling to many Trukese who hold egalitarianism as a fundamental ethic; the drunken behavior of many young men in the community is not unrelated to perceived class differences. Several of the wealthier individuals in Peniyesene keep.22 caliber rifles to deal with persons who might try to break into their homes at night.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_550_FmTrukL] Ethnic and economic hierarchies overlapped somewhat, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent generally belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_551_FmTrukL] Kinship nevertheless remained important: 'We have some misgivings about using class labels derived from the American system to describe Trukese society, and we are convinced that a class analysis by itself cannot explain the reality of modern Trukese social organization. For Truk remains a society organized primarily and fundamentally along kinship lines, and the lineages and clans still serve as the [Page 22] basis for the social structure, whether in the realm of politics or of economics. What we label “incipient social classes” overlay and crosscut the undergirding kinship structure in significant ways, and failing to discuss these emergent differences would produce an inaccurate picture of life in the islands today. A recognition of nascent social classes in Truk is also essential to an understanding of women’s involvement in the prohibition movement over the past decade. In Truk, as in the United States a century ago, middle-class women provided the leadership and the energy to launch and sustain prohibition (see Chapter Seven).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_552_FmTrukL] In post-colonial times, elite families had access to higher-quality private education: 'Many elite couples on Moen in 1985 enrolled their children in one of the church-run private schools because they could afford the tuition and [Page 23] because the students were believed to get a better education there, particularly in mastery of the English language. Education, employment, financial capital, and travel experiences all have equipped elites for leadership positions in the modern political system, bringing their power and prestige full circle. Those Trukese aspiring to elite status harbor dreams and ambitions not unlike those of upwardly mobile young Americans. They want a piece of land on Moen on which to build a nice house and enough money to afford a car. The port town’s rapid growth from immigration has fueled land speculation, and today a small plot on which to build a home may sell for several thousand dollars.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_553_FmTrukL] However, it appears that bureaucratic and administratve positions were open to islanders regardless of wealth in principle: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_554_FmTrukL] 'Traditionally, men gardened, cooked and processed food in bulk (in the earth oven), did deep-water fishing, engaged in war and public affairs, and practiced the arts of canoe and house building and of wood, shell, and stone working. Women wove, plaited mats, prepared meals (as distinct from food in bulk), did inshore fishing, and took main responsibility for child care. Men and women have both entered into school teaching, clerical work, and administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_555_FmTrukL] The extent to which positions in the administration were made available to the populations remains in need of further confirmation.
♠ Education is available to people from all social classes ♣ present ♥ Socioeconomic differentiation along class lines emerged in the colonial and post-colonial periods: 'Substantial differences in monetary and material wealth exist among Peniyesene’s population, as evidenced in everything from housing to transportation to clothing and diet. Some residents are, by Micronesian standards, rich; others are abysmally poor. Considerable evidence exists that these differences in wealth are giving rise to emergent social classes. Some residents of Peniyesene own two cars and live in new cement homes with linoleum floors, glass louvred windows, kerosene refrigerators or freezers, western-style furniture, and electricity (from small diesel generators), which is used to run electric lights, fans, and, in at least one case, a washing machine. These same wealthy families operate one or two motorboats equipped with 25 horsepower Johnson or Evinrude outboard engines, dress in stylish clothing, purchase fancy toys for their children, and [Page 29] [Page 30] diaper their babies with disposable diapers. Family meals regularly include frozen Australian beef, chicken from the United States, and such delicacies as cinnamon rolls flown in fresh on Air Mike from Tommy’s Bakery on Guam.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_556_FmTrukL] 'At the other end of the village economic scale, several large families have no member employed for wages and continue to subsist on a traditional Trukese diet of breadfruit, taro, and fresh fish, supplemented by small amounts of imported food, such as rice and flour. Their minimal monetary resources derive from the sale of copra to the TTC or from occasional part-time labor for wealthier members of the community. They own neither car nor motorboat and are lucky to own a canoe. Their homes are either single-room plywood boxes or small structures made piecemeal from corrugated tin, old packing crates, and random pieces of lumber. Their clothing is old and tattered and their children have no fine toys with which to amuse themselves.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_557_FmTrukL] 'These large differences in wealth and life-style are galling to many Trukese who hold egalitarianism as a fundamental ethic; the drunken behavior of many young men in the community is not unrelated to perceived class differences. Several of the wealthier individuals in Peniyesene keep.22 caliber rifles to deal with persons who might try to break into their homes at night.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_558_FmTrukL] Ethnic and economic hierarchies overlapped somewhat, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent generally belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_559_FmTrukL] Kinship nevertheless remained important: 'We have some misgivings about using class labels derived from the American system to describe Trukese society, and we are convinced that a class analysis by itself cannot explain the reality of modern Trukese social organization. For Truk remains a society organized primarily and fundamentally along kinship lines, and the lineages and clans still serve as the [Page 22] basis for the social structure, whether in the realm of politics or of economics. What we label “incipient social classes” overlay and crosscut the undergirding kinship structure in significant ways, and failing to discuss these emergent differences would produce an inaccurate picture of life in the islands today. A recognition of nascent social classes in Truk is also essential to an understanding of women’s involvement in the prohibition movement over the past decade. In Truk, as in the United States a century ago, middle-class women provided the leadership and the energy to launch and sustain prohibition (see Chapter Seven).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_560_FmTrukL] In post-colonial times, elite families had access to higher-quality private education: 'Many elite couples on Moen in 1985 enrolled their children in one of the church-run private schools because they could afford the tuition and [Page 23] because the students were believed to get a better education there, particularly in mastery of the English language. Education, employment, financial capital, and travel experiences all have equipped elites for leadership positions in the modern political system, bringing their power and prestige full circle. Those Trukese aspiring to elite status harbor dreams and ambitions not unlike those of upwardly mobile young Americans. They want a piece of land on Moen on which to build a nice house and enough money to afford a car. The port town’s rapid growth from immigration has fueled land speculation, and today a small plot on which to build a home may sell for several thousand dollars.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_561_FmTrukL] However, it appears that education was generally available to Chuukese regardless of background: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_562_FmTrukL] The extent to which education was made available to the population remains in need of further confirmation.
♠ Property can be owned by people from all social classes ♣ present ♥ Land was held by both individuals and matrilineal descent groups: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_563_FmTrukL] 'Individually-owned property was inherited by the owner's children. Corporately-owned property was inherited by the corporation's 'children' (the children of its men) when the corporation's membership died out.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_564_FmTrukL] Chiefly lineages owned lands associated with their territorial districts, but could grant usufruct and residential rights to junior lineages on a provisional basis: 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_565_FmTrukL] Sharing and cooperation within the matrilineal sib was common: 'The husband and children, however, do have usufruct rights to her property. If she goes back to her family because of death or divorce, then she takes her property with her again. In practice a certain communism prevails, since siblings, members of the same kin group, often live together and cultivate their lands and enjoy the fruits together. This, however, lasts only as long as there are no quarrels among the families.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_566_FmTrukL] Elder brothers held supervision rights over property owned by the sib: 'In contrast to this indirectly communistic property, there is also that which is directly communistic, for example, land. They call it fanu uon ar puipui, land of their brotherhood. Yet the oldest brother plays a special part in connection with all the property. He not only has the supervision and usufruct right to the property of the younger siblings, which goes back to the common [Page 132] father, but he can also withdraw it from them. Since this not infrequently happens, the oldest is usually also the richest in each family. /121/ The oldest has no rights over the property which the younger ones have obtained from other sources. To make up for the fact that the oldest has such extensive rights, he has the obligation to care for his siblings in certain ways.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_567_FmTrukL] Rights in land itself were differentiated from rights in plantings: 'The Truk people are familiar with a distinction of the ground from what is planted on it. Thus, somebody may possess a piece of land, but the trees that stand on it belong to other people. They or their parents once planted the trees on his property, which is permissible according to Truk customs. If the owners of the trees are dishonest, they need only clear the field beginning from the trees, continue to cultivate, and the poor owner is dispossessed. What confused situations that causes in the case of an eventual transfer of the piece of land to another is easily understandable. I myself have had difficulties for years, since certain people still held on to “their” trees after the piece of land had long been the property of the mission. Only the felling of the trees put an end to all claims.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_568_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, land disputes were common: 'The land rights of the Truk people are not based on justice, but on the right of the stronger, the cleverer. There is hardly a plot of land with a clear legal history, and for that reason there are the constant assertions of legal claims, the eternal lawsuits over land. The boldest and most cunning persons always have the best land on Truk. Pretenses for bringing legal claims to foreign property before the chief are easily found in the confused conditions. And once they are found, the Kanakas’ inexhaustible power of invention and art of lying take care of making them convincing to others. That briberies of chiefs, interpreters, and witnesses play a tremendous part in this is obvious, considering the character of the Truk people. No means is too wicked for them in order to “profit. ”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_569_FmTrukL] Bollig attributes this issue to land exchanges and vague boundaries: 'A source of land disputes is the exchange of lands. For example: Soni and Soledon exchange two pieces of land. Soni now cultivates his land, while Soledon lets it lie fallow. Soledon dies. His children, who are not on good terms with Soni, cancel the exchange and take possession of the productive piece of land as property of their deceased father. Soni resists. The parties quarrel for years. Sometimes the one wins, sometimes the other, but no one yields.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_570_FmTrukL] 'The boundaries of the lands are very vague. They change continually under the hands of both neighbors. Sometimes the one, sometimes the other one, goes beyond them. Then they quarrel. What A has planted B tears out, with the argument that it is already on his territory. What B has planted A tears out, with the same argument. Now which of the two is right?' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_571_FmTrukL] 'With such uncertain legal conditions it is not at all surprising that quarrels over land are daily events on Truk. Every death, every divorce, every new marriage has a coil of rats’ tails in quarrels as a result. The boundless egotism of the Truk natives is responsible for all this. Everybody wants to have as much as possible. A Trukese can quarrel for years about a tree, a plant, or a foot of land, even though he has plenty of trees that are not producing anything because of lack of care. The German government gave the natives land documents on which the owner, along with all his pieces of land, was recorded. /123/ The hopes placed on this have not been fulfilled. Today everything is as confused as before.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_572_FmTrukL] It is unclear whether these disputes were endemic even before colonization or a consequence thereof. Bollig also describes strategies for claiming and asserting rights over land and plantings: 'The natives try to document their right of ownership to pieces of land by clearing something on it from time to time, or they build huts on the individual pieces of land, which they then inhabit temporarily. Dying fathers give their children directions to bury them on their pieces of land so that their grave might thus be proof of ownership for the future. One can often hear in the kobu[unknown] that this is precisely what the people refer to.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_573_FmTrukL] 'The riri, that is, to bind, forms a strange title deed on the Truk Islands. For example, somebody sees a tree which bears many fruits. Since he would like some too, he takes the ubud of a coconut palm and wraps it around a branch of the tree in order to make his intention known publicly. In many cases the owner resists such oppression and tears off the ubud. But also in many cases he keeps quiet in order to avoid bigger quarrels.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_574_FmTrukL] 'I myself have had experiences with the riri in that the girls “bound” pineapples for themselves on my plot of land, which I did not allow, of course. The riri is also done in connection with animals, only by words here, of course. They say, for example: “ A riri lon lelugei enan tugo, it is bound in my heart, this chicken, ” that is, it is my property. Then they also further take the wor d riri with a moral obligation. One says, for example: [Page 135] “U a riri uon enan a[unknown]a[unknown], I am bound to that work, ” that is, I am obliged to do it. In any case the former riri is the root of the latter.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_575_FmTrukL] A wide variety of goods could be transferred through barter: 'The acquisition of property on Truk is usually done by means of barter. Lands, houses, and canoes are bartered. Smaller units of exchange are sebi (wooden bowls), deig (curcuma), faupar (red shell disks), hip mats, modesty bands, fishing nets, aromatic oils, coconut cord, home-grown tobacco, and sleeping mats. These products of native industry are not present in like quantity or in like quality on all the islands. Thus, Sapesis on Fefan is famous for its fine bowls, Pol for curcuma and oils, Iluk for its fine hip mats.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_576_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, flexible and vague property arrangements among the Chuukese impacted the management of colonial-era plantings: 'A few decades ago the sandy shore was wilderness. Only gradually, under the influence of Europeans, were coconuts planted,for only this kind of cultivation is possible in the sand. Regular, clean grounds, however, are not to the taste of the Truk people. Coconut trees, breadfruit trees, and forest trees stand higgledy-piggledy, usually so densely that some of them never bear. The confused legal conditions of the natives are shown most glaringly on the shore. Thirty trees, which stand side by side, belong to several owners, for example: coconut tree No. 1 [Page 157] belongs to A, Nos. 2 and 3 to B, No. 4 to A again, etc. One can imagine how many quarrels about the falling fruit result from that.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_577_FmTrukL] Socioeconomic stratification along the lines of social class emerged in the colonial and post-colonial periods: 'Substantial differences in monetary and material wealth exist among Peniyesene’s population, as evidenced in everything from housing to transportation to clothing and diet. Some residents are, by Micronesian standards, rich; others are abysmally poor. Considerable evidence exists that these differences in wealth are giving rise to emergent social classes. Some residents of Peniyesene own two cars and live in new cement homes with linoleum floors, glass louvred windows, kerosene refrigerators or freezers, western-style furniture, and electricity (from small diesel generators), which is used to run electric lights, fans, and, in at least one case, a washing machine. These same wealthy families operate one or two motorboats equipped with 25 horsepower Johnson or Evinrude outboard engines, dress in stylish clothing, purchase fancy toys for their children, and [Page 29] [Page 30] diaper their babies with disposable diapers. Family meals regularly include frozen Australian beef, chicken from the United States, and such delicacies as cinnamon rolls flown in fresh on Air Mike from Tommy’s Bakery on Guam.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_578_FmTrukL] 'At the other end of the village economic scale, several large families have no member employed for wages and continue to subsist on a traditional Trukese diet of breadfruit, taro, and fresh fish, supplemented by small amounts of imported food, such as rice and flour. Their minimal monetary resources derive from the sale of copra to the TTC or from occasional part-time labor for wealthier members of the community. They own neither car nor motorboat and are lucky to own a canoe. Their homes are either single-room plywood boxes or small structures made piecemeal from corrugated tin, old packing crates, and random pieces of lumber. Their clothing is old and tattered and their children have no fine toys with which to amuse themselves.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_579_FmTrukL] 'These large differences in wealth and life-style are galling to many Trukese who hold egalitarianism as a fundamental ethic; the drunken behavior of many young men in the community is not unrelated to perceived class differences. Several of the wealthier individuals in Peniyesene keep.22 caliber rifles to deal with persons who might try to break into their homes at night.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_580_FmTrukL] Ethnic and economic hierarchies overlapped to an extent, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent generally being among the emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_581_FmTrukL] 'Many elite couples on Moen in 1985 enrolled their children in one of the church-run private schools because they could afford the tuition and [Page 23] because the students were believed to get a better education there, particularly in mastery of the English language. Education, employment, financial capital, and travel experiences all have equipped elites for leadership positions in the modern political system, bringing their power and prestige full circle. Those Trukese aspiring to elite status harbor dreams and ambitions not unlike those of upwardly mobile young Americans. They want a piece of land on Moen on which to build a nice house and enough money to afford a car. The port town’s rapid growth from immigration has fueled land speculation, and today a small plot on which to build a home may sell for several thousand dollars.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_582_FmTrukL] According to Marshall, kinship nevertheless remained important: 'We have some misgivings about using class labels derived from the American system to describe Trukese society, and we are convinced that a class analysis by itself cannot explain the reality of modern Trukese social organization. For Truk remains a society organized primarily and fundamentally along kinship lines, and the lineages and clans still serve as the [Page 22] basis for the social structure, whether in the realm of politics or of economics. What we label “incipient social classes” overlay and crosscut the undergirding kinship structure in significant ways, and failing to discuss these emergent differences would produce an inaccurate picture of life in the islands today. A recognition of nascent social classes in Truk is also essential to an understanding of women’s involvement in the prohibition movement over the past decade. In Truk, as in the United States a century ago, middle-class women provided the leadership and the energy to launch and sustain prohibition (see Chapter Seven).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_583_FmTrukL] The above examples demonstrate that while property was unevenly distributed, members of all social classes could own property in principle.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Discrimination on the basis of ethnicity/race
♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ present ♥ According to Gladwin, children of mixed-race descent were readily integrated into matrilineal kin groups: 'Another aspect of kinship deserves mention. As we have seen this is a matrilineal society, which means that the social placement of a child in the lineage and wider social groupings depends in most respects upon his tie with his mother. The Trukese take this quite literally and therefore pay little or no attention to who may [Page 51] be the child’s actual biological father, even though this may be perfectly obvious. While the unmarried mother may find herself in a somewhat embarrassing social position, as far as can be determined no stigma whatsoever attaches to the child. Children of adulterous unions similarly are simply considered to be the children of the man to whom their mother was married at the time of their birth. Perhaps most important of the problems resolved by this device is that of children fathered by foreigners. At the present time there are literally hundreds of children whose appearance unmistakably shows them to have had Japanese fathers, and who in another society could readily form a class of half-breeds or mestizos with highly disruptive effects for themselves and the society as a whole. But on Truk they are simply Trukese children, treated no differently from any others, and properly furnished with mothers and fathers. Those who have seen the deep cleavage formed in societies elsewhere by mestizo groups can readily appreciate the degree of the good fortune of the Trukese in this regard. There are a few true half-castes on Truk, descendents of early traders who married Trukese women and raised their children themselves; these people consider themselves half-castes and are treated as such. But because this limited group can expand only slightly, not being augmented by further foreign transgressions, they can have little harmful effect and, in fact, have used the business knowledge passed down to them from their fathers or grandfathers to make major contributions to the economic adjustment of Truk under American administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_584_FmTrukL] Ethnic and economic hierarchies overlapped somewhat, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_585_FmTrukL] We have therefore assumed that individuals of mixed-race descent had privileged access to bureaucratic and administrative positions rather than being restricted from entering them: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_586_FmTrukL] The extent to which positions in the administration were made available to the populations remains in need of further confirmation.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ present ♥ According to Gladwin, children of mixed-race descent were readily integrated into matrilineal kin groups: 'Another aspect of kinship deserves mention. As we have seen this is a matrilineal society, which means that the social placement of a child in the lineage and wider social groupings depends in most respects upon his tie with his mother. The Trukese take this quite literally and therefore pay little or no attention to who may [Page 51] be the child’s actual biological father, even though this may be perfectly obvious. While the unmarried mother may find herself in a somewhat embarrassing social position, as far as can be determined no stigma whatsoever attaches to the child. Children of adulterous unions similarly are simply considered to be the children of the man to whom their mother was married at the time of their birth. Perhaps most important of the problems resolved by this device is that of children fathered by foreigners. At the present time there are literally hundreds of children whose appearance unmistakably shows them to have had Japanese fathers, and who in another society could readily form a class of half-breeds or mestizos with highly disruptive effects for themselves and the society as a whole. But on Truk they are simply Trukese children, treated no differently from any others, and properly furnished with mothers and fathers. Those who have seen the deep cleavage formed in societies elsewhere by mestizo groups can readily appreciate the degree of the good fortune of the Trukese in this regard. There are a few true half-castes on Truk, descendents of early traders who married Trukese women and raised their children themselves; these people consider themselves half-castes and are treated as such. But because this limited group can expand only slightly, not being augmented by further foreign transgressions, they can have little harmful effect and, in fact, have used the business knowledge passed down to them from their fathers or grandfathers to make major contributions to the economic adjustment of Truk under American administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_587_FmTrukL] Ethnic and economic hierarchies overlapped somewhat, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_588_FmTrukL] We have therefore assumed that individuals of mixed-race descent had privileged access to bureaucratic and administrative positions rather than being restricted from entering them: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_589_FmTrukL] The extent to which positions in the administration were made available to the populations remains in need of further confirmation.
♠ Education is available to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ present ♥ According to Gladwin, children of mixed-race descent were readily integrated into matrilineal kin groups: 'Another aspect of kinship deserves mention. As we have seen this is a matrilineal society, which means that the social placement of a child in the lineage and wider social groupings depends in most respects upon his tie with his mother. The Trukese take this quite literally and therefore pay little or no attention to who may [Page 51] be the child’s actual biological father, even though this may be perfectly obvious. While the unmarried mother may find herself in a somewhat embarrassing social position, as far as can be determined no stigma whatsoever attaches to the child. Children of adulterous unions similarly are simply considered to be the children of the man to whom their mother was married at the time of their birth. Perhaps most important of the problems resolved by this device is that of children fathered by foreigners. At the present time there are literally hundreds of children whose appearance unmistakably shows them to have had Japanese fathers, and who in another society could readily form a class of half-breeds or mestizos with highly disruptive effects for themselves and the society as a whole. But on Truk they are simply Trukese children, treated no differently from any others, and properly furnished with mothers and fathers. Those who have seen the deep cleavage formed in societies elsewhere by mestizo groups can readily appreciate the degree of the good fortune of the Trukese in this regard. There are a few true half-castes on Truk, descendents of early traders who married Trukese women and raised their children themselves; these people consider themselves half-castes and are treated as such. But because this limited group can expand only slightly, not being augmented by further foreign transgressions, they can have little harmful effect and, in fact, have used the business knowledge passed down to them from their fathers or grandfathers to make major contributions to the economic adjustment of Truk under American administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_590_FmTrukL] Ethnic and economic hierarchies overlapped somewhat, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_591_FmTrukL] In post-colonial times, elite families had access to higher-quality private education: 'Many elite couples on Moen in 1985 enrolled their children in one of the church-run private schools because they could afford the tuition and [Page 23] because the students were believed to get a better education there, particularly in mastery of the English language. Education, employment, financial capital, and travel experiences all have equipped elites for leadership positions in the modern political system, bringing their power and prestige full circle. Those Trukese aspiring to elite status harbor dreams and ambitions not unlike those of upwardly mobile young Americans. They want a piece of land on Moen on which to build a nice house and enough money to afford a car. The port town’s rapid growth from immigration has fueled land speculation, and today a small plot on which to build a home may sell for several thousand dollars.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_592_FmTrukL] We have therefore assumed that mixed-race individuals had privileged access to emerging educational institutions rather than being barred from entering them: 'Chuuk was settled by the first century A.D. In the fourteenth century, a cult center was established on Moen Island. It was abandoned in the eighteenth century following a fresh immigration from neighboring atolls. Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_593_FmTrukL] The extent to which educations was made available to the population remains in need of further confirmation.
