Those cases of afflictions (blindness, psychosis, and paralysis) which were definitely attributed to a given sorcerer always applied to someone on another island, angry because his wife had been taken away, his property trespassed upon, or the like. Although various people on Romonum were said to know certain techniques of sorcery and many people expressed a fear of being sorcerized, no one would say that a given person had actually sorcerized anyone. The detailed body of knowledge of procedures in sorcery which exists and the circumstantial accounts of how it was formerly used certainly suggest very strongly that in the past Trukese deliberately sorcerized other Trukese. Whether this is the case today, however, is an open question. In the past [Page 150] it was used by master magicians, both against rival magicians and against the laity, and was also used in the punishment of thieves; but then as now sorcery was primarily the result of one person’s animosity against another and as such acted as a sanction against acts which might antagonize another. Thus anxiety about sorcery is another factor weighing the balance in favor of conformist behavior.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_684_FmTrukL]
♠ Rulers are descendants of gods ♣ absent ♥
♠ Rulers become gods after death ♣ present ♥ Some chiefs were worshipped as spirit beings after death: 'Some souls get into Ledidi, some settle down on the islands of bliss. All these restless, wandering /23/ souls are unpopular, for they can easily become angry and do harm. In this condition they are called önu[unknown]au (evil spirit), önuot (devouring spirit), [Page 25] önurot (gloomy spirit), or even sope again. They say of a person who cannot control himself in anger, who does harm to people: “ A nauni emen önu[unknown]au, he has taken on an evil spirit. Most fortunate is the soul that immediately, still at the grave, finds a guide, a guardian spirit (önusor = good spirit). It is spared any superfluous roaming about. It goes into the sky at once with the help of its guide and, if it stands the test by the fauled, even Önulap. The true ones are this kind of önu. To distinguish them from the gods and nature spirits they are also called önuaramas (spirit person). They are worshiped and invoked the most, in ordinary life more than the celestial one. In general they are favorably disposed toward human beings. They have many secondary names which contribute to their characterization: önuot (good spirit), önusor (guardian spirit), önusodub (spirit which does not deceive. These önu play an important role in the life of the uanönu (spirit carriers) and the ton abab önu (spirit invoker).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_685_FmTrukL] 'Many old people of Truk think that the souls are assigned to different places in the sky according to their eila[unknown], that is, their totemic kin-group. They call the places bis, like the places of the gods. The souls live there, eat, drink, smoke, sleep, dance, etc., just as on earth. In moral aspects too they are true human beings. The bis of the kin group Atau is called Ola and stands under the chief Pulopul. The bis of the kin group Witö has the name of Familon and stands under the chief Sapelipun.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_686_FmTrukL] 'Many of these önuot have made themselves a great name through the miraculous grantings of prayers which are attributed to them, for example, Olap (great man), a former chief of the island of Uman.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_687_FmTrukL] However, we have found no evidence of automatic deification.
♠ Automatic deification ♣ absent ♥
♠ Rulers are gods ♣ absent ♥

Normative Ideological Aspects of Equity and Prosociality[edit]

♠ Ideological reinforcement of equality ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates rulers and commoners ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates elites and commoners ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates all ethnicities ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of ideology explicitly equating all ethnicities.
♠ Ideological thought equates men and women ♣ absent ♥
♠ Ideological thought equates people of all locations ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes rulers and commoners ♣ present ♥ Chiefs were associated with sacredness: 'A district chiefship was divided between the oldest man in the senior female line in the chiefly lineage and the oldest man in the lineage generally. The latter was executive chief, or "chief of talk," and the former symbolic chief, or "chief of food." Food presentations were made to the symbolic chief. Sometimes the symbolic and executive functions fell to the same individual; often they did not. The symbolic chief was surrounded by his lineage brothers and by his sons, who acted as his agents. These followers and his sisters and daughters were of chiefly rank, distinct from commoners. Through conquest, a lineage might gain the chiefship in more than one district and establish a junior branch as the chiefly lineage in the conquered district. The now subordinate district rendered food presentations to the superordinate one. Most districts were linked in two rival leagues based on competing schools of magic and ritual relating to war, politics, and rhetoric. A chief's authority derived from two things. His lineage's ownership of the district's space entitled him to presentations of first fruits at stated times of the year. More importantly, it gave him authority over the conservation and use of the district's food resources. His authority also derived from his connection with the sky world, its gods, and their superhuman power to accomplish purposes. There was, therefore, a degree of sacredness associated with chiefs.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_688_FmTrukL] Chiefs and their associates were also thought to control magical power: 'There were no police. A chief's brothers or sons might act on his behalf to intimidate or attack someone who had offended him. But it was control of magical power, either by the chief or one his brothers or sons, that made improper conduct liable to punishment. Major craft specialists could also make ill those who violated the taboos of their craft. Finally, members of chiefly lineages and their close associates were likely to have knowledge of sorcery. All such knowledge gave punitive power to chiefs and important specialists. People stressed maintaining the appearance of propriety in behavior so as not to give just cause for offense.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_689_FmTrukL] 'Although sorcery is an important cause of illness in both societies, and while Ponapean medicine appears to be vaguely similar to the Trukese system, controls in the Ponapean system do not appear to ramify throughout social relations (Reisenberg, 1948). Although illness may be interpreted as punishment for offenses against men of very high position, medical theory does not function to mediate everyday interpersonal relations to the extent that it does on Truk.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_690_FmTrukL] But while sorcery could be used for punitve purposes, it was also used for retaliation among 'commoners': 'Sorcery is a more direct if more secret form of aggression and is practically precluded from being applied within the lineage by the fact that the spells used are in each case the property of a given lineage. While it is not clear whether they would be considered effective, it is very doubtful that they would be used against others who knew them or could be expected to know them. Data on sorcery are difficult to obtain for no one admits to being a sorcerer. Those cases of afflictions (blindness, psychosis, and paralysis) which were definitely attributed to a given sorcerer always applied to someone on another island, angry because his wife had been taken away, his property trespassed upon, or the like. Although various people on Romonum were said to know certain techniques of sorcery and many people expressed a fear of being sorcerized, no one would say that a given person had actually sorcerized anyone. The detailed body of knowledge of procedures in sorcery which exists and the circumstantial accounts of how it was formerly used certainly suggest very strongly that in the past Trukese deliberately sorcerized other Trukese. Whether this is the case today, however, is an open question. In the past [Page 150] it was used by master magicians, both against rival magicians and against the laity, and was also used in the punishment of thieves; but then as now sorcery was primarily the result of one person’s animosity against another and as such acted as a sanction against acts which might antagonize another. Thus anxiety about sorcery is another factor weighing the balance in favor of conformist behavior.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_691_FmTrukL] But given the 'sacred' character of chiefs, we have decided to code 'present'.
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes elites and commoners ♣ present ♥ As a clan-based society, the Chuukese were initially stratified according to lineages: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_692_FmTrukL] 'The domestic unit was an extended family, based on the women of a lineage or sublineage. It consisted of at least one experienced older woman and two more younger women of childbearing age together with their husbands. Unmarried sons and brothers slept apart in their lineage's meeting house. Extended family households continued through the periods of foreign administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_693_FmTrukL] Chiefly lineages owned land associated with their territorial district: 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_694_FmTrukL] Chiefs generally hailed from senior lineages and relied on the support of male kin: 'A district chiefship was divided between the oldest man in the senior female line in the chiefly lineage and the oldest man in the lineage generally. The latter was executive chief, or "chief of talk," and the former symbolic chief, or "chief of food." Food presentations were made to the symbolic chief. Sometimes the symbolic and executive functions fell to the same individual; often they did not. The symbolic chief was surrounded by his lineage brothers and by his sons, who acted as his agents. These followers and his sisters and daughters were of chiefly rank, distinct from commoners. Through conquest, a lineage might gain the chiefship in more than one district and establish a junior branch as the chiefly lineage in the conquered district. The now subordinate district rendered food presentations to the superordinate one. Most districts were linked in two rival leagues based on competing schools of magic and ritual relating to war, politics, and rhetoric. A chief's authority derived from two things. His lineage's ownership of the district's space entitled him to presentations of first fruits at stated times of the year. More importantly, it gave him authority over the conservation and use of the district's food resources. His authority also derived from his connection with the sky world, its gods, and their superhuman power to accomplish purposes. There was, therefore, a degree of sacredness associated with chiefs.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_695_FmTrukL] However, it appears that the differentiation between chiefly and commoner lineages did not amount to a formal caste system: 'There was little clothing differentiation according to status. Chiefs and men of wealth wore somewhat more richly ornamented garments, but these statuses were not associated with special items of clothing. This privilege was reserved for the specialist in native lore (itang) and for the breadfruit summoner, souattomei. On those occasions when the itang talked to the people in the meeting house, he wore a special cloak (nite), woven from banana fibers along the same pattern as the ordinary man’s cloak, pinu; at these times also, he was the only person allowed to wear the conical pandanus hat, saaim. The souattomei possessed a special loincloth (meciijenimei) which [Page 323] he wore during the model canoe races connected with the breadfruit summoning ceremonies, and also at the feast signalling the end of these ceremonies.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_696_FmTrukL] Socioeconomic differentiation along class lines emerged in the colonial and post-colonial periods: 'Substantial differences in monetary and material wealth exist among Peniyesene’s population, as evidenced in everything from housing to transportation to clothing and diet. Some residents are, by Micronesian standards, rich; others are abysmally poor. Considerable evidence exists that these differences in wealth are giving rise to emergent social classes. Some residents of Peniyesene own two cars and live in new cement homes with linoleum floors, glass louvred windows, kerosene refrigerators or freezers, western-style furniture, and electricity (from small diesel generators), which is used to run electric lights, fans, and, in at least one case, a washing machine. These same wealthy families operate one or two motorboats equipped with 25 horsepower Johnson or Evinrude outboard engines, dress in stylish clothing, purchase fancy toys for their children, and [Page 29] [Page 30] diaper their babies with disposable diapers. Family meals regularly include frozen Australian beef, chicken from the United States, and such delicacies as cinnamon rolls flown in fresh on Air Mike from Tommy’s Bakery on Guam.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_697_FmTrukL] 'At the other end of the village economic scale, several large families have no member employed for wages and continue to subsist on a traditional Trukese diet of breadfruit, taro, and fresh fish, supplemented by small amounts of imported food, such as rice and flour. Their minimal monetary resources derive from the sale of copra to the TTC or from occasional part-time labor for wealthier members of the community. They own neither car nor motorboat and are lucky to own a canoe. Their homes are either single-room plywood boxes or small structures made piecemeal from corrugated tin, old packing crates, and random pieces of lumber. Their clothing is old and tattered and their children have no fine toys with which to amuse themselves.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_698_FmTrukL] 'These large differences in wealth and life-style are galling to many Trukese who hold egalitarianism as a fundamental ethic; the drunken behavior of many young men in the community is not unrelated to perceived class differences. Several of the wealthier individuals in Peniyesene keep.22 caliber rifles to deal with persons who might try to break into their homes at night.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_699_FmTrukL] Ethnic and economic hierarchies overlapped somewhat, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent generally belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_700_FmTrukL] Kinship nevertheless remained important: 'We have some misgivings about using class labels derived from the American system to describe Trukese society, and we are convinced that a class analysis by itself cannot explain the reality of modern Trukese social organization. For Truk remains a society organized primarily and fundamentally along kinship lines, and the lineages and clans still serve as the [Page 22] basis for the social structure, whether in the realm of politics or of economics. What we label “incipient social classes” overlay and crosscut the undergirding kinship structure in significant ways, and failing to discuss these emergent differences would produce an inaccurate picture of life in the islands today. A recognition of nascent social classes in Truk is also essential to an understanding of women’s involvement in the prohibition movement over the past decade. In Truk, as in the United States a century ago, middle-class women provided the leadership and the energy to launch and sustain prohibition (see Chapter Seven).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_701_FmTrukL] But given the distinction between 'chiefly' and 'commoner' lineages, we have decided to code 'present'.
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes all ethnicities ♣ absent ♥ Writing in the colonial period, Gladwin claims that 'mixed-race' individuals were readily integrated into matrilineal kin groups: 'Another aspect of kinship deserves mention. As we have seen this is a matrilineal society, which means that the social placement of a child in the lineage and wider social groupings depends in most respects upon his tie with his mother. The Trukese take this quite literally and therefore pay little or no attention to who may [Page 51] be the child’s actual biological father, even though this may be perfectly obvious. While the unmarried mother may find herself in a somewhat embarrassing social position, as far as can be determined no stigma whatsoever attaches to the child. Children of adulterous unions similarly are simply considered to be the children of the man to whom their mother was married at the time of their birth. Perhaps most important of the problems resolved by this device is that of children fathered by foreigners. At the present time there are literally hundreds of children whose appearance unmistakably shows them to have had Japanese fathers, and who in another society could readily form a class of half-breeds or mestizos with highly disruptive effects for themselves and the society as a whole. But on Truk they are simply Trukese children, treated no differently from any others, and properly furnished with mothers and fathers. Those who have seen the deep cleavage formed in societies elsewhere by mestizo groups can readily appreciate the degree of the good fortune of the Trukese in this regard. There are a few true half-castes on Truk, descendents of early traders who married Trukese women and raised their children themselves; these people consider themselves half-castes and are treated as such. But because this limited group can expand only slightly, not being augmented by further foreign transgressions, they can have little harmful effect and, in fact, have used the business knowledge passed down to them from their fathers or grandfathers to make major contributions to the economic adjustment of Truk under American administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_702_FmTrukL] We have found no evidence of discrimination against mixed-race individuals within Chuuk communities. Ethnic and class hierarchies intersected to an extent, with Chuukese of part-Japanese descent often belonging to an emergent elite: 'Some of today’s elite are part Japanese, the progeny and descendants of unions between Trukese women and Japanese men in an era when few Japanese women lived in the islands. Truk’s elite, as with elites in developing countries elsewhere in the world, have more money, material possessions, and sophistication than their compatriots, largely because they have had greater access to education—particularly higher education—and wage employment, opportunities that have been passed along to their children in most cases. A considerable number of elite families on Moen own two cars, one of which they operate as a taxi to generate extra family income. On a good day a taxi driver can earn $75-$100 on Moen at a set fare of 25 cents/ride (50 cents to the outermost villages).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_703_FmTrukL] It seems that ideology did not explicitly devalue other ethnic groups, but this remains in need of confirmation.
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes men and women ♣ present ♥ Chuukese followed a gendered division of labour: 'Traditionally, men gardened, cooked and processed food in bulk (in the earth oven), did deep-water fishing, engaged in war and public affairs, and practiced the arts of canoe and house building and of wood, shell, and stone working. Women wove, plaited mats, prepared meals (as distinct from food in bulk), did inshore fishing, and took main responsibility for child care. Men and women have both entered into school teaching, clerical work, and administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_704_FmTrukL] Women were excluded from some ceremonial activities due to gendered ritual taboos: 'A few dances are also connected with the worship of the spirits. These are the dugia (dance with kurukur, that is, staffs of orange wood) and the älimod, a dance which is performed in a sitting position. The former is a men’s dance; the latter may be performed by both sexes. During the entire dancing period the dancers are shut up in the udd. This is surrounded by a fence which no unbidden person, especially no woman, may approach. No indecent word occurs in these spirit dances, in contrast to the other dances. They say that the spirits do not like indecent things in connection with the men, a statement which does not correspond with their views on other occasions.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_705_FmTrukL] 'The pue is handled in different ways. The most important and solemn pue is the girot. The soupue makes the girot in the udd in the /66/ presence of his pupils. Women are not allowed to watch. As a matter of fact no woman is allowed to make any kind of pue.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_706_FmTrukL] 'After the apu[unknown]etou, the canoe, which is called faremai (= önumai) if it is a rowing canoe, is tested. It goes out on the sea for the kitir (rowing or sailing race). No woman is allowed to board the faremai, and no food may be put in it. The food must go with the other canoes. In the center of the new canoe sits the souatomai, who caresses the canoe and invokes the spirits. Having reached water favorable for navigation, the crew starts to row, and the vessels shoot across the broad surface with the speed of arrows. The invocations of the suatomai become more and more animated; the iéfot, iéfot of the rowers, wilder and wilder. Strange /74/ canoes passing by must be careful about coming too close to the faremai, for it is sacred.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_707_FmTrukL] Men in turn were excluded from some female-gendered activities, such as childbirth: 'It is not so simple for a child to be born on Truk. One can call it a near miracle if a child escapes all who struggle for its life before and after birth. The woman in childbirth is separated from the other occupants of the house. She often occupies a little house built especially for the birth. One or another older woman from among the relatives, called soufam or souetikar (midwives), is to be found with her. Entrance is forbidden to all men.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_708_FmTrukL] According to Caughey, lineage leaders were usually male and brothers had authority over sisters: 'A lineage is conceived of as a group of siblings ( pwiipwi). In a group of real siblings, males have authority over females and the “eldest brother” ( mwaaniichi) is the leader. Within the lineage, the oldest male of the oldest generation is usually the “lineage leader” ( mmwen noon eterekes, [Page 65] “first inside of the lineage”).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_709_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, brothers were owed respect by sisters: 'As long as the children are small, they run around completely naked. When they become bigger and approach maturity, the boys receive their akadöwar (modesty band), the girls their atok (hip mat). From the day when the boy has his band he is considered a youth. The sister, when meeting him, must aporo, that is, bow. An old custom to indicate the age of a boy is connected with this modesty band. To the question, “How old is the boy?” comes the answer, for example, “ etö efärin” (= akadöwar), that is, a modesty band, which means that he has grown beyond the age of a boy. The natives do not have any precise estimate of their age. None of them is able [Page 99] to say how old he is with any exactness. To designate the stages of age, they have mönukol (1) 1 Literally: the conceived. , sediben (2) 2 “It has no will.” semirid (3) 3 “It cannot think.” = child, that is, very small children. For somewhat bigger ones, the expressions äd, säri (boy), le[unknown]in (girl) are used; at maturity, whether married or not, öluöl (youth), fabul (young woman). Adult persons are called muan (man), fefin (woman).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_710_FmTrukL] However, women could hold property even without the husband's consent (Chuukese lineages were matrilineal): 'The position of the Truk woman in legal respects is not degrading. They are not weakly in the hands of the husband. I have seen men who were terribly henpecked. The women have their property, are able to acquire, buy, and sell without the husband’s consent. The children also belong exclusively to them. They have little work and for the most part are treated well, even if only to prevent them from running away. It is considered wrong to beat women.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_711_FmTrukL]
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes people from different locations ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Ideological reinforcement of inequality ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ Ideological reinforcement of monogamy ♣ suspected unknown ♥ The Chuukese were organized according to membership in matrilineal clans: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_712_FmTrukL] 'The domestic unit was an extended family, based on the women of a lineage or sublineage. It consisted of at least one experienced older woman and two more younger women of childbearing age together with their husbands. Unmarried sons and brothers slept apart in their lineage's meeting house. Extended family households continued through the periods of foreign administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_713_FmTrukL] According to Goodenough, levirate/sororate marriages were practiced: 'Marriage took place for women a bit before and for men a bit after the age of 20. Premarital courtship was covert and included sexual relations. Residence was usually matrilocal. Divorce, common before the birth of children, was rare thereafter. It could be initiated by either spouse and was often instigated by the wife's brothers. Levirate and sororate remarriages were valued. To keep soil and trees that had been granted to the children of a lineage's men circulating back, marriage preferences with one or another kind of cousin, varying from locality to locality, were widespread.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_714_FmTrukL] According to Bollig, polygyny was fairly widespread, partly as a result of levirate/sororate marriages: 'Polygamy (1) 1 a akaruu, he has two wives; a akaulu[unknown]at, he has three wives, etc. is very widespread on Truk. Men with two to nine wives are numerous. One becomes polygamous through the death of his brother, for out of brotherly love he has an obligation to take the widow for himself (levirate marriage). Another one marries a widow with daughters and takes the latter, as soon as they are old enough, as secondary wives. A third takes the sisters of his wife for himself, which is the case for most polygamous situations. The reasons for polygamy vary. One wants to keep landed property together by this means, or to concentrate it in his hands; another wants to have workers, since the secondary wives fish for him. Strangely enough, the motive forces for polygamy are said to be mostly the women themselves. They offer their daughters, sisters, [Page 109] and nieces to their husbands as secondary wives, in order that no strange family come in. This happens especially if they have no children, for if a strange woman comes in and gives birth to children, they will be pushed aside. They try to prevent this by means of the above measure. If polygamy has come about in this way, a peaceful life together is possible, for the women stay together in their own interests. But if the women come from different families or tribes, living together is out of the question. They live apart, and the man has the pleasant task of going back and forth. Unpleasantness and jealousy between the rivals are the order of the day. First one and then the other thinks she is being slighted. First one is tired, then the other. And the husband must always be on the move in order to keep everybody happy. Some polygamous situations which I knew were changing constantly. At one time the husband had four, then some ran away, later they increased to six, etc. A somewhat decent family life is inconceivable. The eventual /101/ children always go with the mother, but the father knows the means for drawing them to him when they are older, so that he will have a work force. Some polygamists are very generous with their wives. They are quickly ready to hand them over to their unmarried relatives, because it gives them advantages. They are able to take a new one and still consider the old one indirectly as their own.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_715_FmTrukL] Bollig claims that polyandry was rare: 'Polyandry seems to be rarer. I knew of only one case, in which two brothers had a common wife.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_716_FmTrukL] But Caughey claims that while polygamy was present, monogamy was the norm for most: 'In the traditional society polygynous marriages rarely occurred. Since marriage sets up heavy obligations to the wife’s lineage, most men did not want to increase this burden, especially by marrying into different lineages. Interpreted differently, the same reasons provided the rationale for those few cases of polygny that did occur. A man who married more than one wife demonstrated his importance and power. It showed that he was capable of engaging in burdensome social relationships with more than one lineage or that he was able to turn this subordinate relationship into one where he dominated. A famous man of bravery on Fáánakkar was once married at the same time to five wives from four different lineages. Later, in a grand gesture of kindness, he gave one of them away to a wifeless brother.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_717_FmTrukL] Expert confirmation is needed on the matter. Information on a possible decline of polygyny in favour of monogamy after Christianization may also be needed.
♠ Ideology reinforces prosociality ♣ present ♥
♠ charity ♣ absent: 1886-1930 CE; present: 1931-1948 CE ♥ Traditionally, informal patterns of self-help, neighbourly assistance and support from the matrilineage were common: 'Within its district each lineage owns a particular plot of land which is regarded as its “true home” or “lineage center” ( imweyiche). The dwelling houses of resident members are typically clustered at this site, and members living elsewhere frequently return here to visit. Persons residing at the lineage center will include some genealogical members of the lineage plus other people who have current links to resident members. Typically some of these will be persons of the same district while others will be members of other districts and occasionally of other islands.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_718_FmTrukL] 'More than one lineage is important to an individual on aanakkar. He automatically has pressing obligations to serve others in his own lineages, and he has strong rights to demand support from them in return. He also has lesser but important rights and obligations to members of his father’s lineage and to members of his spouse’s lineage (for a man this will also be the lineage of his children). Finally he has minor obligations to his father’s father’s lineage and to his spouse’s father’s lineage.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_719_FmTrukL] The sources also mention women's organizations: 'Until the mid-1950s, the few women’s organizations in the Trust Territory were religious in nature. During the period of U.S. administration after World War II, women’s clubs took root, spread slowly, and eventually helped “to raise the standard of living, to arouse interest in adult education and... [to play] an ever increasing and important role in providing community leadership” (U.S. Department of State 1963:83). In 1954, mothers had organized themselves in female parent-teacher groups in a few communities of the Trust Territory (U.S. Department of State 1954:70), and by the following year “a few women’s organizations [had] become active, particularly in the Palau and Ponape Districts, in promoting better child, home, and family care and in sponsoring community, social, and educational activities” (U.S. Department of State 1955:70). By 1962, the Trust Territory administration reported that “almost all districts now have local women’s interests officers,” although technically this was true for only three of the six districts, the others subsuming women’s interests under the responsibilities of community development officers (U.S. Department of State 1962:91, 1963:77). In Truk, for example, one of the first women graduates of Truk High School was sent to Hawaii for a six-month training program in commercial sewing at the Institute for Technical Interchange at the East-West Center, and upon her return to Truk she began working in the Community Development Office. Much of her advice to women’s groups away from Moen consisted of teaching them “how to cook and how to sew,” that is, in sharing her special training in home economics (Ibid.). By 1967, more than 60 women’s groups were organized in the Trust Territory, 5 in Truk District (U.S. Department of State 1967:91). Nearly all their activities were focused on women’s traditional domestic and family caretaker roles. Clearly, the stereotypes surrounding women’s roles in the United States at the time limited Trust Territory government efforts to cater to “women’s interests.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_720_FmTrukL] 'Micronesian and American business and professional women established the first formal women’s club in Truk in 1960. The Trukese-American Women’s Association (or TAWA) included government employees and women engaged in commercial activities ( Truk Review, May-June 1960, p. 4; U.S. Department of State 1960:83). Among the 22 dues-paying members of this new club were women from all government departments and all major trading companies ( Truk Review, May-June 1960, p. 4). The publicized purpose of this organization was modest indeed: “To gain a better understanding of one another and to provide an opportunity for social gatherings...” that occurred approximately once a month (Ibid.).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_721_FmTrukL] 'Beyond church women’s groups, a number of other women’s clubs existed in Truk in the mid-1980s. One—Club 20—was a latter-day version of the old TAWA organization. Club 20 was a multiethnic group of elite Trukese and foreign women who met in Moen restaurants on the 20th of each month and had a maximum membership of 20. According to their bylaws, the purpose of Club 20 was to further members’ social and intellectual interests, and to cooperate with other organizations in advancing community welfare in the areas of beautification, sharing, and scholarships. Money for the scholarship fund was raised from white elephant, bazaar, and bake sales. In 1985, Club 20 had Trukese, Filipino, and American members, including local elite women who held government jobs or whose husbands were important government officials. The most recent attempt at a general organization linking various women’s groups in Truk was the Truk Women’s Association and its Planning Commission. Fin Anisi and Mwichen Maria women central to the temperance movement in Truk (see Chapter Five) established this organization and were the prime movers behind efforts to heighten women’s involvement in the political arena.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_722_FmTrukL] 'Another important women’s club, though one which includes men in some of its activities, is the Truk Red Cross. Koben Mori established the first Red Cross Chapter in Truk in the 1930s (Dolan 1974:59), but it was moribund during most of the American period. In 1984, the wife of one of Koben Mori’s descendants revived the Red Cross organization in Truk to aid local relief efforts after a cholera epidemic. She also hoped the Red Cross would show women they could take care of others in their own communities without outside help. In 1985, recruiting meetings were held in villages throughout Truk State to explain the organization’s goals to [Page 52] women in outlying areas. Essentially, the Truk Red Cross was organized as a private community charity because it was not chartered by either the American Red Cross or the International Red Cross. Truk Red Cross members often carried gifts of soap, towels, or clothing donated by businesses or wealthy Trukese to the elderly poor. In addition to caring for less fortunate people on Moen, Red Cross members have engaged in civic beautification projects—cleaning up rubbish around the airport and the boat pool and planting flowers in public places. The organization sponsored a nine-day-long health care training class in 1987, led by a Honolulu physician, which ended with official first-aid certification of 40 women (The Micronesia Institute 1987). A new building they erected in 1987 was destroyed by Typhoon Nina in November of that year and funds were being sought for its replacement (Ibid.).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_723_FmTrukL] It appears that women's clubs with charitable functions only appeared after WW II. We have chosen the establishment of the Red Cross society as a provisional turning point and adopted 1930 as the date of transition. This is open to review.
♠ production of public goods ♣ present ♥ Construction of meeting houses might qualify. Chiefs could draw on labour services performed by their clan: 'The chief can draw on his people for public works. If the work is done in his private interest, however, he must feed and compensate the people.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_724_FmTrukL] Gladwin also mentions public labour services for the construction of sanitation infrastructure ordered by the colonial government: 'The work activity probably second to food production and preparation, in point of time expended, consists in the maintenance of the island paths, seawalls, and other public works, together with the implementation of the administration’s sanitation directives. One day a week (on a few islands two) is set aside by agreement between the chief and the people for such labor in which all healthy adults from the ages of sixteen to sixty participate through most of the working hours of the day. A cash payment into the island treasury approximately equivalent to the current wage for manual labor may be substituted for this, but can be afforded in general only by those whose regular employment for pay elsewhere precludes their participation. This work is essentially non-productive from the standpoint of the lineages or individuals involved but is rather vaguely felt to be good for the island and in any event is acepted as inevitable. Practically all of the projects undertaken on these island work days can be traced to the orders or recommendations of the present and past foreign administrations; they thus represent a major source of work in excess of the requirements of earlier days.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_725_FmTrukL]
♠ communal dining ♣ present ♥ Hospitality was common. Hosts sought protection from greedy guests through food sorcery: 'General food sorcery can be used to aggress against and attempt to control the actions of people who take too great advantage of hospitality patterns. These patterns require that all persons who are present any time food is consumed be invited to participate in the meal. The only strong sanction that can be used against those who become more or less permanent guests is the threat of food sorcery. In addition, these sanctions can be manipulated to keep relatives eating at home, in which case they can also be induced to contribute their labor to help in supplying provisions.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_726_FmTrukL] 'The food sorcery of sub-division B placed a restraint on those who would take undue advantage of hospitality patterns. It can work two ways, by helping prevent depredations on a lineage’s own food supply, and sometimes through illness, reminding lineage members that their safest place is back home helping their own lineages.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_727_FmTrukL]
♠ morality ♣ suspected unknown ♥

Normative Ideological Aspects of Slavery[edit]

♠ Ideology forbids slavery for co-ethnics ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Ideology forbids slavery for co-religionists ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Ideology forbids slavery universally ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no evidence of slavery in the colonial period. However, we have found no evidence of explicit ideological prohibitions either.

Normative Ideological Aspects of Human Sacrifice[edit]

♠ Human sacrifice ♣ 3 ♥ According to Bollig, the bodies of slain enemies were cut into pieces and eaten: 'The prisoners were usually done away with. Anyone who had a bone to pick with them cut their throats. Yet I have also heard of cases in which the prisoners were spared on please of the women and were later released. The slain enemies were cut into pieces. /106/ In the frenzy some drank their blood or cut pieces from the soft parts, roasted them, and ate them to cool their vengeance.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_728_FmTrukL] He also mentions what appears to be a form of human sacrifice: 'The spirit Paladiu on the island of Falanu is even more modest. Human excrement satisfies him as an offering. During a war human sacrifices seem to have been offered also. At least cases are known where captives had their throats cut over the graves of those who had fallen, so that the blood would be sprinkled over them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_729_FmTrukL] Bollig also claims the ritual mutilation of dead enemies: 'When the plans were ready and the preparations completed, the entire body of troops gathered opposite the enemy territory at a place which was suitable for the battle (rasen moun). Here the ida[unknown] put up the önusoso or soönu (erected spirit). This önusoso was a wooden figure which represented a human being or an animal, for example, shark, hake. In some cases a corpse itself was used. For example, such a soönu was to be found on the premises of the mission on Fautuen. It was the corpse of an enemy warrior who had been treacherously killed. It was set against a tree stump, with the face toward the country of the enemy. The face was terribly disfigured, in that the lips were cut off. The mouth stood open, prevented from closing by a spike of bone. In its hand the corpse held a spear which likewise was directed toward the enemy.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_730_FmTrukL] LeBar denies the cannibalization of enemies: 'Informants denied that slain enemies were ever eaten on Truk. A variant way of handling the dead in the old days required that the corpse be wrapped in mats and hung in the house. Relatives might show their fondness for the deceased by eating [Page 223] a bit of the flesh or drinking a few drops of the body fluids collected in a bowl beneath the corpse.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_731_FmTrukL] We have provisionally coded the variable 'present' as Bollig provides more material overall, but expert feedback is needed on the matter.
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred present ♥ According to Bollig, the bodies of slain enemies were cut into pieces and eaten: 'The prisoners were usually done away with. Anyone who had a bone to pick with them cut their throats. Yet I have also heard of cases in which the prisoners were spared on please of the women and were later released. The slain enemies were cut into pieces. /106/ In the frenzy some drank their blood or cut pieces from the soft parts, roasted them, and ate them to cool their vengeance.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_732_FmTrukL] He also mentions what appears to be a form of human sacrifice: 'The spirit Paladiu on the island of Falanu is even more modest. Human excrement satisfies him as an offering. During a war human sacrifices seem to have been offered also. At least cases are known where captives had their throats cut over the graves of those who had fallen, so that the blood would be sprinkled over them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_733_FmTrukL] Bollig also claims the ritual mutilation of dead enemies: 'When the plans were ready and the preparations completed, the entire body of troops gathered opposite the enemy territory at a place which was suitable for the battle (rasen moun). Here the ida[unknown] put up the önusoso or soönu (erected spirit). This önusoso was a wooden figure which represented a human being or an animal, for example, shark, hake. In some cases a corpse itself was used. For example, such a soönu was to be found on the premises of the mission on Fautuen. It was the corpse of an enemy warrior who had been treacherously killed. It was set against a tree stump, with the face toward the country of the enemy. The face was terribly disfigured, in that the lips were cut off. The mouth stood open, prevented from closing by a spike of bone. In its hand the corpse held a spear which likewise was directed toward the enemy.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_734_FmTrukL] LeBar denies the cannibalization of enemies: 'Informants denied that slain enemies were ever eaten on Truk. A variant way of handling the dead in the old days required that the corpse be wrapped in mats and hung in the house. Relatives might show their fondness for the deceased by eating [Page 223] a bit of the flesh or drinking a few drops of the body fluids collected in a bowl beneath the corpse.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_735_FmTrukL] We have provisionally coded the variable 'present' as Bollig provides more material overall, but expert feedback is needed on the matter.
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ According to Bollig, the bodies of slain enemies were cut into pieces and eaten: 'The prisoners were usually done away with. Anyone who had a bone to pick with them cut their throats. Yet I have also heard of cases in which the prisoners were spared on please of the women and were later released. The slain enemies were cut into pieces. /106/ In the frenzy some drank their blood or cut pieces from the soft parts, roasted them, and ate them to cool their vengeance.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_736_FmTrukL] He also mentions what appears to be a form of human sacrifice: 'The spirit Paladiu on the island of Falanu is even more modest. Human excrement satisfies him as an offering. During a war human sacrifices seem to have been offered also. At least cases are known where captives had their throats cut over the graves of those who had fallen, so that the blood would be sprinkled over them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_737_FmTrukL] Bollig also claims the ritual mutilation of dead enemies: 'When the plans were ready and the preparations completed, the entire body of troops gathered opposite the enemy territory at a place which was suitable for the battle (rasen moun). The mouth stood open, prevented from closing by a spike of bone. In its hand the corpse held a spear which likewise was directed toward the enemy.' ♠ human sacrifice of a low-status individual ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ human sacrifice of a criminal ♣ inferred absent ♥ According to Bollig, the bodies of slain enemies were cut into pieces and eaten: 'The prisoners were usually done away with. Anyone who had a bone to pick with them cut their throats. Yet I have also heard of cases in which the prisoners were spared on please of the women and were later released. The slain enemies were cut into pieces. /106/ In the frenzy some drank their blood or cut pieces from the soft parts, roasted them, and ate them to cool their vengeance.' ♠ human sacrifice of a high status individual ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ According to Bollig, the bodies of slain enemies were cut into pieces and eaten: 'The prisoners were usually done away with. Anyone who had a bone to pick with them cut their throats. Yet I have also heard of cases in which the prisoners were spared on please of the women and were later released. The slain enemies were cut into pieces. /106/ In the frenzy some drank their blood or cut pieces from the soft parts, roasted them, and ate them to cool their vengeance.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_744_FmTrukL] He also mentions what appears to be a form of human sacrifice: 'The spirit Paladiu on the island of Falanu is even more modest. Human excrement satisfies him as an offering. During a war human sacrifices seem to have been offered also. At least cases are known where captives had their throats cut over the graves of those who had fallen, so that the blood would be sprinkled over them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_745_FmTrukL] Bollig also claims the ritual mutilation of dead enemies: 'When the plans were ready and the preparations completed, the entire body of troops gathered opposite the enemy territory at a place which was suitable for the battle (rasen moun). ♠ human sacrifice of other ♣ ♥
♠ Maximum known number of victims in a HS event ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Capital Punishment for Religious Offenses ♣ ♥
♠ Capital Punishment for Witchcraft ♣ ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ unknown ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ unknown ♥
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ unknown ♥ According to Bollig, the bodies of slain enemies were cut into pieces and eaten: 'The prisoners were usually done away with. Anyone who had a bone to pick with them cut their throats. Yet I have also heard of cases in which the prisoners were spared on please of the women and were later released. The slain enemies were cut into pieces. /106/ In the frenzy some drank their blood or cut pieces from the soft parts, roasted them, and ate them to cool their vengeance.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_748_FmTrukL] He also mentions what appears to be a form of human sacrifice: 'The spirit Paladiu on the island of Falanu is even more modest. Human excrement satisfies him as an offering. During a war human sacrifices seem to have been offered also. At least cases are known where captives had their throats cut over the graves of those who had fallen, so that the blood would be sprinkled over them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_749_FmTrukL] Bollig also claims the ritual mutilation of dead enemies: 'When the plans were ready and the preparations completed, the entire body of troops gathered opposite the enemy territory at a place which was suitable for the battle (rasen moun). Here the ida[unknown] put up the önusoso or soönu (erected spirit). This önusoso was a wooden figure which represented a human being or an animal, for example, shark, hake. In some cases a corpse itself was used. For example, such a soönu was to be found on the premises of the mission on Fautuen. It was the corpse of an enemy warrior who had been treacherously killed. It was set against a tree stump, with the face toward the country of the enemy. The face was terribly disfigured, in that the lips were cut off. The mouth stood open, prevented from closing by a spike of bone. In its hand the corpse held a spear which likewise was directed toward the enemy.' A variant way of handling the dead in the old days required that the corpse be wrapped in mats and hung in the house. Relatives might show their fondness for the deceased by eating [Page 223] a bit of the flesh or drinking a few drops of the body fluids collected in a bowl beneath the corpse.' ♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ inferred absent ♥ According to Bollig, the bodies of slain enemies were cut into pieces and eaten: 'The prisoners were usually done away with. Anyone who had a bone to pick with them cut their throats. Yet I have also heard of cases in which the prisoners were spared on please of the women and were later released. The slain enemies were cut into pieces. /106/ In the frenzy some drank their blood or cut pieces from the soft parts, roasted them, and ate them to cool their vengeance.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_752_FmTrukL] He also mentions what appears to be a form of human sacrifice: 'The spirit Paladiu on the island of Falanu is even more modest. Human excrement satisfies him as an offering. During a war human sacrifices seem to have been offered also. At least cases are known where captives had their throats cut over the graves of those who had fallen, so that the blood would be sprinkled over them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_753_FmTrukL] Bollig also claims the ritual mutilation of dead enemies: 'When the plans were ready and the preparations completed, the entire body of troops gathered opposite the enemy territory at a place which was suitable for the battle (rasen moun). Here the ida[unknown] put up the önusoso or soönu (erected spirit). This önusoso was a wooden figure which represented a human being or an animal, for example, shark, hake. In some cases a corpse itself was used. For example, such a soönu was to be found on the premises of the mission on Fautuen. It was the corpse of an enemy warrior who had been treacherously killed. It was set against a tree stump, with the face toward the country of the enemy. The face was terribly disfigured, in that the lips were cut off. The mouth stood open, prevented from closing by a spike of bone. In its hand the corpse held a spear which likewise was directed toward the enemy.' A variant way of handling the dead in the old days required that the corpse be wrapped in mats and hung in the house. Relatives might show their fondness for the deceased by eating [Page 223] a bit of the flesh or drinking a few drops of the body fluids collected in a bowl beneath the corpse.' Moralizing Supernatural Powers[edit]

♠ Moral concern is primary ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is certain ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing norms are broad ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is targeted ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement of rulers ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by elites ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by commoners ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in afterlife ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in this life ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is agentic ♣ present ♥These data were reviewed by expert advisors and consultants. For a detailed description of these data, refer to the relevant Analytic Narratives, reference tables, and acknowledgements page.[MAJIDBENAM_REF_756_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_REF_757_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_REF_758_FmTrukL]

Normative Ideological precepts concerning morality/supernatural beings[edit]

Supernatural beings (e.g., gods, spirits, ancestors)
♠ Number of officially sanctioned supernatural beings ♣ polytheistic ♥ 'Besides Önulap, the Jupiter of the Truk people, there is still a large number of others, in part male, in part female, in part sympathetic, in part unsympathetic. The gods in their customs are often not a bit better than the Truk people themselves. They eat, drink, dance, play, marry, and also perform many a trick which is not at all appropriate for gods. Even Önulap, although the best one in the sky, is a true old Kanaka chief, who lies on his mat in his hut and stares straight ahead. Just like the Truk regions, they have also transplanted in the sky the inhabitants with their good and bad qualities. Is one justified in ridiculing or blaming them, since we have observed the same thing among anciently civilized peoples. Let us look more closely at some of these gods. Semenkoror (father of wisdom) is a brother of Önulap. Human beings are in debt to him for many skills, for which he stands in the highest esteem among all the natives. Silelap (the master), Äremei (achiever), Ämarourou (chatterer), Nugeila[unknown] (the mediator in the sky), Soukuli[unknown], Ororofit, Semoutut (the one not moving). Nothing was to be learned about the activities of these gods individually.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_759_FmTrukL] 'The most unsympathetic one of all is Olfäd (the treader). He was given the name “Treader” because, according to a legend, he is supposed to have produced a great number of small islands near Uman by a step with his foot. That is, a girl whom he wanted to marry reproached him for his poverty, whereupon in anger he trod [Page 8] these islands out of the sea. The most extraordinary things are told about Olfäd. On account of his cunning, his evil tricks, he is unpopular among gods and human beings.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_760_FmTrukL] 'Besides the gods, there is also a large number of goddesses, among whom the two sisters Nisärere and Nipälou are the most interesting. They are regarded as patronesses of the art of weaving and are frequently invoked by the women.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_761_FmTrukL] 'Neanean (the wisher) is a happy goddess. She need only wish for something and it is there immediately.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_762_FmTrukL] 'What Olfäd is among the gods, Inemes (mother of the face) is among the goddesses. Her love potions and love magic confuse all hearts. She is the protectress of lechery, the Venus of the Truk people. Opinions vary concerning her appearance. Some call her ugly, infected with a skin disease; others, as pretty. The latter seems to be the correct one.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_763_FmTrukL] 'Inemes also has a daughter, who has the significant name of Ururupuin (night flirt). With regard to morals she has the same point of view as her mother.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_764_FmTrukL] 'The Truk people think of the sky as inhabited by gods, and the earth, by spirits. Yet all these spirits come from Önulap and are subject to his leadership.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_765_FmTrukL] 'Nigoubub (the procreatress) is a female spirit. She produced earth and human beings at Önulap’s command. The islanders conceive of Nigoubub as a female eel at whose breast the earth rests. When she turns, the earth trembles. That is the Truk people’s explanation for earthquakes. Women who desire children or those who are in labor worship Nigoubub. Nigoubub’s companion is Niro[unknown]epü[unknown] (she who hears the sound). She lives in holes in the earth in the shape of a large crab. She comes out at night and creeps about. The sound of the steps of approaching human beings drives her away. If she bites a person in the foot, he will become deaf. In the säd (3) 3 säd is low water along the land. live the tölöken (4) 4 tol is peak, comb in the case of chickens, dorsal fin in the case of fish. ken = sharp, pointed. [illegible]. They are the creators and rulers of the säd and of the fish living in these quarters. Loubon (he who lives in the interior) is an important tölöken. Weather and typhoons are subject to him.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_766_FmTrukL] 'Creators and rulers of the deep waters are the osen madau (voices of the sea) and the nidudun (female sea-divers). The former are male, the latter female. They are often mentioned in the rales of the seafarers.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_767_FmTrukL] 'On the mountains dwell the notorious osen tuk (voices of the mountains), who have already devoured many a human being. The one called Önun pelien or Resim (5) 5 resim = rainbow. is regarded as the ruler of the rainbow and therefore especially dangerous for seafarers. The rainbow does not evoke any friendly feelings among the islanders, since they consider it a sign of death. Among the women Soumöröges is loved and hated, for the children’s souls are subject to him. He brings them and takes them away again upon the death of the child. Kir is a malicious spirit who dries up the breasts of nursing women.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_768_FmTrukL] 'Spirits, the so-called önunumai (3) 3 önu = spirit, mai = breadfruit. , also dwell in the trees, [Page 14] especially in the breadfruit trees. Säli[unknown]eruu (the two-eared) is a spirit who sows discontent among human beings. Ke de Säli[unknown]eruu, you should not be two-eared, is an admonition frequently given to those who let themselves be influenced by all sides.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_769_FmTrukL] 'Spirits, the önunupun, are likewise found in the earth. All these spirits, whose number is boundless, are more or less forces of nature, phenomena which the natives are unable to explain and therefore ascribe to spirits. The natives imagine these nature spirits in every possible shape. Some are hardly distinguishable from true human beings. Others have long hair all over their bodies and the teeth of a boar. Some have eyes in front and in back, etc. Many islanders [unknown]bstinately maintain that they have seen such beings. They play an important part in the old legends [unknown]and tales. The story of brave men who defeated and rendered harmless such man-eating spirits always excites general applause among the audience. According to the view of the Truk people everything has a soul, even plants and animals. But their souls perish with the matter. The /14/ human being has two souls, a [unknown]unuot and a [unknown]unu[unknown]au, that is, a good one and a bad one, or, better said, a beautiful soul and an ugly soul. The beautiful soul resembles a beautiful person; the ugly soul, an ugly person. The manner of existence of these two souls is different. The [unknown]unu[unknown]au has grown together with the body and cannot leave it during its lifetime. [Page 15] The [unknown]unuot, on the other hand, rests on the shoulder of the person. It is lightly winged, like a bird, and can fly away. But an absence of some time would result in the early death of the person. The natives maintain about insane persons that they no longer have any [unknown]unuot. The Truk people explain dreams by the flying away of the good soul. On Truk “A dreams of B” means nothing but that the souls of A and B have flown away and have met in the gathering of the souls of the deceased. If one frightens an islander so that he starts, he will say: “ A äsilo [unknown]uni,” that is, “my soul has flown away.” When a dying person has ceased struggling, it is said: “ A lo [unknown]unun, his soul has gone away.”'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_770_FmTrukL]
♠ Omnipresent supernatural beings ♣ present ♥ We define "omnipresent supernatural beings" as "all-seeing supernatural beings who are present everywhere and can observe all actions, but can't necessarily read minds or know the intentions underlying actions". The following quote suggests that Önulap was omnipresent in this sense. 'Önulap is the highest of the gods. He is the father of the gods and human beings. Everything comes from him, including illness and misfortune. [...] Önulap also knows everything that human beings do, since a turn of speech runs: “ Si a fadal le mesen Önulap” (we walk in the presence of the great spirit).'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_771_FmTrukL]
♠ Omniscient supernatural beings ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We define "omniscient supernatural beings" as "all-knowing, mind-reading supernatural beings who have access to all socially strategic information." The following quote suggests that Önulap knows all that humans being do, but not necessarily what they think. 'Önulap is the highest of the gods. He is the father of the gods and human beings. Everything comes from him, including illness and misfortune. [...] Önulap also knows everything that human beings do, since a turn of speech runs: “ Si a fadal le mesen Önulap” (we walk in the presence of the great spirit).'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_772_FmTrukL]
♠ Omnipotent supernatural beings ♣ inferred present ♥ 'Önulap is the highest of the gods. He is the father of the gods and human beings. Everything comes from him, including illness and misfortune. Everything is tinien Önulap (fate, messenger of the great spirit). Human beings too belong to Önulap. The Truk people believe that Whites are the first-born, the Blacks, the Kanakas, the younger children of the great spirit. They express this in the following phrase: “ Naun Önulap muänidi re uon, naun /7/ sodubudur kanaka.” Önulap also knows everything that human beings do, since a turn of speech runs: “ Si a fadal le mesen Önulap” (we walk in the presence of the great spirit). The gods and spirits are also subject to Önulap. Whatever they do they do only at his command. Since Önulap stands so high and also does not come down to the uanönu like most of the other gods, his individual worship is rarer. In important matters, for example, in case of war, he is invoked.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_773_FmTrukL] It's not very clear whether Önulap himself punished or rewarded mortals, but it is clear that the gods in general actively intervened in human affairs--though possibly not on the basis of moral principles. 'The natives express the relationship of the önu to the human being and vice versa in the following parallelism: Emen a önubodede, a feiot; emen a önumamau a [unknown]au, “when one is obedient to the önu, then he is happy; but when he is rebellious toward the önu, then he is unhappy.” In other words: For one who obeys the spirits, it will go well; for one who disobeys them, it will go badly. Having everything go well is brought about by the protection of the önu; things go badly because of their inflicting punishment on human beings. Thus, everything adverse in the world is punishment for the violation of the commands or prohibitions which the önu, and especially Önulap, have imposed on h human beings. The Truk people also say about disagreeable events: tinien Önulap, that is, decree of the “Great Spirit.” When an önu punishes a human being, the natives express this in the phrase önu a ku, the spirit has bitten. This “bite” manifests itself in various ways: by the swelling of limbs, stiff neck, maimings, epilepsy, sudden death, etc. The “bites” are regularly directed [Page 29] against a person’s life, which accounts for the fact that the natives are concerned about manau, life, more than anything else. But by life they almost exclusively mean manauen inisit, life of the body, inasmuch as, despite their knowledge of the other world, they have no desire whatsoever to go to the other world.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_774_FmTrukL]
♠ High Gods (creator gods) ♣ active ♥ There is clearly a High God, Önulap. 'Önulap is the highest of the gods. He is the father of the gods and human beings. Everything comes from him, including illness and misfortune. Everything is tinien Önulap (fate, messenger of the great spirit). Human beings too belong to Önulap. The Truk people believe that Whites are the first-born, the Blacks, the Kanakas, the younger children of the great spirit. They express this in the following phrase: “ Naun Önulap muänidi re uon, naun /7/ sodubudur kanaka.” Önulap also knows everything that human beings do, since a turn of speech runs: “ Si a fadal le mesen Önulap” (we walk in the presence of the great spirit). The gods and spirits are also subject to Önulap. Whatever they do they do only at his command. Since Önulap stands so high and also does not come down to the uanönu like most of the other gods, his individual worship is rarer. In important matters, for example, in case of war, he is invoked.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_775_FmTrukL] It's not very clear whether Önulap himself punished or rewarded mortals, but it is clear that the gods in general actively intervened in human affairs--though possibly not on the basis of moral principles. 'The natives express the relationship of the önu to the human being and vice versa in the following parallelism: Emen a önubodede, a feiot; emen a önumamau a [unknown]au, “when one is obedient to the önu, then he is happy; but when he is rebellious toward the önu, then he is unhappy.” In other words: For one who obeys the spirits, it will go well; for one who disobeys them, it will go badly. Having everything go well is brought about by the protection of the önu; things go badly because of their inflicting punishment on human beings. Thus, everything adverse in the world is punishment for the violation of the commands or prohibitions which the önu, and especially Önulap, have imposed on h human beings. The Truk people also say about disagreeable events: tinien Önulap, that is, decree of the “Great Spirit.” When an önu punishes a human being, the natives express this in the phrase önu a ku, the spirit has bitten. This “bite” manifests itself in various ways: by the swelling of limbs, stiff neck, maimings, epilepsy, sudden death, etc. The “bites” are regularly directed [Page 29] against a person’s life, which accounts for the fact that the natives are concerned about manau, life, more than anything else. But by life they almost exclusively mean manauen inisit, life of the body, inasmuch as, despite their knowledge of the other world, they have no desire whatsoever to go to the other world.'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_776_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Supernatural Enforcement of Morality
♠ supernatural enforcement against harm ♣ absent ♥ Based on early 20th century accounts: "The attractive traits, associated with one's mirror image and comprising one's good soul, joined the gods in the sky world, while the unattractive traits, associated with one's shadow and comprising one's bad soul, became a potentially dangerous ghost that did not leave the region of substantive things. ... they pertained to one's place in the cosmos and had little, if anything, to do with a person's psyche (tiip) or with what kind of person one was while living" [MAJIDBENAM_REF_777_FmTrukL]. "The fate of one's good soul after death was not a matter of reward or punishment for good or evil deeds. Its fate in the spirit world depended more on its psychic qualities, as such, than on specific acts." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_778_FmTrukL] People psyches (irresponsible, wise etc.) could determine what happened to their good soul, but this was predetermined and had nothing to do with their actions in life [MAJIDBENAM_REF_779_FmTrukL] However, there is an example of someone using a spirit to kill but it seems a human use of an evil spirit rather than any kind of deterrent to kill an enemy 'The incident begins just after assassins, who sneaked up to his meeting house and poked their rifles through the thatch wall, have shot and killed the chief Mwaatejinyk: “All of the occupants of the wuut fled in panic except for Wenejog... Mwaatejinyk’s grandson. He picked up his grandfather’s body and carried it out of the wuut to prevent its falling into the assassin’s hands. Carrying it down to the north shore of the island, he proceeded west along the rocks on the shore and then climbed back up to... where Mwaatejinyk had lived.... Here Wenejóg buried his grandfather in an upright position leaving his head above ground and facing in the direction of the Pwereka 1 house (his enemy’s lineage center).... He then propped Mwaatejinyk’s mouth open with a stick so that his ghost would go and devour the Mwej people in revenge. This deed earned for Wenejóg a great reputation for bravery” (Goodenough 1951:155-156).'[MAJIDBENAM_REF_780_FmTrukL]
♠ supernatural enforcement of fairness ♣ present ♥ Based on early 20th century accounts: Sky God "'Good Determining' (Oororofich), said to be a brother of 'Father of Determining', was another resident of 'Under Brow'. Concerned with the maintenance of good relations among people, he was angered by theft and other antisocial behaviour." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_781_FmTrukL]. Although not from Chuuk, the same rainbow spirit in the Mortock Islands has been recorded as becoming angry on human conduct at sea (for example taking food reserved for the navigator or other crimes) and requires appeasement when appearing. [MAJIDBENAM_REF_782_FmTrukL]
♠ supernatural enforcement of human reciprocity ♣ present ♥ This is 20th century ethnographic data but has continuity from late 19th century practices: Gods had control of a spirit power that could influence how well other's lives went in terms of work and property. An enuusor was a kind of spirit that could dish out power to mediums with knowledge of sorcery and spells. If one was "effective" in building houses, fulfilling family and social duties etc. they had a better chance of becoming a spirit who could influence the lives of their kin from the afterlife: "A person who appeared to be well above the average in effectiveness might be seen as having a good soul with a better than average chance of becoming an enuusor (effecting spirit)" [MAJIDBENAM_REF_783_FmTrukL]. Based on early 20th century accounts: "When a dead person's soul that was "unworthy" (Bollig's word, presumable for having an inappropriate psychic disposition) approached 'Great Spirit's' house, the two stones clapped together and "killed" it." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_784_FmTrukL]
♠ supernatural enforcement of property rights ♣ present ♥ Based on early 20th century accounts: Sky God "'Good Determining' (Oororofich), said to be a brother of 'Father of Determining', was another resident of 'Under Brow'. Concerned with the maintenance of good relations among people, he was angered by theft and other antisocial behaviour." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_785_FmTrukL]. "A good soul might be angered by failure to pass on to its surviving children a share of the property it held while alive. There was a saying that ... 'one who has been polite to spirits fares well; one who has been disrespectful of spirts fares badly'. Against such illness no medicine was needed. Cure resulted from corrective action taken in regard to the offended spirit. ... local spirits caused illness if one trespassed on their locality." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_786_FmTrukL]
♠ supernatural enforcement of kinship obligations ♣ present ♥ "Quarrels among siblings were most regrettable and could, if serious, bring illness to themselves or their children through the displeasure of their deceased elders." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_787_FmTrukL] This is 20th century ethnographic data but has continuity from late 19th century practices: "There was much talk also of demons and ghosts; and adults made no effort to conceal their own fear of them from their children. Illness was attributed to the malevolence of demons and ghosts. A person was vulnerable to attack by them when he was away from human settlement and was alone. This is frequent reference in Gladwin's data to parents warning children against going off by themselves (Gladwin and Sarason 1953). Good spirits of the dead, whose favor could be helpful, would also punish their living relatives with sickness and death for improper behaviour and ill will among people who were close kin." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_788_FmTrukL] Based on early 20th century accounts: Spirits of the soil could give elephantiasis through biting those who remained on their taro patches too late into the day. There were similar sea and mountain spirits. Also dangerous tree and breadfruit spirits, which required the appropriate propitiatory singing before cutting them down. [MAJIDBENAM_REF_789_FmTrukL] Many dangerous spirits who preyed on pregnant women who went outdoors, eating their foetus and causing miscarriages. Also 'Grabbers' who caused illness and distress to infants who went out late afternoon with their mothers. [MAJIDBENAM_REF_790_FmTrukL] "In any case, surviving close kin did not want to have the good soul of the deceased angry with them for their neglect. Its anger could lead it to inflict illness and possible death on one or more of them. The mourning and bringing of gifts that characterized the proceedings immediately following death were also intended to make the deceased's good soul well disposed to surviving kin." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_791_FmTrukL]
♠ supernatural enforcement of in-group loyalty ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Based on early 20th century accounts: "A medium could also pass on a warning from the spirit that through their conduct people were likely to incur its wrath and endanger their community." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_792_FmTrukL] however, there does not seem to be any examples of supernatural enforcement of loyalty in terms of punishment for a lack of loyalty or support, so punishing a community for one's actions is not enough to code present.
♠ supernatural enforcement of respect ♣ present ♥ This is 20th century ethnographic data but has continuity from late 19th century practices: Political priests called Itang wielded far more spiritual power (Manaman) than others. [MAJIDBENAM_REF_793_FmTrukL] Based on early 20th century accounts: "Miracles were a product of manaman. Ordinary people lacked it. They could obtain access to it by learning the spells that activated recipes and medicines and that offered success in war and other undertakings. Specialists had access to it through the rituals associated with their specialties. Its ultimate source was the spirit world, especially 'Under Brow', it was obtained by humans from 'human god' ancestors and from 'effecting spirits' of the dead through their mediums." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_794_FmTrukL]. "It seems reasonable to infer, therefore, that beliefs about the fate of the soul provided at least some incentive for people to endeavor to be correct in their behaviour to others and, especially, to be obedient to the authority of chiefs, lineage heads, and older siblings of same sex." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_795_FmTrukL]
♠ supernatural enforcement of bravery ♣ present ♥ Based on early 20th century accounts: Bravery was an attribute males needed to show, perhaps like the nearby Namoluk the good souls who died in battle, and were buried at sea, went to the god of war 'Rainbow' (Resiim). [MAJIDBENAM_REF_796_FmTrukL]. In addition, as described above, those who were "effective" (perhaps brave in war) and had a good "psyche" (which included bravery for men) had a higher chance of becoming spirits who could influence the lives of their kin in the afterlife.
♠ supernatural enforcement of purity ♣ present ♥ Based on early 20th century accounts: Sharp Water Spirits could make people ill or "eaten" or "bitten" by the sharp water if they did not follow certain rules, such as playing or swimming too much in the same waters, not abstaining from sexual intercourse or not abstaining from fish food before visiting the reefs where the spirits dwelled. [MAJIDBENAM_REF_797_FmTrukL]. To become a medium one needed to observe taboos on food and abstain from sexual activity to be chosen by a spirit. Spirits can also terminate relationships with mediums if one does not observe the taboos. [MAJIDBENAM_REF_798_FmTrukL]. "During the period of this daily dance, the men who took part in it had to sleep in the meeting house, avoiding having sex. Violation of this restriction would anger 'Lord of South' and result in no breadfruit that year." [MAJIDBENAM_REF_799_FmTrukL]. Heron sickness for those who ate certain foods under sacred trees. [MAJIDBENAM_REF_800_FmTrukL] Based on early 20th century accounts
♠ general supernatural enforcement of morality ♣ present ♥
♠ other supernatural enforcement ♣ present ♥ Based on early 20th century accounts: On the Great Spirit "Everything came from him, including sickness and misfortune. ...
