Consistent with this are the reports from surrounding atolls, but not from the Chuuk itself, that 'Great Spirit' held in his hands the life threads of living persons. These threads were connected to the tops of people's heads. If 'Great Spirit' disapproved of a person's behaviour, he or his mother tore the thread, and the person died (Damm and Sarfert 1935:192; Kramer 1937:150-151, 279) [MAJIDBENAM_REF_801_FmTrukL]. Based on early 20th century accounts of nearby Namoluk, even if not Chuuk Islands it may be relevant: "It is reported from Namoluk that there the souls of people who had "sinned" in life were not admitted to the sky world but were taken by 'Stamper' to a "place of damnation" called Leenchiichi (sic), chiichi being the name of a tree whose sap causes burning irritation to one's skin. There they were cast into a great hole, called 'Sea of Muck', where they remained unable to move. (Girschner 1912:192)" [MAJIDBENAM_REF_802_FmTrukL][MAJIDBENAM_BR]Human Enforcement of Morality
♠ care/harm ♣ absent ♥ It appears that bravery and cleverness were valued over care/harm and fairness/cheating norms in conflict situations: 'By fleeing from the youth’s attack, N.P. showed himself to be a person of cowardice as well as arrogance. T. E. demonstrated bravery both in the stick test and in stabbing N.P. despite the fact that he tricked him and stabbed him from behind. T.E.’s behavior is acceptable partly because sportsmanship is not prominent in the ideal of bravery once a conflict has begun. The ideal is to have sympathy for others, and to care for them, until a conflict develops, “and then people are very sorry”. When a fight begins today, any available weapon is immediately used. In traditional warfare, sneaking by night into another district and cutting the throats of the sleeping enemy was considered clever strategy.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_803_FmTrukL] 'When a drunken young man burst into the district meeting house swinging a machete, the women and two of the men present ran away from him to the other side of the building. One man, S.O. stood up and stayed where he was. After failing to intimidate S.O. by swinging at him with his weapon, the intruder turned and left. During the next few days gossip flared. The two men who had fled were condemned for their cowardice while S.O. was praised. As people commented, “To the person of bravery it is completely taboo that another should see his back, to him it is better to die than to run.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_804_FmTrukL] 'Another way of insulting someone is to claim that he is afraid of someone else, perhaps of a particularly tough person in another district. Accusations of arrogance are especially common in arguments, for they provide justification for attack as well as insult. Expressions such as “I despise your arrogance” ( wúwa fóókkun opwut namanan tekiyomw) are standard. The aggressive response is “So what?” ( meyit?) or some counterattack on the other’s character. The backing down response is “Forgive me please” ( omwusaanó ááy tipis) with some excuse. To insult a man for weak thought one may say “Go wear women’s clothes” ( achchék or wúféwúf wúfen feefin).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_805_FmTrukL] However, attitudes varied betwen islands in the colonial period (see bravery below). We have provisionally coded 'absent', but this obscures the variation found in the colonial period.
♠ fairness/cheating ♣ absent ♥ It appears that bravery and cleverness were valued over care/harm and fairness/cheating norms in conflict situations: 'By fleeing from the youth’s attack, N.P. showed himself to be a person of cowardice as well as arrogance. T. E. demonstrated bravery both in the stick test and in stabbing N.P. despite the fact that he tricked him and stabbed him from behind. T.E.’s behavior is acceptable partly because sportsmanship is not prominent in the ideal of bravery once a conflict has begun. The ideal is to have sympathy for others, and to care for them, until a conflict develops, “and then people are very sorry”. When a fight begins today, any available weapon is immediately used. In traditional warfare, sneaking by night into another district and cutting the throats of the sleeping enemy was considered clever strategy.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_806_FmTrukL] 'When a drunken young man burst into the district meeting house swinging a machete, the women and two of the men present ran away from him to the other side of the building. One man, S.O. stood up and stayed where he was. After failing to intimidate S.O. by swinging at him with his weapon, the intruder turned and left. During the next few days gossip flared. The two men who had fled were condemned for their cowardice while S.O. was praised. As people commented, “To the person of bravery it is completely taboo that another should see his back, to him it is better to die than to run.”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_807_FmTrukL] 'Another way of insulting someone is to claim that he is afraid of someone else, perhaps of a particularly tough person in another district. Accusations of arrogance are especially common in arguments, for they provide justification for attack as well as insult. Expressions such as “I despise your arrogance” ( wúwa fóókkun opwut namanan tekiyomw) are standard. The aggressive response is “So what?” ( meyit?) or some counterattack on the other’s character. The backing down response is “Forgive me please” ( omwusaanó ááy tipis) with some excuse. To insult a man for weak thought one may say “Go wear women’s clothes” ( achchék or wúféwúf wúfen feefin).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_808_FmTrukL] However, attitudes varied betwen islands in the colonial period (see bravery below). We have provisionally coded 'absent', but this obscures the variation found in the colonial period.
♠ in-group loyalty ♣ present ♥ The in-group coincided with the kin group. Society was organized in matrilineal clans: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_809_FmTrukL] 'Kinship terms are few. A generational mode of reckoning is skewed in a Crow manner so that all members of one's father's lineage are in a senior generation, children of men of that lineage are in one's own generation, and children of men of one's own lineage are in a junior generation.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_810_FmTrukL] Lineage endogamy was not permitted: 'All the Truk people are divided into eila[unknown] (kin groups / Sippen/). The mother is bearer of the eila[unknown]. In any case this is connected with the doctrine of Nigoubub, who, as the origin of life, is also female. All children follow the eila[unknown] of the mother. Marriage within the same eila[unknown] is not permitted. A Witö woman may never marry a Witö man. Such a marriage is regarded as incest and is never permitted, even if the common ancestors of the loving couple lie many generations back. On the other hand, marriages between uncle and niece, male cousin and female cousin, father and stepdaughter are not rarities, as long as the eila[unknown] is different. Marriages within the same eila[unknown] were formerly punished by death. Even now this [Page 89] marriage is still detested, even among Christians. I was acquainted with a single case, and the common judgment was: “The man is bad, for he married his sister.” One inquires about the eila[unknown], for example, in the case of women, “ fin med en? (Woman, what sort are you?),” whereupon the answer comes, for for example, “ fin Witö.” For men, the question runs, “ muan meden? (Man, what sort are you?).”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_811_FmTrukL] Ties to members of one's own lineage were important: 'Within its district each lineage owns a particular plot of land which is regarded as its “true home” or “lineage center” ( imweyiche). The dwelling houses of resident members are typically clustered at this site, and members living elsewhere frequently return here to visit. Persons residing at the lineage center will include some genealogical members of the lineage plus other people who have current links to resident members. Typically some of these will be persons of the same district while others will be members of other districts and occasionally of other islands.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_812_FmTrukL] Individuals had obligations to their own lineage as well as affinal lineages: 'More than one lineage is important to an individual on aanakkar. He automatically has pressing obligations to serve others in his own lineages, and he has strong rights to demand support from them in return. He also has lesser but important rights and obligations to members of his father’s lineage and to members of his spouse’s lineage (for a man this will also be the lineage of his children). Finally he has minor obligations to his father’s father’s lineage and to his spouse’s father’s lineage.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_813_FmTrukL]
♠ respect for authority ♣ present ♥ Humility was valued on some islands, but not others, possibly as a result of Christianization: 'These two styles of social interaction seem to be associated with a difference in character values. In writing about Romónum culture in the modern period, ethnographers never mention the ideal of strong thought, and although there are brief allusions to bravery it is not presented as a significant ideal. The literature on Romónum does refer, again and again, to the other major character value we found on Fáánakkar, the importance of mosonoson, which is translated as “humility” or “respectfulness” as opposed to namanam tekiya, which is translated as “haughtiness” or “arrogant behavior”. Given these translations of the value labels and the examples furnished, it appears that the meanings of these terms are similar on Romónum and Fáánakkar.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_814_FmTrukL] But respectfulness was generally valued, although it may have been interpreted differently in different contexts: 'It is expected that people will despise a person of arrogance and that there will be much hostile gossip about him. The resulting shame has driven a number of persons to suicide. Because they hate him, it is also assumed that people will eagerly seek a chance to do him in, and that he will become a target for “foul play” ( sorongngaw). This term refers to sorcery and other stealthy aggressive acts such as ambush and arson. Elders frequently warn younger kinsmen who are acting rudely to be more respectful, lest they meet an early death. Another [Page 51] person’s failure to offer even a single required word of respect is sometimes considered adequate justification for using sorcery against him. Conversely, respectfulness is universally praised. It is also assumed that other people will feel sympathy towards such a person and treat him, in turn, with kindly respectfulness.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_815_FmTrukL] Chiefs were owed gifts in produce, given their status as 'symbolic' landowners: 'As noted above, the relations between a chief and the people of his district are patterned largely after the relations between the parties in divided ownership. As provisional title holders to territory, the various lineages owe the chief periodic gifts of produce from the land. These gifts are rendered at stated times in connection with feasts given in the chief’s honor. He fixes the time for these feasts in accordance with a seasonal calendar: two feasts during the breadfruit season, and two more during the turmeric season. The men of the various lineages prepare breadfruit in giant wooden bowls while the women fish. Other types of food are also collected. On the day of the feast each lineage brings its food in a procession, the men carrying the giant bowls on frames and chanting as they walk. The food is carried into the meeting house of the chief’s lineage. The chief then selects the largest bowl for himself and his lineage mates and redistributes the rest of the food to the assembled population. The distribution is made according to lineage and is roughly proportional to the size of each lineage. The contributions which each lineage makes are also proportional to the size of its membership and the amount of productive land which it controls. If a lineage fails in this obligation, the chief has the right to confiscate its holdings. Should he indicate dissatisfaction with the contribution of a particular lineage, its members will hasten to prepare additional food and other gifts to mollify him.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_816_FmTrukL] Chiefs were owed respect: 'Everyone who was not a consanguineal or affinal relative of the chief was heavily “taboo from setting himself above” him. This involved saying “ fääjiro” as an expression of respect on meeting a chief. If further required that one crouch or crawl in the chief’s presence if he was seated, for it was forbidden to have one’s head on a higher plane than his. One avoided initiating social interaction with a chief, unless the need was urgent, in which case one made him a gift and then waited the chief’s pleasure. One could not persist in refusing a chief’s request without being guilty of namanam tekija (arrogant behavior), nor could one address him harshly or belligerently. For persons other than his relatives, a chief occupied the most heavily taboo status with respect to behavior of this kind. (The other categories of persons who shared this status with the chief were jiuag and pwëny (navigators).) His consanguineal and affinal kinsmen, however, behaved toward him in accordance with the status positions which he occupied as their kinsman, at least as far as their being “taboo from above” him was concerned. Other formalities were also accorded a chief. When he walked along a path with a party of people, he went first, unless the path was difficult. In the latter event someone went ahead to clear the way. While crawling behavior and the expression “ fääjiro” are no longer exhibited, a chief still walks first today and the people still feel themselves to be “taboo from above” him.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_817_FmTrukL] Younger siblings had to respect older siblings, and sisters had to respect brothers: 'Younger siblings must obey and respect their older siblings of the same sex. Nor is this obedience and respect a matter of theory only. It is strictly observed in practice, and anyone failing in this is severely censured. Similarly sisters must obey and respect their brothers regardless of their relative age in years, provided only the brothers are past the age of puberty. A sister who consistently fails to do so is virtually disowned by her brothers, who no longer concern themselves about her welfare.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_818_FmTrukL]
♠ purity ♣ present ♥ Marriage within the kin group was not permitted and apparently considered impure: 'There are not many obstacles to marriage on Truk. Under all conditions marriage within the same kin group is absolutely forbidden (totemism), even if the common root goes back ten degrees. For various kin groups marriage is not permitted, for relatives of the first degree, and, to be sure, in the direct line and collateral line. Therefore marriages between father and daughter, mother and son, and brother and sister are [Page 108] regarded as reprehensible. In this connection adopted siblings and half siblings are regarded as true siblings. It very often happens, however, that a man who marries a widow with an adult daughter takes the latter as a second wife. That is regarded as entirely proper. I have known of one single case in which a Truk chief married his own daughter and had several children with her. The natives frown upon such illegal marriages. They call them, rather crudely, pupulun pig (pig marriage).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_819_FmTrukL] 'All the Truk people are divided into eila[unknown] (kin groups / Sippen/). The mother is bearer of the eila[unknown]. In any case this is connected with the doctrine of Nigoubub, who, as the origin of life, is also female. All children follow the eila[unknown] of the mother. Marriage within the same eila[unknown] is not permitted. A Witö woman may never marry a Witö man. Such a marriage is regarded as incest and is never permitted, even if the common ancestors of the loving couple lie many generations back. On the other hand, marriages between uncle and niece, male cousin and female cousin, father and stepdaughter are not rarities, as long as the eila[unknown] is different. Marriages within the same eila[unknown] were formerly punished by death. Even now this [Page 89] marriage is still detested, even among Christians. I was acquainted with a single case, and the common judgment was: “The man is bad, for he married his sister.” One inquires about the eila[unknown], for example, in the case of women, “ fin med en? (Woman, what sort are you?),” whereupon the answer comes, for for example, “ fin Witö.” For men, the question runs, “ muan meden? (Man, what sort are you?).”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_820_FmTrukL] Some activities caused uncleanness: '1. An unclean person is one who has stepped into sonepuin (1) 1 son = sediment, dregs; puin, night. The soiling can easily happen during nocturnal wanderings on the beach, which the Kanakas use as a toilet. The uncleanness lasts two, four, six, or eight days. During this time the one concerned must refrain from all religious acts. He himself can choose the number of days in proportion to his repentance and his zeal in the worship of the spirits. But it is expressly required that it must be an even number of days or nights, since the odd numbers are unfavorable.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_821_FmTrukL] 'An unclean person is one who has already partaken of food. They express this defect with the words u a olokon, which corresponds somewhat to our “ ich bin nicht mehr nüchtern” /I am no longer fasting/.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_822_FmTrukL] '3. An unclean person is one who has had sexual intercourse, no matter whether marital or extramarital, since the natives make no distinction in this. This defect is designated with the expression u se oloudd, that is literally, I have not slept in the udd (men’s house). Namely, one must consider the fact that no woman was allowed to enter the udd in olden times. Therefore the men who stayed there overnight could not have sexual intercourse. For that reason the expression “to sleep in the udd” means the same as to be continent. Standing in contrast to oloudd is olaim. It means to sleep in the im (dwelling), therefore, to have sexual intercourse.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_823_FmTrukL] This was associated with spiritual dangers and misfortune: 'This oloudd is also a condition for other activities, as well as in connection with offerings, probably because they are subject to the influence of the spirits in a special way. It is required: If the men are obliged to be continent for one of the reasons mentioned above, this does not hold eo ipso for the women as well. They remain completely untouched. One can imagine what bad effects this practice, praiseworthy in itself, must have on family life during a long period. Only in the case of the weierek do the women on some islands also seem to be obligated to be continent. For example, if a man has bad luck because sharks spoil his fishing, he accuses his wife as though she were to blame for it on account of her incontinence. Other islands, on the other hand, deny the obligation of the women.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_824_FmTrukL] 'The people have a great fear of violating these binin. Anyone who violates a binin incurs the penalty of the revenge of spirit concerned, the one that issued it. He becomes feienau. This is the punishment that the people of Truk abhor. They have little understanding for moral defect. One who commits a bad deed and [Page 42] thereby becomes feienau has “sinned.” One who does not fall into this has not committed a sin. That in general is the principle of all Truk people. The conception of sin in the Christian sense is lacking among them. The term dibis that they have now was introduced from the outside and is identical with the above-mentioned feienau, according to the view of the natives.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_825_FmTrukL] Pregnancy, childbirth and menstruation were also considered unclean: 'As long as the child is small, the mother remains free of all work. She does not go fishing and in general does nothing other than merely sit with the child. But nobody will reproach her for it. Her husband brings her food, which is especially made for her ( mo[unknown]o ew fam), since she is still considered unclean. But he is not allowed to stay with her and eat with her as long as the child is not okotap, that is, turns on the mat independently.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_826_FmTrukL] 'The woman who is menstruating or pregnant has something unclean, contemptible, about her. She is isolated from the others; no one who holds a “religious position” as ida[unknown] may enter the little dwelling, prepare her food, or eat anything intended for her. The prohibition ends when the condition does.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_827_FmTrukL]
♠ kinship ♣ present ♥ The in-group coincided with the kin group. Society was organized in matrilineal clans: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_828_FmTrukL] 'Kinship terms are few. A generational mode of reckoning is skewed in a Crow manner so that all members of one's father's lineage are in a senior generation, children of men of that lineage are in one's own generation, and children of men of one's own lineage are in a junior generation.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_829_FmTrukL] Lineage endogamy was not permitted: 'All the Truk people are divided into eila[unknown] (kin groups / Sippen/). The mother is bearer of the eila[unknown]. In any case this is connected with the doctrine of Nigoubub, who, as the origin of life, is also female. All children follow the eila[unknown] of the mother. Marriage within the same eila[unknown] is not permitted. A Witö woman may never marry a Witö man. Such a marriage is regarded as incest and is never permitted, even if the common ancestors of the loving couple lie many generations back. On the other hand, marriages between uncle and niece, male cousin and female cousin, father and stepdaughter are not rarities, as long as the eila[unknown] is different. Marriages within the same eila[unknown] were formerly punished by death. Even now this [Page 89] marriage is still detested, even among Christians. I was acquainted with a single case, and the common judgment was: “The man is bad, for he married his sister.” One inquires about the eila[unknown], for example, in the case of women, “ fin med en? (Woman, what sort are you?),” whereupon the answer comes, for for example, “ fin Witö.” For men, the question runs, “ muan meden? (Man, what sort are you?).”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_830_FmTrukL] Ties to members of one's own lineage were important: 'Within its district each lineage owns a particular plot of land which is regarded as its “true home” or “lineage center” ( imweyiche). The dwelling houses of resident members are typically clustered at this site, and members living elsewhere frequently return here to visit. Persons residing at the lineage center will include some genealogical members of the lineage plus other people who have current links to resident members. Typically some of these will be persons of the same district while others will be members of other districts and occasionally of other islands.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_831_FmTrukL] Individuals had obligations to their own lineage as well as affinal lineages: 'More than one lineage is important to an individual on aanakkar. He automatically has pressing obligations to serve others in his own lineages, and he has strong rights to demand support from them in return. He also has lesser but important rights and obligations to members of his father’s lineage and to members of his spouse’s lineage (for a man this will also be the lineage of his children). Finally he has minor obligations to his father’s father’s lineage and to his spouse’s father’s lineage.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_832_FmTrukL]
♠ bravery ♣ present ♥ Bravery was valued on some islands, but values differed between islands: 'When the people of Fáánakkar talk about character and valuables, they assume certain definitions and rules, but they [Page 160] also typically retell or allude to a set of standard illustrative stories in which the rules are encoded. That is, each value label conjures up in people’s minds a series of basic images embodied in a stock of stories about people who behaved with extraordinary bravery, arrogance, or strong thought. Sometimes these stories are based on the semi-legendary exploits of people in the old days ( e.g., the story of how C.J. killed the outer island sorcerer or the tale about the arrogance of N.P., and how he was stabbed by the wronged chief’s nephew). Other stories involve the dramatic behavior of people in the community today ( e.g., accounts of major boundary disputes, knife fights, sorcery battles, and sumptuous feasts). The situations and events in these stories provide a person with standards for measuring the conduct of other people and guidelines for behaving.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_833_FmTrukL] 'Ideal character is not defined this way on Fáánakkar. Respectfulness is a major value there but, as we have seen, it is balanced by an equally heavy emphasis on the aggressive and competitive ideals of bravery and strong thought. None of the accounts of modern Romónum, including the life histories, give any indication that these two character values are major preoccupations on that island. It also appears that acts which would be seen as manifestations of bravery on Fáánakkar are [Page 173] viewed as arrogant on Romónum, while actions which could be defined as cowardice on Fáánakkar are viewed as respectful on Romónum. Swartz shows that it is not only inappropriate or unjustified aggression that is considered wrong on Romónum, all aggression is defined as “haughty” (1958:475). Fighting with kinsmen is very bad, fighting with outsiders is less bad, but fighting is haughtiness (1965:32) and “all ‘haughty’ behavior is bad” ( Ibid.:32). One exception is wife beating, “when a woman violates the proscriptions on ‘haughty behavior’ or is disobedient, her husband may beat her” (1958:472) but “these values (of humble or nonhaughty behavior) also apply to men and combine with the threat of divorce to limit overt aggression against his wife” ( Ibid.:473). In all other relationships, even when someone has grossly violated the norms in a haughty way, aggressive retaliation is not approved; “even the punishing of a criminal is seen as aggressive or haughty” (1965:33). In short, on Romónum, “the cultural norm categorically proscribes aggression” ( Ibid.:38). Clearly this is not true on Fáánakkar where people want to be, and want to be known as, persons who are capable of successful aggression. On Fáánakkar the ideal type, the person of “true bravery”, does not usually engage in unjustified or unprovoked aggression (although he shows he is capable of it) but he must be ready and eager to respond competitively and aggressively when challenged, especially by another’s arrogance. To remain humble in the face of another’s challenge is not respectfulness; it is cowardice, and on Fáánakkar, this is despised at least as much as is arrogance.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_834_FmTrukL] This may be the result of Christianization. Caughey claims that bravery and fierceness were universally valued on Truk prior to colonization: 'However, on Romónum it appears that neither the exclusive stress on respectfulness, nor the “prohibition of aggression” (Swartz 1965:37), nor the unaggressive style of social conduct were characteristic prior to the German pacification of Truk in 1903. In the 19th century, the people of Truk as a whole were considered highly aggressive in comparison to those of other areas in Micronesia. “As is well known, 19th century whalers and other travelers avoided Truk because of its reputation for belligerency toward outsiders, and within the atoll itself warfare was frequent. Although the Spanish held title to Truk from 1885 to 1889 and theoretically administered it [Page 174] from their base at Ponape, they actually did not govern the island. The bellicose nature of the people of Truk was a factor in the Spanish avoidance of the area” (Swartz 1965:17). My information about warfare on 19th century Fáánakkar clearly fits this picture as do the reports of Germans who lived on Truk in the early 20th century. “Truk was one big battlefield. Island fought against island, tribe against tribe. On one day two villages were co-operating; on the next day they were fighting each other. There was constant killing in an ever changing situation” (Bollig 1927:104). Evidently aggressiveness was also common on 19th century Romónum. In tracing the history of Romónum from 1850 to 1903, Goodenough notes that the history begins with a fight, and his account shows that it was permeated by assassinations, bloody feuds, sorcery battles, and warfare with neighboring islands (1951:148-161). Gladwin and Sarason (1953:41) provide additional supporting evidence. It also appears that this aggressive behavior was associated with an ideal of bravery similar to that on Fáánakkar. An example from Goodenough’s history of Romónum will illustrate this point. The incident begins just after assassins, who sneaked up to his meeting house and poked their rifles through the thatch wall, have shot and killed the chief Mwaatejinyk: “All of the occupants of the wuut fled in panic except for Wenejóg... Mwaatejinyk’s grandson. He picked up his grandfather’s body and carried it out of the wuut to prevent its falling into the assassin’s hands. Carrying it down to the north shore of the island, he proceeded west along the rocks on the shore and then climbed back up to... where Mwaatejinyk had lived.... Here Wenejóg buried his grandfather in an upright position leaving his head above ground and facing in the direction of the Pwereka 1 house (his enemy’s lineage center).... He then propped Mwaatejinyk’s mouth open with a stick so that his ghost would go and devour the Mwej people in revenge. This deed earned for Wenejóg a great reputation for bravery” (Goodenough 1951:155-156).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_835_FmTrukL] 'On Romónum, Fáánakkar, and most of the other Truk islands overt aggression was characteristic throughout the 19th century and an aggressive style of behavior has persisted, in [Page 175] modified form, on Fáánakkar and at least some of the other Truk islands. On Fáánakkar, the traditional values of bravery and strong thought have also persisted, and along with respectfulness, they are still important measures of character. On Romónum overt aggression has very much declined, and the aggressive and competitive components of bravery and strong thought are no longer prominent. It also appears that a shift in the meaning of these terms may have taken place such that several classes of behavior encompassed within the traditional ideal of bravery are now condemned as arrogance. In fact, Swartz believes that the people of modern Romónum “consider all the warfare that went on before foreign control to have been ‘haughty”’ (1965:32).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_836_FmTrukL] According to Gladwin, scarification was displayed as a sign of bravery: 'In recent years, such mutilation has been confined almost exclusively to burning with a lighted cigarette; only older persons show any other type of scar. The cigarette is held just touching the skin of the man’s arm by his partner until a burn has been made, and the operation repeated until four, six, or sometimes eight such burns have been made in a double row down the upper arm on either side. The man, of course, makes no outcry before his love and properly should appear unaware even that it hurts. The burns blister immediately and are highly conspicuous. No new scars were observed on women during our stay on Romonum, as might be expected in view of the fact that they were all married with one exception (who was reported by some informants to be hostile toward men), but very few indeed of the older women had scars either, indicating that the practice is at any time rare for a woman. Burning has always been used for this purpose; prior to the introduction of long-burning imported cigarettes by the Japanese this was done by igniting the punk-like dry powder found in dead breadfruit stumps and produced a less neat scar. More commonly small parallel incisions were made with a knife on the man’s arm; a conspicuous scar was often later assured by rubbing dirt into the wound to increase the amount of scar tissue. It is significant that when one informant was describing this practice to Dr. LeBar, he added that identical cuts were made [Page 112] by a man on his own arm to show his bravery and thus intimidate his opponent just prior to a fight. The only mutilation confined to women in this context is a scratch on the cheek, inflicted by the lover with a long sharp thumbnail. Men formerly kept one thumbnail long for this purpose, although again there was also a relevance to fighting for this long nail was useful in slicing an adversary’s eye. No such scratches were observed and informants stated that this no longer takes place; one youth, however (who had no burns on his arm), cherished a long sharp thumbnail but would not divulge its purpose. He simply said he liked it that way.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_837_FmTrukL] Accordingly, we have provisionally coded 'present', although this obscures the ideological variation seen in the colonial period.
♠ respect for property ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Property offences included theft, trespass and failure to pay obligations, but these issues were traditionally dealt with through retaliation, not formal punishment: 'There are three main ways in which the property rights of others may be infringed on Truk. The first is theft or the deliberate destruction of another’s property. The second is trespass. The third is default in one’s obligations as a provisional title holder or as the recipient of a loan or niffag. To refuse a kiis to a wife’s brother is more a breach of marital than of property relations.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_838_FmTrukL] 'In aboriginal times no formal action was taken by the community against a thief. It was up to the individual and his corporation (lineage) to collect damages or kill the offender, the latter action frequently leading to a feud with the offender’s lineage. If the identity of a thief was unknown, divination was resorted to in order to discover it. The injured party demanded restitution or payment. If the thief refused, a fight resulted. District chiefs did not interfere directly in such matters. Informants indicated that for them to do so would have been to court the enmity of the entire community. On the other hand, a chief used to preach to his people about the evils of stealing and exhort them to respect each other’s rights in order to hold down dissension within his district.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_839_FmTrukL] 'Trespass applies to two types of situation. The first has to do with entering another’s house without permission. Such action is construed as motivated by a desire to steal something, to leave an object which will sorcerize its occupants, or, if at night, to commit adultery. Its occurence is bound to precipitate, if not a fight, at least bad relations with the occupants of the house.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_840_FmTrukL] 'The other type of trespass consists of entering a section of lagoon or a plot of land on which a “no trespass” sign has been placed. Such a sign is made by tying a young coconut leaflet on a stake in the water or around the trunks of trees. This is called röög (not to be confused with roog, magic). A man may put a röög sign on his property if he is going to be away from his district on a protracted visit. It is (or at least used to be) customary when someone dies for his relatives to put a röög sign on his coconut trees and fishing areas. It may be that this action provides a “cooling off” period before settlement of his holdings. In any case, it serves notice on members of the community that trespass will be construed as an insult to the memory of the dead and will be done at the risk of one’s life. After a few months such a röög is lifted ceremonially, and the property is taken over by the proper heirs. Informants denied that the violator of such a taboo sign on property incurs any penalties of supernatural origin. Violation involves only the risk of having open season declared on one’s life by the property holder and/or his lineage mates.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_841_FmTrukL] Troublemakers could also be socially isolated by their lineages: 'One might assume that dependence on private sanctions for breaches of this kind would provide a situation in which powerful persons and lineages could take advantage of weaker ones. While this has happened, the entire community is likely to unite against a too frequent offender. The property system does not depend, however, on the threat of direct retribution alone. Trouble makers tend to be socially isolated. Even their own lineage mates may eventually withdraw support if their activities too frequently put the lineage in embarrassing situations. These less formal sanctions are usually effective, and a person or group is not likely to violate another’s property rights deliberately and openly except with the definite purpose of precipitating a show-down.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_842_FmTrukL] Sorcery was employed to fight thieves, at least in the past: 'Sorcery is a more direct if more secret form of aggression and is practically precluded from being applied within the lineage by the fact that the spells used are in each case the property of a given lineage. While it is not clear whether they would be considered effective, it is very doubtful that they would be used against others who knew them or could be expected to know them. Data on sorcery are difficult to obtain for no one admits to being a sorcerer. Those cases of afflictions (blindness, psychosis, and paralysis) which were definitely attributed to a given sorcerer always applied to someone on another island, angry because his wife had been taken away, his property trespassed upon, or the like. Although various people on Romonum were said to know certain techniques of sorcery and many people expressed a fear of being sorcerized, no one would say that a given person had actually sorcerized anyone. The detailed body of knowledge of procedures in sorcery which exists and the circumstantial accounts of how it was formerly used certainly suggest very strongly that in the past Trukese deliberately sorcerized other Trukese. Whether this is the case today, however, is an open question. In the past [Page 150] it was used by master magicians, both against rival magicians and against the laity, and was also used in the punishment of thieves; but then as now sorcery was primarily the result of one person’s animosity against another and as such acted as a sanction against acts which might antagonize another. Thus anxiety about sorcery is another factor weighing the balance in favor of conformist behavior.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_843_FmTrukL] 'Even more common than the uwuli aramas is the uwuli ton solä (roasting of thieves). If somebody has had something stolen, he goes to the souatömen so that the latter will help him take revenge on the thief. The souatömen now does the following: [Page 84] He takes a fishing pole and line, ties a small crab to it, sits down in the grass, and sings. In this song he now mentions the names of all those who are suspected of the thievery. As soon as he pronounces the name of the culprit, a kinom or kuen (dark, ugly leguan) jumps out of the grass and bites into the crab. The souatömen seizes the animal, breaks all its bones, and roasts it in a coconut shell. The thief now pines away and must die. But again it is in the hands of the souatömen to put an end to this harsh sentence if the client wishes it in a fit of pity. He rubs the “roasted one” with a protective safei, and the spell is lifted.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_844_FmTrukL] Dogs and traps were also used: 'For protection against nocturnal thieves, many Truk people have dogs which are supposed to alarm the occupants of the huts by their barking. /126/ in order to make the animals really mad and snappish, they take shark and hake’s teeth, pulverize them, and mix them with the dog food. Yet experienced thieves do not let themselves be intimidated even by that. They know how to distract the attention of the dogs and to get into the hut on the side against the wind. To do away with annoying dogs by means of poison and ground glass is also not unknown to them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_845_FmTrukL] 'A better means of protection against thieves than dogs is the averet. This is ray spines or pointed sticks [illegible] in the ground with the tip upward. Whoever steps on them carelessly may tear open the entire sole of the foot.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_846_FmTrukL] According to Goodneough, the possibility of theft was a major source of anxiety although individuals generally respected each other's property rights: 'The possibility of stealing seems to arouse considerable anxiety in the Trukese today as well as formerly, and this despite the fact that they scrupulously respect each other’s rights when in anyone else’s company. They seem always ready to attribute the worst of motives to their fellows.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_847_FmTrukL] But Caughey writes that stealing openly was considered as a sign of fierceness and bravery: 'To steal openly from others is admirable in that it shows a person’s dominance and demonstrates that he is not intimidated by the aggressive powers of others.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_848_FmTrukL] Destroying another's property in revenge was common: 'The Truk people are a little nation that always knows how to twist things so that one’s own self does not come out short. Just because everybody thinks only of himself and wants to have everything, damage in material connections is the most sensitive for them. Whoever wants to take revenge on another and deal him a blow need only do some kind of damage against him and he is stricken. That is why damage to houses and canoes, felling trees, uprooting young plants, and killing domestic animals out of a thirst for revenge so frequently occur.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_849_FmTrukL] The material reviewed is contradictory. Expert input may be needed to resolve this.
♠ Moralistic punishment by human religious agents ♣ absent ♥ absent/present/unknown. As a result of missionary activities, Christianity spread quickly in the 20th century: 'After 1900 Christianity became well established in most major centres in Micronesia. For the most part, traditional religions ceased being practiced in their full original form, although in Yap and some atolls of the central Carolines, traditional religion continued to be practiced until the middle of the 20th century. Missionaries and travelers recorded descriptions of certain aspects of the island religions, but there is no complete and systematic account.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_850_FmTrukL] However, we have coded for the 'traditional' religion. The literature makes it clear that the Chuukese believed that transgressions could be punished by supernatural beings [MAJIDBENAM_REF_851_FmTrukL]. It's worth noting that incest was punished [MAJIDBENAM_REF_852_FmTrukL]--though it's not clear by whom. eHRAF provides a general description of ritual specialists: 'Ritual practices were conducted by their own specialists. They included spirit mediums, breadfruit summoners, fish summoners, healers, masters of spells, masters of sorcery, builders, navigators, diviners, and most importantly the masters of magic and ritual relating to war and politics. Their knowledge was private property passed down to their children and junior lineage mates.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_853_FmTrukL] Spirit mediums were important, but we have found no evidence of them being involved in moralistic punishment: 'In the space of this work we shall consider only the direct residing, which manifests itself in the belief in the nanönu / uanönu/. It is to be recalled that, according to the views of the islanders, the spirit which has appeared at the invocation of the spirits takes up residence on the far. The uanönu is in the service of this far and the spirit sojourning on it. He makes the far, hangs it up, tends to the asor, calls the spirit to jump down from it and settle on his neck. In this condition he speaks with the spirit, asks him questions in the spirit language, presents to him the people’s wishes, and also receives many a revelation. The common people prefer to have recourse to the uanönu in their religious needs. All the spirits, except for Onulap, seem ready to jump down, but especially those of the most recently deceased. The uanönu like to see the souls of deceased children coming down to them, because they have the advantage of being wenewen, that is, sincere, while adults are even able to deceive the uanönu. Some uanönu asserted that never yet had the soul of a deceased Christian come down to them. Anyone /61/ men, women, boys, girls, can be chosen as uanönu or uomar, that is, canoe of the spirit. The choice is wholly at the discretion of the spirit.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_854_FmTrukL] 'As soon as someone in the tribe has died, the people gather and tempt the soul so that it will settle down on the far and choose one of the persons present as uanönu. If the spirit grants this plea, the one chosen is regarded as uanönu until the spirit leaves him again. If the people have a request about which the spirit is to give information, he is summoned. The uanönu is the medium. The summoning takes place amid certain ceremonies. At night the people gather in the udd in which the far is hung. A quantity of food and other objects is collected, in part as asor [Page 68] for the önu, in part as gifts for the uanönu, in order to make them both obliging. Then the dancers grasp the kurukur and dance the spirit dance ( dugia), in order to show the spirit their veneration. The uanönu lies calmly on his mat and waits for the right moment. He suddenly feels as though goose flesh were spreading over him. He jumps up, takes hold of the kurukur, and jumps about, while he shouts hi, hi... It is not long before he feels by the heaviness of his neck that the spirit is sitting on him. He stands still, begins to tremble, bends under the weight of his neck, and sometimes even begins to foam. He presses his lips together hard so as not to speak quickly, since he might easily falsely announce the spirit’s words because of hurrying too fast. Finally the people call to him: “ Wäsi me[unknown]inom, tell your revelations.” The uanönu now asks the spirit: “ E seiö, who are you?” (In ordinary speech: en iö?) Whereupon the spirit begins to talk. The people pose their questions, express their wishes, which the uanönu communicates to the spirit in spirit language and receives the answer in the same language. The summoning is not always done in this fussy manner. Some uanönu are so easily susceptible that it suffices to strike them on the arm with an ubud, and they begin to tremble.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_855_FmTrukL] 'The performance does not always turn out as desired. It might be that the spirit who settles down is an “ onu[unknown]au or önurot, which the people notice at once by the furious, wild behavior of the uanönu. Then they quickly hide everything dangerous, such as knives, fire, etc., so that the uanönu cannot cause a disaster for anybody, for it has often happened, as the natives asserted, that such a raging one /62/ threw all kinds of things at the heads of those present and ran after them with bush knives. If, on the other hand, the uanönu speaks calmly and softly, the people are delighted, for the spirit is an önusor. Unfortunately, however, the revelations not infrequently turn out to be wholly a fraud. Then the natives grumble about the false uanönu and önumaken (liar spirit), but they do not so quickly lose faith in the business. Next time it will turn out better.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_856_FmTrukL] 'The uanönu also has the privilege of seeing the souls of human beings and the spirits in dreams. Thus an uanönu in Param told me one he had seen at night, while sleeping, a number of spirits in the middle of the island, as they danced together. The soul of a man who was still living was also present. That could become dangerous for the poor fellow, however, because how easily might the fickle soul stay away entirely, and then he would have to die. Therefore, as soon as a native hears that a dreaming uanönu has seen his soul, there is nothing more urgent for him to do than to wrap up a few good things, go to the uanönu, and ask him if he would catch again the one that escaped. That is, the uanönu also knows this art. It is called ama[unknown]un. The uanönu makes a certain safei, pours it into a coconut shell, and looks in. All the souls that have flown away now gather in this safei and look like drops of blood. He fishes out the foreign souls by means of a sou and throws them away. The soul of the petitioner, however, remains. The uanönu gives the safei with the captured soul to the unfortunate one to drink and he goes away beaming with joy. He has his soul back and need not die yet, while the uanönu has the gifts. Envious souls on Truk say about the uanönu that they see the most at precisely those times when their chests are the emptiest.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_857_FmTrukL] 'There is still another kind of uanönu, called mo[unknown]epui. These indeed see the human souls that have flown away, but do not understand the art of getting them back. They do not play any role among the Truk people.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_858_FmTrukL] 'The uanönu has another task during the performance of the spirit dances. The uanönu stands with the safei in the middle of his rows of dancers. This spot is called poönu, that is, bed of the spirit. No one may crowd close to this place. When the procession goes to the dancing place, the uanönu goes before his tribe, his blow-shell in one hand, giddun, /63/ that is, coconut offering for the spirit, in the other. When he steps into the udd, he throws down the coconut. He stations himself wherever it falls, and his dancers crowd around him. He gives them some of the safei to drink, so that the evil sorcery of the troops of dancers and their leaders will not harm them. Then [Page 70] he rubs his shell with curcuma and puts it down with the opening upwards. While the troop is dancing, the uanönu of the other party does all kinds of sorcery in order to disturb the dance. He likewise takes his shell, rubs it with charcoal, and puts it down with the opening downwards. His companions tie an ubud around their necks as a sign for the dancers that they should hang themselves. It now depends on which of the two parties can practice better sorcery. The defeated party is put to shame during the dance. The dancers’ voices fail.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_859_FmTrukL] 'A number of binin surround the uanönu. Besides the above-mentioned ones, which also hold for most of his ro[unknown] colleagues, he is not allowed to eat apot or oranges. The people must be careful not to sneeze in his presence, for the spirits do not like that. If the uanönu wants to get rid of his spirit -- which is not at all rare -- he only need bathe in stinking apot water, and the spirit will no longer come to him.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_860_FmTrukL] 'There are a great many of these uanönu on Truk. On the island of Fefan, which numbers scarcely 2,000 people, there are more than 90 of them, some of whom still practice their profession. Although these uanönu do not have the authority of the ida[unknown], they still sincerely contribute their share in supporting heathen customs and practices and keeping the spirit cult alive. Many a movement toward Christianity in tribes still heathen was suppressed by the intrigues of the uanönu. Although, on the one hand, many a former uanönu, men and women, came over to Christianity, on the other hand, it was precisely the uanönu still practicing who were the most obstinate opponents of the faith, even more than the ida[unknown].' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_861_FmTrukL] Other ritual specialists were associated with warfare and politics: 'During the battle the ida[unknown] is near his men. If he wants to see the fighting ended, he throws himself between the lines of the ones fighting and cries, “ e bue le iou,” whereupon the warriors reply, “ e bue le iou (it shall be finished),” and the fighting stops. Anyone who does not obey this call is “bitten” by the ida[unknown] and is killed in the next battle. If there are people of the ida[unknown] who were killed in the battle, they may not be buried immediately, because the ida[unknown] must first inspect their position. Namely, if one lies with his feet toward the region of the enemy, as though he wanted to give him a kick, then there are no difficulties about the burial. But if it is the opposite, then the ida[unknown] first has to bring the corpse into the proper position. While singing, he pushes and turns the dead until his feet fortunately have the desired direction. Only then may his comrades carry him away. As respected as the ida[unknown] is by his own party, so is he hated by the opposite party, since they not unjustly attribute the war to his intrigues. If he falls into the hands of the enemy, he is tortured alive in front of the enemy soönu.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_862_FmTrukL] These specialists employed sorcery to retaliate against their enemies and people who slighted them, but we have found no evidence of third-party moralistic punishment: 'The ida[unknown] are also masters in the sphere of sorcery. Their word is regarded as puitikar (hot), which means destructive. An ordinary bite of the ida[unknown] causes a swollen throat. A curse cast by him on an unfortunate person devours the latter’s soul, that is, his life.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_863_FmTrukL] 'The occasion for this curse is the anger of the ida[unknown] because the careless so-and-so is so disrespectful as to make noise in his vicinity. It is no wonder that the people are afraid of a man who has such power in his mouth. Yet it is to be added for the vindication of the honor of the ida[unknown] that he also possesses various safei which end the effects of the bites and curses. Good pay, however, is a preliminary condition.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_864_FmTrukL] Sorcery was a common means of retaliation: 'What embitters life most for the Truk natives is the boud (sorcery to harm one). The boud occurs in innumerable forms. Nearly all souro[unknown] know how to make the boud with the help [Page 83] of their önu; the ida[unknown] in particular is a feared souboud. Yet there are also very distinct souboud who, with the help of an önu[unknown]au, are able to bring all kinds of trouble to human beings. How often one can hear from sick people the words: “ Emen a boud [unknown]eniei, somebody has cursed me, bewitched me.” The boud prevents women from giving birth, disturbs children’s growth, makes limbs swell, spoils one’s work, steals the [unknown]unuot, and brings inevitable death. Fear of the boud is a true tyranny for the unhappy, heathen Truk people.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_865_FmTrukL] 'A radical boud is the uwuli or umuni aramas (roasting human beings). If the souboud cannot get at a person whom he hates, he will kill him symbolically, which soon has as a consequence his actual death. For this purpose he sends his wife into the lölö to search for “his fish” ( iken ro [unknown]). The fishing women know the meaning. As soon as they have caught the fish, they lament the person condemned to death. They bring the fish to the souboud, who breaks the backbone bends it everywhere, and then roasts it. He buries the roasted fish or secretly puts it under the cursed person’s sleeping mat. The fala[unknown] (cookhouse) in which the act has taken place is abandoned and no longer used in the future, because the curse clings to it.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_866_FmTrukL] 'The person concerned, however, the one who was sentenced to death in this fashion, still has a chance to escape his fate if he learns about the boud soon enough. He simply has himself /75/ “roasted” again by a souro[unknown], whereby the first “roasting” is neutralized. The souro[unknown] makes a hole in the ground in the house of the person concerned, puts the counter- safei in it, and covers it with hot stones so that it steams. Over this he spreads coconut fronds together with the sleeping mat of the “patient.” The latter now has nothing else to do but to lie on it for a time. The boud is destroyed by this simple method, and the threat to life removed.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_867_FmTrukL] 'Even more common than the uwuli aramas is the uwuli ton solä (roasting of thieves). If somebody has had something stolen, he goes to the souatömen so that the latter will help him take revenge on the thief. The souatömen now does the following: [Page 84] He takes a fishing pole and line, ties a small crab to it, sits down in the grass, and sings. In this song he now mentions the names of all those who are suspected of the thievery. As soon as he pronounces the name of the culprit, a kinom or kuen (dark, ugly leguan) jumps out of the grass and bites into the crab. The souatömen seizes the animal, breaks all its bones, and roasts it in a coconut shell. The thief now pines away and must die. But again it is in the hands of the souatömen to put an end to this harsh sentence if the client wishes it in a fit of pity. He rubs the “roasted one” with a protective safei, and the spell is lifted.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_868_FmTrukL] 'In former times the natives hardly dared walk across the sandy shore, for the footprints impressed in the soft sand could easily bring about their ruin. If a souboud saw the prints of someone hated by him, he lifted them up, put them in a bowl, and cooked them together with a certain safei. If the sorcery was successful, the feet and legs of the person in question would swell.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_869_FmTrukL] 'Jealous women likewise sometimes let themselves be carried away and have recourse to the boud. For example, if a mother sees that the child of her neighbor is growing better than her own, she makes the safeien usiwör, and the bewitched child will become a cripple.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_870_FmTrukL] 'The soumaram ( maram, moon) is feared as a sorcerer. In the opinion of the Truk people he has a mysterious connection with the moon. When the moon appears in the west ( sikauru, first quarter) the natives do not dare pronounce the moon’s name in the presence of the soumaram. /76/ Instead of “a li[unknown]maram, the moon shines,” they say, “ a war ewe samol, that chief appears,” since the moon is the chief of the night.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_871_FmTrukL] 'Some souboud also have a method for harming people by throwing a sorcery- safei into people’s land or house at night. The most suitable nights for this are those between the first quarter and full moon, and, to be sure, toward morning. The souboud wraps his head, throat, hands and feet with ubud and, swaying his body back and forth while singing, he approaches the house. As a precaution, however, he has a few precious things [Page 85] with him as pen manauan (ransom). Namely, at the time of the boud the occupants of the houses are on the lookout in order to catch a possible souboud. He now hopes, in case he should be detected in his dirty work, to savelhimself from punishment by means of gifts. This does not always seem to succeed, however, for on many islands it is told how such souboud would be paid their reward with the bush knife. The souboud also has a method for recognizing whether his sorcery is effective against a given house or not. He pours safei into a bowl, puts some glowing stones into it, and inoffensively passes the house in question. If the steam of the safei goes toward the house, the boud will be successful; if not, he must repeat it.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_872_FmTrukL] However, this does not seem to constitute third-party moralistic punishment. Clarification on the difference between retaliation and punishment is needed.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Type of punishment this typically entailed (can be more than one):
♠ physical punishment ♣ present ♥ It appears that troublemakers were killed prior to colonization, at least occasionally. This included people who committed incest: 'All the Truk people are divided into eila[unknown] (kin groups / Sippen/). The mother is bearer of the eila[unknown]. In any case this is connected with the doctrine of Nigoubub, who, as the origin of life, is also female. All children follow the eila[unknown] of the mother. Marriage within the same eila[unknown] is not permitted. A Witö woman may never marry a Witö man. Such a marriage is regarded as incest and is never permitted, even if the common ancestors of the loving couple lie many generations back. On the other hand, marriages between uncle and niece, male cousin and female cousin, father and stepdaughter are not rarities, as long as the eila[unknown] is different. Marriages within the same eila[unknown] were formerly punished by death. Even now this [Page 89] marriage is still detested, even among Christians. I was acquainted with a single case, and the common judgment was: “The man is bad, for he married his sister.” One inquires about the eila[unknown], for example, in the case of women, “ fin med en? (Woman, what sort are you?),” whereupon the answer comes, for for example, “ fin Witö.” For men, the question runs, “ muan meden? (Man, what sort are you?).”' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_873_FmTrukL] This was discontinued in the colonial period, but offenders could be sentenced to labour: 'Another weak point of the chiefs is partiality. Members of the chief’s kin group, blood relatives, and friends are not readily punished, not even for serious crimes. On the other hand, poor devils whom the chief cannot bear are sentenced to hard labor for the slightest reason or are reported to the government as “disobedient ones” or “rebels.” In the old days the Truk chiefs did away with troublesome persons by means of the knife; today they do it by means of lies and false denunciations.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_874_FmTrukL] Some sources claim that chiefs gained more power to punish offenders in the colonial period, but the precise character of these sanctions is unclear: 'A greater apparent gain from the presence of foreign power is the chief’s ability to punish those who offend against the community. Although there is an independent judiciary, on Romónum, at least, the division of labor is not very clear, and the chief spends a good deal of time considering the enforcement of laws passed either by his own island legislature or by the yearly assembly of chiefs of all the islands in the atoll.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_875_FmTrukL] 'It might seem that interlineage political structure gained strength through the addition of power to punish deviants and prosecute offenders, but if we are to judge by the effectiveness of this force as customarily used, it does not make a major contribution to political organization by outside domination.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_876_FmTrukL] We have provisionally treated forced labour as a form of physical punishment.
♠ exile ♣ absent ♥ Goodenough mentions the case of a man who fleed his island during a feud, but this was not exile in the sense of formal punishment: 'Remaining in the older house were two sisters, Nijeejice, who was married to Cëëppywn (P3a), and Nijeejinen, who was married to Mwaatejinyk (P2a). In the feud between Pwereka 2 and Pwereka 3a following the murder of Jöku, Cëëppwyn and Mwaatejinyk were on opposing sides, and the former was eventually forced to flee Romonum, going to live for a time on Moen. When Mwaatejinyk became island chief he gave his children the plots of Neemwëc (720-470), Neeceemej (420-460), Neejimwetä (390-450), and Neeram (460-490), and built a house for his wife and daughters at Neeceemej, thereby establishing the Söör 2a descent line. Full or residual title to the soil of these plots is now considered the property of this descent line. When Cëëppwyn returned from exile, he gave his children the land plot Neejöör (540-470), where he, too, built a house for his wife and daughters, who founded the present Söör 2b descent line. All three descent lines continued to operate as a single lineage with one wuut—the old one at Fënykytiw was moved to Neetupw (580-350)—and one fanag, forming an over-all corporation holding full or residual title to the old sööpw lands collectively called Pwowunög.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_877_FmTrukL]
♠ loss/seizure of property or wealth ♣ present ♥ Wronged spouses could demand compensation from adulterers: 'As long as the adultery is secret, nobody does anything about it. But as soon as it comes into the open, the one or the other deceived marital partner causes an uproar and deserts the unfaithful one, although he himself perhaps does the same thing in secret. But there are many married couples who do not even get excited about such “little things.” They discuss the case very calmly, since now they have a double reason to repay unfaithfulness with unfaithfulness, and no harm can be done to them. But I have heard that in a few cases the deceived wives took revenge on their husbands by suddenly breaking off during the next coitus, which caused an injury to the men, as a result of which they died. According to native law the insulted husband can demand compensation from the seducer of his wife. In order that no hostility arise between the families on account of the payment, however, the sinning woman likewise gives compensation to the wronged wife of her seducer. Thus equilibrium is established again. If the culprit cannot pay the compensation ( fes) by himself, the other relatives must contribute clothing, knives, necklaces, fishing nets. Houses, land, and canoes may serve as a basis for the fees.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_878_FmTrukL] Prior to colonization, adultery was also dealt with through blood vengeance, but this was discontinued in the colonial period. However, forced labour was still practiced: 'In olden times war often arose as a result of such adultery. The insulted husband sought revenge by killing the seducer. In more recent times the guilty wife was also punished by the chief and sentenced to forced labor. But the measure had little success. As soon as the adulteress seems to repent, /97/ everybody has pity on her, her husband first of all. She is pardoned [Page 105] again, a good meal is prepared for her, and everything is forgiven and forgotten. These sores on Truk marriage can be healed, not by external force, but by awakening the moral sense through Christianity.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_879_FmTrukL] Lineages that failed to pay obligations to chiefs had their property confiscated: 'As noted above, the relations between a chief and the people of his district are patterned largely after the relations between the parties in divided ownership. As provisional title holders to territory, the various lineages owe the chief periodic gifts of produce from the land. These gifts are rendered at stated times in connection with feasts given in the chief’s honor. He fixes the time for these feasts in accordance with a seasonal calendar: two feasts during the breadfruit season, and two more during the turmeric season. The men of the various lineages prepare breadfruit in giant wooden bowls while the women fish. Other types of food are also collected. On the day of the feast each lineage brings its food in a procession, the men carrying the giant bowls on frames and chanting as they walk. The food is carried into the meeting house of the chief’s lineage. The chief then selects the largest bowl for himself and his lineage mates and redistributes the rest of the food to the assembled population. The distribution is made according to lineage and is roughly proportional to the size of each lineage. The contributions which each lineage makes are also proportional to the size of its membership and the amount of productive land which it controls. If a lineage fails in this obligation, the chief has the right to confiscate its holdings. Should he indicate dissatisfaction with the contribution of a particular lineage, its members will hasten to prepare additional food and other gifts to mollify him.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_880_FmTrukL]
♠ loss of status ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on chiefs being demoted or deposed, although this cannot be ruled out entirely. Expert input is needed.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Extent of punishment (can be more than one):
♠ punishment of rulers ♣ absent ♥ Chiefs often punished 'commoners', but not their own kin or allies: 'Another weak point of the chiefs is partiality. Members of the chief’s kin group, blood relatives, and friends are not readily punished, not even for serious crimes. On the other hand, poor devils whom the chief cannot bear are sentenced to hard labor for the slightest reason or are reported to the government as “disobedient ones” or “rebels.” In the old days the Truk chiefs did away with troublesome persons by means of the knife; today they do it by means of lies and false denunciations.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_881_FmTrukL]
♠ punishment of elites ♣ absent ♥
♠ punishment of commoners ♣ present ♥

Economic Well-Being[edit]

State Intervention in Economy
♠ The state regulates banking ♣ inferred absent ♥ Note: Prior to colonization, the Chuukese economy was subsistence-based: 'In the past, swidden gardens with dry taro, turmeric, and sugar cane were few and small. Breadfruit, supplemented by wet taro, was the staple. Being seasonal, breadfruit was preserved by fermenting in pits. Copra has become the only export. Fishing was important.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_882_FmTrukL] 'Traditionally, men gardened, cooked and processed food in bulk (in the earth oven), did deep-water fishing, engaged in war and public affairs, and practiced the arts of canoe and house building and of wood, shell, and stone working. Women wove, plaited mats, prepared meals (as distinct from food in bulk), did inshore fishing, and took main responsibility for child care.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_883_FmTrukL] 'Traditional crafts included: making outrigger paddle canoes; building houses; woodworking (to make bowls, storage chests, spears); gardening; cordage (to make rope, string, slings); working stone (for sling stones), shell (for adz blades), and coral (for breadfruit pounders); preparing medicines; loom weaving with hibiscus and banana fibers (to make loin clothes, wraparound skirts, shirts, mosquito canopies); plaiting (of baskets, mats); and other leaf working (for thatch, sun hats). Sewing arts and dressmaking have replaced weaving.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_884_FmTrukL] Some trade schools were established in the colonial period: 'A further step on the educational ladder was eventually provided with the establishment of a trade school for carpenters at Koror, Palau, a thousand miles to the west. Promising graduates of the higher elementary schools were selected from all over the mandated territory to attend this school. Later a small agricultural school was established on Dublon Island, Truk, and, after the Japanese started to alienate “undeveloped” native land for colonization, a surveyor’s school was established in Palau.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_885_FmTrukL] Economic 'development' was interrupted during the World Wars: 'While the militarization of Truk, which was to prove a disatrously inadequate bastion for the Japanese in the second World War, changed the emphasis of Japanese [Page 45] development of the islands, it served merely to accelerate the processes of change in the Trukese society initiated earlier by the economic development program which of course continued but on a lesser scale. But with the beginning of the air strikes against Truk in 1944, and the blockade which followed, the fruits of the Japanese efforts at economic development were destroyed and the necessity of supporting some 35,000 foreigners in addition to the almost 10,000 Trukese off the land resulted in a serious depletion of their resources. Intensive cultivation of sweet potatoes made unfit for use many acres of good gardening land, and the extensive use of explosives in fishing, as well as the underwater explosion of many aerial bombs and mines, depleted the fish population to an extent which is felt to the present day. While there are still plenty of fish, they are not as numerous in any one place, and therefore harder to catch.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_886_FmTrukL] Commercial fishing was introduced in the colonial period. Goodenough's comments seem to imply that further economic diversification only emerged under American administration: 'Okinawans developed commercial fishing during Japanese rule; and some commercial fishing on a small scale was continued by the Chuukese after World War II. Under American rule, the principle source of cash income was government employment as teachers and program administrators. Tourism was unimportant.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_887_FmTrukL] 'Men and women have both entered into school teaching, clerical work, and administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_888_FmTrukL] 'New arts include motor maintenance (of cars and outboards); boat building; bookkeeping; school teaching; government administration; and nursing and medical practice.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_889_FmTrukL] We have assumed that in the colonial period, the number of native petty officials and craftsmen was very small, with most islanders remaining in subsistence horticulture. Accordingly, some of the below variables might not apply to the colonial-period Chuuk islands.*******Money was introduced by the colonial administration: 'The impact of these economic changes upon the Trukese was great. Just as under the Germans law and order were made the province of the administration, a step which can be reversed (without chaos) only by a long and intelligently directed course of evolution, so under the Japanese the step to a money economy and dependence upon some categories of imported goods was carried far enough beyond the German beginnings so that it too has become irreversible. While the Trukese were not indoctrinated in the more skilled techniques, such as deep-sea fishing and boat-building, there were many jobs available at manual labor, an ever-increasing flow of trade goods upon which to spend the earnings thereof, and head taxes to assure that those who did not work cut copra. The Trukese began to travel more and more on Japanese boats (many of which they have now taken over and operate), to use a wider variety of Japanese tools, to eat (although not depend upon) rice and canned fish, and to wear clothese exclusively of foreign material.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_890_FmTrukL] Marshall, writing in the 1970s, describes banks in urban centres: 'The district’s oldest and largest commercial complex—Truk Trading Company (TTC)—has been joined in recent years by a number of modern air-conditioned stores selling everything from hardware to imported food to clothing and locally made handicraft (figures 3 and 4). Prominently displayed on the shelves of most of these stores is a wide array of imported alcoholic beverages. Scattered among these stores and government offices are four small, locally owned hotels, two of which run popular bars; the district’s radio station (WSZC); two local produce markets; the Bank of America; and the U.S. Post Office, complete with its own Zip Code. Also located downtown are a large public elementary school, the boat pool, several churches, and a variety of housing ranging from tropical-palatial to ghettolike. The downtown streets are paved, and most persons who live downtown have electricity and running water.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_891_FmTrukL] It is unclear from his description when banks were established for the first time. Swartz seems to imply that Chuukese households often stored money and wealth items in their homes: 'In strictly interpersonal disputes between spouses, the wife’s brothers often side with the husband. One morning I heard a young man shouting at his wife that she had lost the key to the locked box she shared with him. (Everyone has a box that can be locked, in which prayer books, money, or other valuables are kept.) As I approached the house, the woman rushed out carrying her infant daughter and followed by her husband, who was brandishing a machete. He shouted “You are very disobedient,” and struck her across the chest with the flat of the machete. The woman staggered back and began to wail that the baby had been cut. Her brother, who was with me, ran to her and began shaking her. “See the price of your disobedience!” he told her. The brother explained afterward that his sister was not virtuous ( mirit) and that she “drove everyone crazy.” The woman’s brothers must also protect a man’s marital rights with their sister if the husband fulfills his obligations to them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_892_FmTrukL] Accordingly, we have assumed that savings schemes were absent prior to WW II.
♠ Price controls ♣ ♥ See above.
♠ Regulations against hoarding/stockpiling goods ♣ ♥ See above.
♠ Regulations regarding usury ♣ ♥ See above.
♠ Debt-relief measures ♣ ♥ See above.
♠ Pensions ♣ absent ♥ See below.
♠ Standardization of weights/measures ♣ inferred absent ♥ Prior to colonization, islanders employed no formal system of weights and measures. Bollig claims that in house construction, materials were measured by eye rather than abstract standards: 'The method of construction of the udd is the simplest imaginable. Four mighty corner posts ( ur) are driven into the ground, on which longitudinal beams ( dilöu) extending across are set and lashed. On the longitudinal beams rest the crossbeams (outam), and, to be sure, in the case of larger udd, three of them, the thick one in the middle. Into the crossbeams are inserted small posts, on which then directly rests the heavy ridge-beam ( uin), which, like all beams, consists of one piece. The beams are not nailed since the old Truk people were unfamiliar with iron. They took wooden pegs or tied the beams together with coconut cord, which can hold for decades. The modern Truk people do use nails. Finally, the rafters are put up and lashed, and the framework is completed. One might think that this work would be done quickly, but far from it, for the natives have to be always changing and turning so that the house will not be crooked and humpy. They are not familiar with measuring instruments; everything is done by eye. Although some udd are beautifully and precisely constructed, nevertheless nothing of true art is to be noted, for it would have to be the rafters, which are crudely notched here and there and even more crudely painted with black, white, or red paint.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_893_FmTrukL] Volume was measured in 'handfuls': 'These linear measures are also used in part as dry measures insofar as the people put the finger or the hand into the bowl and thus determine the height from the ground. The hand too is a dry measure; epö is a handful.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_894_FmTrukL] So far, no information on weights has been found. However, Bollig mentions some linear measures: 'These linear measures are also used in part as dry measures insofar as the people put the finger or the hand into the bowl and thus determine the height from the ground.
