The hand too is a dry measure; epö is a handful.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_895_FmTrukL] 'They are not all alike in style either. Every island and also every important canoe-builder ( soufalafal) have their own style ( sän). The word sän means rope, because in hewing the keel, /129/ which has considerable influence on the usefulness of the canoe, the measuring is done with a piece of rope. The cances are differentiated according to the method of measuring. Thus, one distinguishes sänin Ku (old name for Mortlock), sänin Poluot, säniged, etc.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_896_FmTrukL] While colonial administrators probably employed their received weights and measures, we are unsure how quickly these became common usage among the Chuukese. We have provisionally assumed that informal measurements remained common throughout the colonial period.
♠ Guarantee stability of coin value ♣ present ♥ Prior to colonization, Chuukese exchange systems were not monetized. Islanders traditionally engaged in trading expeditions and barter trade: 'At the present time, sailing canoes suitable for long trips remain in use only in the small islands of the Caroline group scattered widely over the ocean from Truk westward. The language and culture found on these islands relate them clearly to Truk, whereas most of them fell historically under the hegemony of Yap to the west—a tie which Lessa (1956) has demonstrated is by no means completely extinct. Both Truk and Yap possess volcanic soils which can support crops impossible of cultivation on the sandy coral islets which lie between. Trade therefore provided the impetus for travel to and from the high islands, and there was in addition considerable social visiting back and forth between all the islands. Some voyages, apparently of exploration, have also been recorded extending over hundreds of miles to Guam and even remoter islands. Trips of up to 200 miles or so are still made, although with reduced frequency. Canoes are also used on a few islands other than those mentioned above for interisland, but essentially local, travel to Truk and Ponape.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_897_FmTrukL] 'The acquisition of property on Truk is usually done by means of barter. Lands, houses, and canoes are bartered. Smaller units of exchange are sebi (wooden bowls), deig (curcuma), faupar (red shell disks), hip mats, modesty bands, fishing nets, aromatic oils, coconut cord, home-grown tobacco, and sleeping mats. These products of native industry are not present in like quantity or in like quality on all the islands. Thus, Sapesis on Fefan is famous for its fine bowls, Pol for curcuma and oils, Iluk for its fine hip mats.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_898_FmTrukL] 'Weaving generally takes place at certain times, especially when the canoes from the low islands are expected, the inhabitants of which barter for things. In former times not very nice [Page 186] customs were associated with weaving. When the women had completed their work, they put on the new mats and gathered on the shore.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_899_FmTrukL] Money was introduced by the colonial administration: 'The impact of these economic changes upon the Trukese was great. Just as under the Germans law and order were made the province of the administration, a step which can be reversed (without chaos) only by a long and intelligently directed course of evolution, so under the Japanese the step to a money economy and dependence upon some categories of imported goods was carried far enough beyond the German beginnings so that it too has become irreversible. While the Trukese were not indoctrinated in the more skilled techniques, such as deep-sea fishing and boat-building, there were many jobs available at manual labor, an ever-increasing flow of trade goods upon which to spend the earnings thereof, and head taxes to assure that those who did not work cut copra. The Trukese began to travel more and more on Japanese boats (many of which they have now taken over and operate), to use a wider variety of Japanese tools, to eat (although not depend upon) rice and canned fish, and to wear clothese exclusively of foreign material.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_900_FmTrukL] But barter continued into the colonial period: 'As a result of the German, Japanese, and American administrations, the natives have become thoroughly aware of the value of money in relation to specific situations. It is needed to pay taxes and is required for the purchase of goods from local retail outlets. Money is in fairly wide use in native transactions, though barter continues as the more practical form of exchange. Two informants, for example, had no trouble in estimating the cash price of a coconut tree (if not old) at $2.00 and that of a breadfruit tree at $5.00, a big one fetching perhaps as much as $10.00. Sales of trees are, however, fairly rare. If they should become more common, one might predict that the price would rise to accord with their economic importance. As the present prices suggest, money plays no part in the domestic food economy. It is needed to purchase food by only a handful of natives. Except for them, money is treated simply as an important sort of movable property ( pisek). One may make a niffag of money, trade it for goods or for labor, and have it appropriated by one’s wife’s brothers as a kiis.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_901_FmTrukL] In this case, the variable refers to German and Japanese currencies which were introduced to Chuuk in the colonial period. Accordingly, we have assumed that this variable applies here.
♠ Public markets ♣ present ♥ Commercial fishing was introduced in the Japanese period, but apparently limited to foreigners at the time: 'Okinawans developed commercial fishing during Japanese rule; and some commercial fishing on a small scale was continued by the Chuukese after World War II. Under American rule, the principle source of cash income was government employment as teachers and program administrators. Tourism was unimportant.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_902_FmTrukL] But Bollig implies that some form of market exchange was present in the colonial period, as evidenced in cash cropping: 'Little lul is made on the Truk Islands, out of fear of evil sorcery, so the people say. So much the better is it understood by the inhabitants of the small low islands of Mortlock, Poluot /Puluwat/, etc., where the old men in particular try to make themselves useful by the twisting of lul. The cord comes on the market in large, carefully wound balls, which often contain several hundred [unknown]af. One hundred [unknown]af form esän, that is, a rope. The value of the esän is about one mark, which is not too much, considering the work. In former times even cheaper coconut cord was available.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_903_FmTrukL] 'A type of cultivation which was vigorously pursued in ancient times, but which is now dying out through the influence of the Europeans, is that of the curcuma ( efen or also äfän). The curcuma fields are nicely hoed and free of all weeds. When the tubers have ripened, they are dug up, washed clean, and prepared. Out of superstition the preparation is done only when the moon is waning, probably because the time of the waxing moon is the time of sorcery. /147/ The tubers are grated and strained through a spread piece of cloth ( tôtô), and the water collected in a bowl. The fine, yellow substance (son) now settles here. It is poured into coconut shells, cooked over a fire, and pressed into forms. Now it is called deig and comes on the market.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_904_FmTrukL] More detail is needed.[MAJIDBENAM_BR]Contracts
♠ State enforcement ♣ ♥ We are unsure whether the colonial administration enforced contracts among Chuukese parties. It appears that colonial courts dealt with litigation, but these disputes might have been based on informal agreements and conventions rather than formal contracts.
♠ Non-state enforcement ♣ ♥ So far, we have found no material on contracts per se. But even prior to colonization, senior lineages and dominant clans could grant residential and usufruct rights to junior groups on a provisional basis: 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_905_FmTrukL] Individuals could also grant provisional land rights to other individuals: 'Land was held privately both by individuals and matrilineal, corporate descent groups. Rights in undeveloped space, productive soil, trees and gardens were separable. When soil and breadfruit trees were given in grant, the grantor retained residual rights and the grantee acquired provisional rights. Grantors and grantees could be either individuals or corporations. Full rights went to the survivor on the death or extinction of the other.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_906_FmTrukL] We are unsure whether this constitutes a contract according to our Code Book. Chiefs occasionally confiscated property granted to junior lineages and provisional title holders in case of disobedience (such as failure to deliver food prestations on the occasion of feasts): 'As noted above, the relations between a chief and the people of his district are patterned largely after the relations between the parties in divided ownership. As provisional title holders to territory, the various lineages owe the chief periodic gifts of produce from the land. These gifts are rendered at stated times in connection with feasts given in the chief’s honor. He fixes the time for these feasts in accordance with a seasonal calendar: two feasts during the breadfruit season, and two more during the turmeric season. The men of the various lineages prepare breadfruit in giant wooden bowls while the women fish. Other types of food are also collected. On the day of the feast each lineage brings its food in a procession, the men carrying the giant bowls on frames and chanting as they walk. The food is carried into the meeting house of the chief’s lineage. The chief then selects the largest bowl for himself and his lineage mates and redistributes the rest of the food to the assembled population. The distribution is made according to lineage and is roughly proportional to the size of each lineage. The contributions which each lineage makes are also proportional to the size of its membership and the amount of productive land which it controls. If a lineage fails in this obligation, the chief has the right to confiscate its holdings. Should he indicate dissatisfaction with the contribution of a particular lineage, its members will hasten to prepare additional food and other gifts to mollify him.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_907_FmTrukL] Clarification is needed before a coding decision can be taken.
♠ Corporate Agency ♣ absent ♥
♠ State contracting ♣ absent ♥
♠ Limited Liability ♣ absent ♥Patronage
♠ within-class formal patronage ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of patronage relations. More material may be needed.
♠ between-class formal patronage ♣ absent ♥
♠ within-class informal patronage ♣ absent ♥
♠ between-class informal patronage ♣ absent ♥

Public Goods[edit]

♠ Famine relief ♣ inferred absent ♥ Bollig claims that no communal provisions were made for the case of famine: 'Although the natives have sufficient food supplies in normal times, or could have, nevertheless times of famine are not unfamiliar to them. Causes of famine might be a typhoon or a long drought. A lack of rain for three to four months can be disastrous for the islands, since, with the thin layer of humus, all the plantings /166/ die. In such times of famine many cases of death always occur; the families broke up, because everybody was only concerned with saving his own skin. The people cut down the coconut trees and ate the heart (faunepon), which resulted in the death of many. There was no longer any order. Looting theft, and murder were the order of the day. Especially clever ones carried soil onto very high trees and raised some tobacco there.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_908_FmTrukL] 'An old saying gives the following advice for a famine: “ nugu sebi, nugu neif, nugu lul. Protect the bowl, the knife, the coconut cord.” That is, one who has a bowl can make himself mogemog (arrowroot) when other foodstuffs are exhausted. This mogemog grows wild in great quantities and, although the Truk people like to eat it, is hardly noticed because it requires too much work. But anyone who also has the other two things besides the bowl, he can climb the coconut palms, cut the blossom stalk, fasten a bowl to it, and thus procure for himself the fortifying palm wine. This gives him a chance to struggle through until better times come.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_909_FmTrukL] Islanders relied on crabs and bitter yams in times of famine: 'When fishing is unsuccessful due to unfavorable weather, famine prevails in the huts of the Kanakas, and many a person is hungry and mournfully hangs his head. Others,on the other hand, who are more courageous, roam through the mangrove swamps for mussels or look for crabs in the crab holes on the shore. As bait they hold a fern frond in the crab hole. When the crab seizes the fern with its claws, they quickly pull it out. The natives know very well how to grasp the animal in such a manner that they cannot be pinched by the claws.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_910_FmTrukL] 'Yam The yam (Dioscorea sp.), termed eep, is rarely used as a food. According to informant Kekkin on Romonum, this plant was formerly cultivated. The bitter yam, Dioscorea bulbifera, grows wild and is used only as a famine food.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_911_FmTrukL] LeBar mentions other 'famine foods': 'Marginal, or famine, foods including: heart of palm (eeryk), Dioscorea bulbifera (pwereka), Ipomoea gracilis (ruke), Ficus tinctoria (jöwöön), Ipomoea digitata (jeteniten).' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_912_FmTrukL] According to Mahony, Cyrtosperma was stored in swamps for use in times of famine: 'A large number of varieties of Colocasia and Cyrtosperma are recognized but there are only a few varieties of Alocasia, one of which is never eaten. Varieties are classified on the basis of their color, whether or not they have thorns and if so whether many or few, how fast they mature, how large the corm grows and what its consistency and taste are like after being cooked. Almost all of the Colocasia varieties mature in about six months or so. Many of the older varieties of Cyrtosperma take at least three years to mature. Some varieties, such as simiten, are reported to mature in little more than a year. Many of these early maturing varieties are recent introductions but they are very popular, have become quite widespread and are frequently planted. One early maturing variety whose name, six months ( sikismont) is an English translation of the Ponapean name ( sowunpwong wennew), was introduced to Lukunor years ago by a couple of men who worked on a sailing vessel which stopped at Ponape and heighboring islands. It is apparently grown only on Lukunor and a few neighboring islands. However, the magic [Page 95] of its name has gained for it a wide reputation and many people would like to try it out. This variety would be extensively propagated if it were made available, though some might be disappointed since it does not quite live up to its name, taking a year, sometimes a little less than a year, to grow to maturity. In regard to Cyrtosperma, the tasty, rapidly maturing varieties are the most highly desired but they seem to be less hardy. In former times, people used to keep a reserve supply of the hardier but less tasty varieties of Cyrtosperma in the swamps for use in times of famine. This is no longer being done so the hardier varieties are not so frequently propagated.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_913_FmTrukL] It is unclear from Mahony's description whether these supplies had a communal character or were only used by individual families. We have provisionally assumed the latter. Expert confirmation is needed on the matter. So far, we have found no evidence on famine relief mesasures undertaken by the colonial administration.
♠ provision of famine relief ♣ ♥
♠ Food storage ♣ inferred absent ♥ According to SCCS variable 20 'Food Storage' 'Individual households', not 'Communal facilities', 'Political agent controlled repositories', or 'Economic agent controlled repositories' were present, coded in the SCCS as ‘2’. Bollig and Goodenough describe the fermentation of breadfruit: 'Truk’s small land area and limited animal resources force its inhabitants to rely for food almost exclusively on vegetable and marine resources. The staple food is supplied by the breadfruit tree, which is well suited to the steep slopes, its roots preventing soil erosion. Since it provides a seasonal crop, breadfruit is stored and fermented in pits for the lean period, when the diet is further supplemented with taro, sweet potatoes, and manioc.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_914_FmTrukL] 'Since the breadfruit tree does not bear throughout the year, the natives must preserve the surplus so that it, together with the yields from the plantings, will help them through to the next breadfruit harvest. In this period of preserving, all the men and boys are busy with picking ( amomo). With baskets and the iass (picker) they set out in order to relieve the trees of their burden. All the fruit is heaped up in piles at a certain place. A funnel-shaped pit ( nas) has been dug out there and lined with banana leaves. The shell of the fruit is scraped out with a tiger shell ( [unknown]i[unknown]i), which is ground like a plane, the core is cut out, the fruit split into pieces and thrown into the pit. The whole is covered with banana leaves and grass and weighted with large stones. Some time later the fruit begins to ferment, and a yellowish-white mass is formed, which smells sourish.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_915_FmTrukL] 'All kinds of breadfruit are preserved together on Truk. On other islands they are carefully sorted out, whereby better apot, mar (name of the preserved food) is supposed to be produced. A mar contains hundreds, even thousands, of fruits. If one considers that each family makes several nas for the lean months, it is clear that one tree cannot feed a family. The apot keeps for years. If more is made in the following year, it [Page 161] is mixed with the old, which is thereby improved. It must be hard to digest, however, since some get a stomachache from eating it. Even at a long distance one can smell the nas, and the breath of those who have eaten apot. For the majority of the natives it is a delicacy. In their “cookbook” there are many recipes for its preparation. They mix it with grated coconut or coconut milk, or knead it in sea water is order to kill the smell somewhat ( marepupu). These recipes, however, are used only on better occasions. Usually it is baked as it comes from the pit.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_916_FmTrukL] Fish and other sea animals were roasted and stored in baskets: 'The Truk people still must usually have animal food to accompany the vegetable main dish, or else it will not slide down. The accompanying food is usually fish. The preparation of the fish is a matter for the women and girls, who perform their task with skill and intelligence, although the procedure is a little dirty. The larger fish, with scales and entrails, are simply put on the open fire; the smaller ones, several at a time, are first wrapped in a breadfruit leaf. The fact that, in addition, the cook spits into the fire or blows her nose in it does not spoil the appetite of any true Trukese. During the work she must very carefully watch the animals wandering about, for whatever animals the hut shelters prowl around the fire in order to grab something. Depending upon the circumstances, mussels, cray-fish, and other sea animals are added to the fish on the open fire. After the work is finished, everything roasted is put into the food baskets hanging from the roof, out of which it is then taken as needed. After a very short time under the tropical sun the animals begin to smell. But though the smell may be ever so strong, no Truk native will throw away a good bite on account of it. One does not hear anything about illnesses as a consequence of eating such food. They seem to be completely immune.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_917_FmTrukL] We have assumed that stored fish and breadfruit served individual families and domestic units rather than villages or even lineages. This remains in need of confirmation. According to Mahony, Cyrtosperma was stored in swamps for use in times of famine: 'A large number of varieties of Colocasia and Cyrtosperma are recognized but there are only a few varieties of Alocasia, one of which is never eaten. Varieties are classified on the basis of their color, whether or not they have thorns and if so whether many or few, how fast they mature, how large the corm grows and what its consistency and taste are like after being cooked. Almost all of the Colocasia varieties mature in about six months or so. Many of the older varieties of Cyrtosperma take at least three years to mature. Some varieties, such as simiten, are reported to mature in little more than a year. Many of these early maturing varieties are recent introductions but they are very popular, have become quite widespread and are frequently planted. One early maturing variety whose name, six months ( sikismont) is an English translation of the Ponapean name ( sowunpwong wennew), was introduced to Lukunor years ago by a couple of men who worked on a sailing vessel which stopped at Ponape and heighboring islands. It is apparently grown only on Lukunor and a few neighboring islands. However, the magic [Page 95] of its name has gained for it a wide reputation and many people would like to try it out. This variety would be extensively propagated if it were made available, though some might be disappointed since it does not quite live up to its name, taking a year, sometimes a little less than a year, to grow to maturity. In regard to Cyrtosperma, the tasty, rapidly maturing varieties are the most highly desired but they seem to be less hardy. In former times, people used to keep a reserve supply of the hardier but less tasty varieties of Cyrtosperma in the swamps for use in times of famine. This is no longer being done so the hardier varieties are not so frequently propagated.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_918_FmTrukL] It is unclear from Mahony's description whether these supplies had a communal character or were only used by individual families. We have provisionally assumed the latter. Expert confirmation is needed on the matter. We have found no evidence of food storage facilities provided by the colonial administration.
♠ provision of food storage ♣ ♥
♠ Alimentary supplementation ♣ absent ♥ See above.
♠ provision of alimentary supplementation ♣ ♥
♠ Drinking water ♣ absent ♥ Islanders used rainwater and freshwater springs rather than public drinking water supply systems even in the colonial period: 'A supply of drinking water is kept in every house. At the present time a converted gasoline drum, with the lid removed by cutting with a cold chisel, is placed just outside the house to catch rainwater from the corrugated iron roof; or else water is carried from springs and kept in glass bottles. In former times, fresh water springs located on high ground inland constituted the chief source of supply and water was carried from these springs in coconut shell containers. In former times also, short breadfruit logs were occasionally dubbed out and placed beneath the eaves to catch rainwater.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_919_FmTrukL]
♠ provision of drinking water ♣ ♥
♠ Irrigation works ♣ absent ♥ Traditionally, swidden farming rather than irrigated agriculture was the norm: 'In the past, swidden gardens with dry taro, turmeric, and sugar cane were few and small. Breadfruit, supplemented by wet taro, was the staple. Being seasonal, breadfruit was preserved by fermenting in pits. Copra has become the only export. Fishing was important.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_920_FmTrukL] Accordingly, we have assumed that no irrigation systems were provided by the colonial administration.
♠ provision of irrigation works ♣ ♥
♠ Health infrastructure ♣ present ♥ Illnesses were cured by ritual specialists rather than managed within the framework of a public health infrastructure: 'Ritual practices were conducted by their own specialists. They included spirit mediums, breadfruit summoners, fish summoners, healers, masters of spells, masters of sorcery, builders, navigators, diviners, and most importantly the masters of magic and ritual relating to war and politics. Their knowledge was private property passed down to their children and junior lineage mates.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_921_FmTrukL] 'Major ceremonies were those associated with death, communicating with good souls of the dead, summoning breadfruit, and making food presentations to chiefs. Ritual was also associated with divination, curing, warfare, political meetings, house building, and courtship.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_922_FmTrukL] Medicines were associated with the agency of spirits: 'In traditional belief, spirit beings were widely distributed in the sky, under the sea, and on land. The important places among spirit lands in the sky were: a region under the dome of Heaven, home of the gods who could take human form; a region in the south from which came all the plant and marine life that gave people food; and a region named 'Achaw' or 'Kachaw,' abode of the ancestors of many Chuukese clans and particularly of the clans associated with the chiefship and the special bodies of magical lore from which chiefly power derived. Spirits could accomplish their intentions at will and were thus the source of all that was MANAMAN (mana), such as efficacious spells, medicines, and rituals. Good souls of the dead were consulted through mediums. The Chuukese also invoked in spells the spirits inhabiting the dome of Heaven, presided over by 'Great Spirit,' and the spirits associated with particular crafts and major bodies of lore.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_923_FmTrukL] Diviners, Healers, and Mediums were involved in the treatment of illness: 'Sickness was believed to result from the 'bite' of a malevolent spirit, or of any other spirit one had offended or that was controlled by a ritual specialist one had offended or by a sorcerer. Sickness might also result from soul loss. In all but the latter case, treatment involved the use of medicines to be applied externally, to be drunk, or to be inhaled. For soul loss, a spirit medium was consulted to help find and restore the soul. Divination was used as a diagnostic aid in cases of severe or prolonged illness. Massage was used to treat bruises, local infections, and muscle ailments.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_924_FmTrukL] Knowledge of divination was considered incorporeal property: 'There are systems of knowledge which are subject to special rules of their own. [Page 56] For example, to learn knot divination a pupil must pay the diviner ( sowupwe) even if the latter is his own father or mother’s brother. An jitag (a sort of lawyer, general, diplomat and orator all rolled into one, who occupies the most prestigeful position in Trukese society) is alleged never to teach his own children as much as he teaches his sister’s children. This contention does not, however, appear to be supported by the genealogical connections of the past jitag of Romonum Island. Despite special rules governing specific forms of incorporeal property, their over-all organization is analogous to that of corporeal property and does not require a new conceptual framework to make them intelligible.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_925_FmTrukL] Spirit mediums relied on the experience of possession rather than a transmitted system of knowledge: 'All religious practitioners as well as craftsmen and magicians are owners of the knowledge necessary to exercise their specialties. The Trukese make no distinction between them and other skilled personnel. There is one important exception to this rule, the spirit medium ( wäättwa or wään ëny). His (or her) position is not based on knowledge so much as on having been possessed by a spirit. This spirit is in no way classed as the medium’s property, nor can it be inherited automatically by a son or lineage mate. The position of a spirit medium, therefore, is different from that of a property holder, except as he uses his abilities to diagnose illness.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_926_FmTrukL] Public health infrastructures on Chuuk were introduced in the colonial period. Mahony describes the public health infrastructure as it existed in the post-colonial period: 'Hospital medicine may be sought directly from a health aide at the local dispensary, or, if some way can be found to get there, at the District Hospital on Moen Island. Occasionally a missionary, a Peace Corps Volunteer, or some other Westerner present in the community may serve as a source of hospital medicine. In any event, when hospital medicine is sought, the patient and his relatives need only make a determination about the kinds of symptoms present.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_927_FmTrukL] 'Nowadays health services are delivered to people living in the Truk Lagoon in two major ways: through the local dispensary on each island or municipality and through the District Hospital on Moen Island with its associated Public Health Office, which handles immunizations and prenatal and well-baby clinics. All of these services are administered by a District Director of Public Health, at present a Trukese medical practitioner. As an official of the Trust Territory government, he receives technical supervision from the Public Health Director attached to the High Commissioner’s Headquarters staff on Saipan. The District Director of Public Health is assisted by other medical practitioners, all graduates of the Fiji School of Medicine, which gives five years of training but does not award a full M.D. degree. These practitioners may be assisted from time to time by a fully licensed physician. These personnel and facilities service the 27,000 people of the Truk District, which includes Truk Atoll and a number of other islands and atolls to the west and south of Truk.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_928_FmTrukL] 'The most readily available source of ‘hospital medicine’ for Pis and Fano Islanders, and most others in the Truk District, is the local dispensary (also called piiuiig) manned by a local health aide. For the most part the treatment given is symptomatic, and there is virtually no attempt at diagnosis. It could hardly be otherwise since the health aides have minimal training and very little in the way of facilities. None of the health aides in the Truk District has had the equivalent of a High School education; in fact, many have had no formal schooling whatsoever. All, however, have had from six months to one year of in-service training through working at the District Hospital, plus occasional refresher training at the same hospital.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_929_FmTrukL] 'These health aides dispense medicines out of a small stock of remedies kept in a closet in their homes or the shack that serves as local dispensary. They administer broad spectrum antibiotics for various complaints, apply ointments, salves, and dressings; dispense worm pills and aspirin; and dole out liberal amounts of cough syrup and nose drops. Although the desires or needs of individual patients are occasionally met satisfactorily, and while there are practically no outspoken complaints, the general level of satisfaction with these services can safely be said to be very low.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_930_FmTrukL] 'The next normal outlet where ‘hospital medicine’ can be sought is at the hospital on Moen Island. Patients sometimes face difficult problems in obtaining transportation to Moen, and arranging for food and lodging while there. If these problems can be overcome, patients must frequently wait for hours at the out-patient clinic before being examined. The number of out-patients ranges from 85 to over 100 per day, and there is only one Micronesian medical practitioner on duty from 8:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. to handle this patient load.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_931_FmTrukL] However, according to Fischer, Chuukese continued to practice 'native' forms of medicine even when taking advantage of colonial hospitals: 'Sickness: In almost every house in which there is a young child will also be found medicines to protect him from various illness caused by the [Page 98] supernaturals. Sick babies will be taken to the American hospital only if the parents are above average as far as acculturation goes, and if the hospital is within a convenient distance from the home. On Romonum the hospital is much too inconveniently situated, ten miles away across the lagoon on Moen, to make taking babies who are other than at death’s door feasible. Even in this case, the faith in Trukese medicine is often so great that it is felt that nothing can save the child if Trukese medicine fails. American doctors, getting only severe cases from long distances, are at a disadvantage in establishing faith in American medicine. One child, who had a badly swollen eye, with one side of his mouth and face also infected, was taken to the hospital by a reluctant parent, when urged by the anthropologist, only after Trukese medicines had failed to relieve the child in a two-week trial. After a few days under penicillin treatment in the hospital, the child return with all signs of the swelling gone. His parents brought a gift of food to the anthropologist in gratitude. To illustrate how difficult it is to convince a people of the fallacy of their own ways of medication, the adopted mother of this same child had an advanced and very painful case of venereal disease which she refused to have treated in the hospital, and submitted only as treatment by a Trukese woman who was reported to have very strong venereal medicine.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_932_FmTrukL] 'Even those who will bring their children to the hospital, and undergo the hardship of having to remain in confinement with them, are in general not secure enough in their belief in the American medicine to abandon their own treatment. Thus, many children, who are also taking medicine from the hospital, will have a black, tar-like substance spotted over their bodies and will be having bundles of Trukese medicine soaked in water and the water subsequently poured over their heads.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_933_FmTrukL] We need to confirm when hospitals and clinincs became commonplace and add a transition date.
♠ Control of infectious disease ♣ present ♥ Gladwin and Mahony describe a number of vaccination efforts undertaken by successive colonial administrations: 'Disease can never be avoided but with the exception of tuberculosis, which is apparently recent in the area and takes a serious toll, there are no diseases which could be called menacing. Smallpox was quite a killer between its introduction in the last century and the beginning of vaccination under the Japanese, but is now virtually unknown. The anopheles mosquito is not present, so there is no malaria; amebic dysentery exists, but probably because water is not drunk from the springs is never epidemic. Even syphilis is interdicted by the closely related skin disease yaws, although it is interesting and disturbing to speculate upon the possible consequences of the eradication of yaws (through the use of penicillin by the American administration) upon the resistance to syphilis of the rising generations.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_934_FmTrukL] 'Other infectious diseases which have sometimes occurred in epidemic proportions in recent years include measles (rubeola), German measles, whooping cough (pertussis) and poliomyelitis. It should be noted that the Trust Territory administration in 1964 launched a mass immunization program for smallpox, tetanus, diphtheria, whooping cough, poliomyelitis, typhoid and paratyphoid fever. This program is beginning to provide protection against some of the more serious epidemic diseases.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_935_FmTrukL]
♠ Care of war invalids/veterans ♣ absent ♥ We have found no material on care of war invalids. While the Japanese administration certainly provided services to its own soldiers during WW II, we are unsure whether Chuukese individuals benefitted from this.
♠ Care of orphans ♣ absent ♥ Orphans were taken in by the extend family rather than cared for within a public health framework: 'The cooperative extended family is responsible for the provision of material wealth for its members. This family has in the past consisted of a group of own sisters, their spouses, their daughters, married and unmarried, and their unmarried sons and brothers, residing matrilocally. Today, the demise of the large family house has sometimes led to [Page 19] a grouping of sisters’ houses around a common family hearth. In other cases today, where it is more economically beneficial, married couples will reside patrilocally, while still others will set up nuclear family households. Families will often gain additional recruits from various sources such as teen-age children, dissatisfied with treatment in their own homes, who may be taken in as a pwipwi (sibling of the same sex) by some member of the family who happens to take a temporary or permanent liking to them, or among orphans and their spouses if they are still too young to set up households of their own at the time they are left without families. Cooperation for the benefit of the family extends outside this unit but within this unit it is more rigidly regulated. Other units formed for procuring biologic necessities are informal, transitory and voluntary except for those associated with the public welfare. In this last instance the chief generally assigns certain quantities of work to each family unit, who may in turn apportion it among their members as they see fit. This is done in the case of food for feasts, building of public works, etc.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_936_FmTrukL] Orphaned infants were fed by related women or neighbours: 'The feeding of the child is primarily a matter for the mother. But other women in the house do not hesitate to help the mother in the nursing. One can see children who have been able to walk and talk for a long time and are still suckled. The European feeding-bottle has also successfully made a way for itself and is filled with goat’s milk or condensed milk. If the mother of a suckling dies or if she cannot feed it enough, it is lost in most cases. The women try to feed it with curcuma or chew sugar cane which the little one must suck from their lips, but it is not much use. On the whole mortality is high among the little children of Truk. Many die from intestinal catarrh, fevers, and misery.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_937_FmTrukL] So far, we have found no material on colonial orphanages.
♠ Care of elderly ♣ absent ♥ The elderly were taken care of within the family: 'In Truk it makes expecially good economic sense to produce at least one child. Parents want children in order to have someone to care for them in old age and to have someone to help with their work. The love of children and of relatives is expressed as based on mutual dependence, and feelings of independence are repressed.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_938_FmTrukL] According to Fischer, treatment of the elderly differed according to gender: 'The old man and woman (the chiinn&aunknown;p): After the female passes the menopause she is considered to be an old woman. This is the period of her life of which she is most afraid. If she has had no children and becomes too weak to work she becomes an unwelcome burden upon her more distant relatives. If she has children her status depends somewhat upon how much her children love her. This frequently turns out to be much less than she would expect. If she has grandchildren she may become useful as a baby sitter, while the younger woman works, but more frequently she is expected to provide what food and care she can for the pregnant daughter or daughter-in-law or for the same woman if she has a young child. It is not uncommon for her to be beaten by her own children. Her attempts to keep the good will of others is shown in her changed attitude toward eating. When the anthropologist inquired from Amywo why his wife Aryko ate such a little bit of food and saved the best parts for him, he said, ‘Yes, she is just like an old woman in this. She just picks a little bit at her food and saves the rest for her relatives.’ All old women [Page 38] are not in this unenviable position. Some, especially those who have had large famililies, are secure among their many children, and are not much of a burden to any one of them. If they have gained the respect and love of their children they may be treated in something approaching the ideal manner for treatment of parents in this culture, which is that the parent has only to express a desire to have the children go to great lengths to achieve it for them. There are also certain superstitions associated with neglect of a duty to feed an older person. This is illustrated in Fyciko’s reaction to the following part of a dream: ‘Later I stayed at home and the mother of Siro and Rooke came - she is dead. She was eaten by a soope (ghost) in my dream. Afterwards I screamed loudly, but just a little noise came out because of the soope. Then the soope carried me to Siro’s mother. There was a house. Then Siro’s mother said to me ‘What are you doing?’ I said the soope had eaten me. Then the woman said she would make medicine and the soope wouldn’t eat me. She told me she would get a stick of fire because that was the medicine of the soope. I was very frightened because I thought I would be dead. Afterwards Eniina looked for me and asked the people of the house ‘Where is Fyciko?’ I said, ‘I am here.’ ‘What are you doing here?’ ‘Because a soope ate me, therefore I am here.’ Then she asked, ‘Which one ate you?’ I said, ‘The soul of your sister.’' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_939_FmTrukL] 'The old man is not quite so unfortunate as the old woman. No old man on Romonum had lost so much vigor that he was unable to work. Like the old woman, if he is able, he is expected to provide some food for his grandchildren and their mothers. Unlike the old woman, he is frequently [Page 40] a respected and important figure, who will be called upon for advice from his large store of wisdom. This is especially true if he has been a figure of importance in his youth. If he is weak he is supported by his children or relatives or friends. Young people are admonished to be nice to people because if they should be left alone in old age without children or other relatives, people will love them and will take them in and feed them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_940_FmTrukL] Bolling claims that elderly persons without support networks were left to fend for themselves: 'From the above statements one sees that the lot of the sick is on the average good among the natives; to be sure, the Kanaka is not overindulged either. Only the fate of old, sick people who no longer have any close relatives or are afflicted with a contagious illness is not enviable. They are left in dirt and excrement and lie without care. Someone will barely condescend to give them anything to eat and drink. On trips I often found dying persons, without food, without clothing, who were treated simply like a mangy animal. In heathendom love does not extend very far. Those natives who do not belong to the family of a sick person, generally take no notice of him and do not even visit him; at most one makes the malicious remark: “ deiwet e bue le pa, it serves him right, he will die.” To be sure, the family of the Kanaka does not want any strange visitors, out of fear of evil sorcery.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_941_FmTrukL] So far, we have found no material on colonial systems of care for the elderly.
♠ State pensions for elites ♣ inferred absent ♥ In the period immediately preceding colonization, the Chuuk Islands were not governed by a state. Instead, the Chuukese/Trukese were divided into multiple clans and lineages sharing resources: 'Chuuk's population is divided into a number of dispersed, matrilineal clans. Within any one district the several lineages are usually but not always of different clans. There are also personal kindreds. As a principle of clan and lineage membership, descent is matrilineal, but otherwise kinship is reckoned bilaterally.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_942_FmTrukL] 'The domestic unit was an extended family, based on the women of a lineage or sublineage. It consisted of at least one experienced older woman and two more younger women of childbearing age together with their husbands. Unmarried sons and brothers slept apart in their lineage's meeting house. Extended family households continued through the periods of foreign administration.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_943_FmTrukL] District chiefs were chosen from the dominant lineage of an area: 'In each district the lineage with title to its space held the chiefship. The several lineages with full or residual title to plots of soil had full residential rights. Lineages with only provisional titles to plots of soil in grant from other lineages had only conditional residential rights. Lineages with full residential rights maintained symbolic hearths where, with their client lineages, they prepared food to present to the chief in recognition of his lineage's ownership of the space.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_944_FmTrukL] 'A district chiefship was divided between the oldest man in the senior female line in the chiefly lineage and the oldest man in the lineage generally. The latter was executive chief, or "chief of talk," and the former symbolic chief, or "chief of food." Food presentations were made to the symbolic chief. Sometimes the symbolic and executive functions fell to the same individual; often they did not. The symbolic chief was surrounded by his lineage brothers and by his sons, who acted as his agents. These followers and his sisters and daughters were of chiefly rank, distinct from commoners. Through conquest, a lineage might gain the chiefship in more than one district and establish a junior branch as the chiefly lineage in the conquered district. The now subordinate district rendered food presentations to the superordinate one. Most districts were linked in two rival leagues based on competing schools of magic and ritual relating to war, politics, and rhetoric. A chief's authority derived from two things. His lineage's ownership of the district's space entitled him to presentations of first fruits at stated times of the year. More importantly, it gave him authority over the conservation and use of the district's food resources. His authority also derived from his connection with the sky world, its gods, and their superhuman power to accomplish purposes. There was, therefore, a degree of sacredness associated with chiefs.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_945_FmTrukL] Traditionally, authority did not extend beyond the atoll and was shared among multiple chiefs on one island. Chuuk was somewhat more fragmented than other Micronesian societies: 'Throughout most of Micronesia the maximum independent autonomous political unit was the high island or the atoll, often subdivided into more than one polity. At the time of European contact, Satawan Atoll in the Mortlocks had four separate communities, each with its own leader, which sometimes fought one another. Palau had two confederations of villages or districts, each independent of the other, and the villages themselves had considerable autonomy. Pohnpei had five petty states, although traditions of a unified rule for the whole island are apparent from an earlier period. Chuuk was extremely fragmented politically, with several independent communities on each of the six larger high islands. The Marshalls and the Gilberts had larger polities and integrated groups of separate atolls under a high chief; these expansionist states achieved their fullest development after the introduction of firearms by Europeans.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_946_FmTrukL] Accordingly, we can not assume a system of state pensions for elites prior to colonization. The political structure changed with the advent of colonization, when an administrative infrastructure was introduced by the colonial powers: 'Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_947_FmTrukL] Government chiefs (those tolerated by colonial powers) received a share in the taxes they collected for the government: 'Upon the delivery of the head tax the chiefs were given a few marks back from the German government as gratification. All in all the chief’s office is not a position which can make the possessor rich. It is understandable if the chief further bleeds his people somewhat on the side, especially since often enough he must draw on his purse in their behalf. If two families quarrel on account of something and the one must pay compensation, it is advanced by the chief if the family cannot pay. If someone from a foreign tribe has a claim on a member of his tribe, the chief is responsible for it. All creditors depend on him. Afterwards he can see to getting it back from the debtors. It is strange that the chief is even obliged to distribute gifts here and there. If he sees that one of his people is stirred up about something and he fears disagreeable /118/ scenes, he calms him with little gifts. [Page 129] He knows from experience that the subjects are able to annoy the chief more than he them.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_948_FmTrukL] We are unsure whether government chiefs received pensions as well. However, we have assumed that native petty officials were compensated in the form of a state salary. Accordingly, it might be possible that they also received a modest pension after retirement. More information is needed on the matter. We have provisionally coded 'inferred absent', but this is open to review.
♠ State pensions for non-elites ♣ absent ♥ See above.

Entertainment and Knowledge Well-Being[edit]

♠ Funding for festivals ♣ absent ♥ Islanders prepared food for feasts held by chiefs: 'As noted above, the relations between a chief and the people of his district are patterned largely after the relations between the parties in divided ownership. As provisional title holders to territory, the various lineages owe the chief periodic gifts of produce from the land. These gifts are rendered at stated times in connection with feasts given in the chief’s honor. He fixes the time for these feasts in accordance with a seasonal calendar: two feasts during the breadfruit season, and two more during the turmeric season. The men of the various lineages prepare breadfruit in giant wooden bowls while the women fish. Other types of food are also collected. On the day of the feast each lineage brings its food in a procession, the men carrying the giant bowls on frames and chanting as they walk. The food is carried into the meeting house of the chief’s lineage. The chief then selects the largest bowl for himself and his lineage mates and redistributes the rest of the food to the assembled population. The distribution is made according to lineage and is roughly proportional to the size of each lineage. The contributions which each lineage makes are also proportional to the size of its membership and the amount of productive land which it controls. If a lineage fails in this obligation, the chief has the right to confiscate its holdings. Should he indicate dissatisfaction with the contribution of a particular lineage, its members will hasten to prepare additional food and other gifts to mollify him.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_949_FmTrukL] Bollig describes the preparations for a festival: 'Both develop a feverish activity. The men prepare whole mountains of food. Whatever is found in the plantings is dragged out. The women too get no rest. They are constantly squatting in the water in order to snatch at a little tail. If the supplies of their own tribe are not sufficient, friends on other islands have [Page 201] to help out, for which equal help is given to them in a similar situation. There is movement on all roads on the morning of the fadanap day, for no Kanaka wants to be absent when there is something to chew. All are loaded with bananas, pineapples, sugar cane, coconuts, and fish, which they carry to the chief’s house, where everything is piled up. Very rich ones also bring such European goods as rice, biscuits, salmon; indeed, even beer and liquor could not be lacking in Japanese times. The most festive moment is the bringing of the large madün bowls. Cautiously they come rocking along, carried on the shoulders of strong men. The carriers are painted, /183/ adorned, and sing their emoir. When the fadanap participants are in two parties, they approach from different sides, singing to each other. But usually one tribe or the other takes it badly, since ancient hostility prevails among all the tribes. They quarrel with each other, throw food at their heads, and not infrequently bring knives and spears into play.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_950_FmTrukL] 'A dance festival ( pine) in a village is a happy event, not only for the village itself, but for the whole region. Practicing goes on untiringly for weeks and months beforehand. The dance tunes resound from the shore until late into the night. The closer the day comes, the greater the zeal. Everybody is on their feet. Great quantities of food must be prepared, whole baskets of fish will be roasted, so that the stomach will not come out short either. Some dancers travel around to the neighboring islands and beg for dancing jewelry from friends and acquaintances in order to be able to shine properly. On the morning of the day of the dance they come streaming from all sides, by land, by water, dancer and spectator, their /176/ dance adornment in little baskets. Gay activity increases in front of the dance house. In the huts, under the coconut palms, everywhere unembarrassed toilettes are being made. Mothers paint their stark naked little ones. How happily their little eyes shine, because today they will look beautiful. The adults help each other. Here a woman rubs her husband, there the sister her brother, from head to foot. The people as a whole are a yellow mass. The neck is decked out with faupar, wreaths of flowers. Bands of faupar are wound around arms and legs. The men wear on their heads the mätaritu, the thick, yellow dance wreath made of coconut fibers, and, in addition, enormous wooden combs with bird’s feathers, indeed, whole wings.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_951_FmTrukL] 'The women and girls wear freshly colored hip mats; their arms are adorned with tortoise-shell rings, on the head sits a wreath made of four precious tortoise-shell rings. What one individual has on his body in the way of adornment amounts to hundreds of marks. A happy, festive mood prevails on the dance place. The dancers stand to one side. One recognizes them by the rich adornment and the ubud which they have wound around their hips. They hold one more brief dress rehearsal in order to see whether everything goes well. Then the shell resounds. Everybody rushes into the dance house in order to gain a good place. The rows of dancers sit on the floor gravely and ceremoniously. It is an important day.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_952_FmTrukL] Festival were accordingly not 'publicly funded' by third-party authorities, but their organization depended on food pretations provided by lineage members.
♠ Entertainment buildings ♣ absent: 1886-1914 CE; present: 1915-1948 CE ♥
♠ Theatres ♣ absent ♥
♠ Arenas ♣ absent: 1886-1914 CE; present: 1915-1948 CE ♥ Recreational facilities, such as sports grounds, were introduced in the Japanese period and often attached to schools: 'The school site was generally large enough to have an athletic ground of some sort. Some of these grounds were large enough for baseball fields. Baseball became quite popular in Truk in Japanese times and English baseball terms are still pronounced in a Trukese modification of a Japanese accent by the men who attended Japanese schools.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_953_FmTrukL] 'The fact of daily association and residential proximity puts the members of a community in a position where they are most likely to call upon one another rather than strangers for assistance in the many little tasks that come up where an extra hand or two may be needed, as, for example, in launching a canoe. The members of a community tend, therefore, to be more or less obligated ( kinessëw) to one another in informal matters as well as in more formal property relationships. Similarly, recreational activities frequently involve the entire community membership. Dancing appears to have been [Page 147] the most important activities of this kind in aboriginal times, but under the influence of missionaries it has come to be considered sinful and no longer serves this purpose. Its place has been taken by baseball, a sport introduced by the Japanese. When services are over, every Sunday on Romonum is devoted to baseball in which the entire population participates as players or spectators. Many communities are now split into Catholic and Protestant congregations, but the indications are that in former times participation in religious ceremonies was largely a community affair.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_954_FmTrukL] We have assumed no recreational facilities of this kind prior to Japanese rule.
♠ Ritual buildings/spaces ♣ absent ♥ Feasts and other ceremonial events were held at meeting-houses, but meeting-houses served a variety of other functions as well: 'A large and important lineage might have a meeting house, wuut. In some districts only the chief’s lineage has one; in others only the well established lineages. At one time or another every lineage on Romonum has had its own wuut. When a man’s lineage is without a meeting house, he attends that of his father’s or his wife’s lineage.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_955_FmTrukL] 'Under aboriginal conditions a lineage’s wuut was not necessarily located near its jimw. It frequently stood by the shore, where it served as a canoe house ( wutten waa) as well as a meeting house ( wutten mwiic). A meeting house was not in itself taboo to women, although normally they did not enter it if men other than their husbands were present. Both men and women, however, could be present together at such feasts and dances as did not exclude one sex and were held in the meeting house. During certain ceremonies, men kept away from the meeting house and it was used exclusively by women. The women of a lineage could hold meetings of their own in its wuut.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_956_FmTrukL] 'Its wuut was the place where the unmarried young men of a lineage slept. Its older men, and at times the husbands of its women, also slept there whenever they were observing important sexual taboos. A meeting house was the lounging place for men during the evening, where they visited and told stories. In it visitors from other islands and districts were received, entertained, and put up for the night.' ref>Goodenough, Ward Hunt 1951. “Property, Kin, And Community On Truk”, 68</ref> 'All the old lineage meeting houses of Romonum are gone today. All over Truk, however, every district still maintains at least one meeting house. Women enter them more freely now than they used to, because the unmarried men no longer sleep there. The latter now go to sleep in the houses of non-taboo relatives. Several unmarried men may together occupy a small hut for sleeping purposes, the hut being built in the style of an jimw rather than of an wuut. The district meeting house is still the place where the men sleep before a ball game or track meet. Guests are still entertained there, and it still is the place for feasts and district meetings. All local governmental functions are carried on in the district wuut.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_957_FmTrukL] Regional ceremonial centres were present until the 18th century, but were abandoned in the immediate pre-colonial period: 'I mention the foregoing in order to show that the present political and learned traditions of Truk derive from a set of older institutions, which they still echo. These institutions involved the political domination of Truk by a presumably immigrant clan whose patron god was Sowukachaw, for whom a shrine was maintained on Achaw Peak, the spiritual seat and source of supernatural power of that dominant clan. A dual system of titles, perhaps not unlike that in Ponape, may have been a feature of the organization of rank and authority, providing the basis for a subsequent division of Truk into the rival political and magico-religious leagues of immediate precolonial times. Truk and Ponape were not the only places in Micronesia to have a cult that associated kingship or high chiefship with a thunder god and basaltic stone. Mention has already been made of the sacred basaltic stones at Nan Moadol on Ponape and the association of one of them with the god of thunder. Basaltic peaks on Ponape were spirit places, and basaltic monoliths the abodes of spirits. This association of basalt with spirits appears [Page 561] even in the Marshall Islands. On Namu and Aur atolls, there were shrines with basaltic stones on them at the places of origin of the clans of paramount chiefs (Finsch 1893:396). The one on Namu, thrown into the sea by a zealous missionary, embodied a clan’s founder (Pollock 1977; Erdland 1914:345); and according to Erdland (1914:343), the totem of the high chiefly clan on Ebon was the thunder, Läköta (‘Sir Cloud’, see ļa- and kōd¸o in Abo et al. 1976). From Ngatik, near Ponape, the Bishop Museum has in its possession an old photograph of an altar. On top of it, according to a notation, is the “stone god,” from its appearance a block of basalt.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_958_FmTrukL] 'A high island, such as Kosrae or Ponape, clearly had to be the source of the basaltic stones in the atolls. But those who carried them and who introduced the cult had to be seafarers, and the seafarers, we have seen, were the atoll dwellers in Micronesia. Kosrae was obviously visited by Marshall Islanders, for the names of a number of places in the Marshalls were known in Kosrae (Sarfert 1919-20:218, 224). It is tempting to consider it the source of the basalt in Namu and Aur. But the Ponapean tradition that people from Namu were in some way associated with Isohkelekel, including mention of their clan name (Fischer, Riesenberg, and Whiting 1977:68, n. 22), makes it more likely that the basalt and the cult were brought to the Marshalls by Marshallese adventurers returning from Ponape.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_959_FmTrukL] Accordingly, we have assumed that their archeological remains did not serve ceremonial functions in the pre-colonial period. Missionaries were active in the colonial period: 'By the middle of the twentieth century all of Chuuk's people were at least nominally Christian, either Protestant or Catholic, and Christianity had become the focus of religious life.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_960_FmTrukL] 'The main island is Toloas. On it lie: the government station (Witetun), the main station of the Catholic ( O[unknown]omenau) and of the Protestant ( Kutua) missions. The landmark of Poloas is the legendary mountain of Tolemuan (peak of the man). The small island of Eten, on which was to be found the seat of the Jaluit Company, is also under the head chief of Toloas.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_961_FmTrukL] 'Before the Spanish Government had gained sufficient influence in the islands, the people of Truk lived under the rule of numerous petty chiefs who were constantly engaging in inter-district and inter-island warfare. In Spanish and German times, Catholic and Protestant missionaries Christianized and subdued the warlike tendencies of the population, but many of the old suspicious attitudes still show in present-day culture patterns. The numbers of Spanish and Germans who came to Truk at any one time were relatively small; they left their mark on the people in the folklore, in the religion and in the alphabet which they applied to the Trukese language, teaching the people to read and write. It was left to the Japanese to make the most impression on the native economy.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_962_FmTrukL] As a result of missionary activities, Christianity spread quickly in the 20th century: 'After 1900 Christianity became well established in most major centres in Micronesia. For the most part, traditional religions ceased being practiced in their full original form, although in Yap and some atolls of the central Carolines, traditional religion continued to be practiced until the middle of the 20th century. Missionaries and travelers recorded descriptions of certain aspects of the island religions, but there is no complete and systematic account.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_963_FmTrukL] We have assumed that Christian missionaries also constructed churches. However, we are unsure as to the extent of church construction prior to the Japanese period. We have provisionally coded 'absent', but this is open to review.
♠ Other ♣ absent ♥
♠ accessibility of entertainment buildings ♣ general population ♥ We have assumed that sports facilities associated with schools were accessible to the general population.
♠ Full-time entertainment specialists ♣ absent ♥ Islanders performed poetry and storytelling: 'Performing arts included dancing, storytelling, playing the noseflute and bamboo Jew's harp (in courtship serenading), singing, and poetry and rhetoric. Other arts were associated with tattooing, woodworking, weaving, and warfare.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_964_FmTrukL] Goodenough describes oral traditions that cover myth and past migrations (see also 'general variables' for material about Chuukese prehistory): 'IN THE ORAL HISTORY OF TRUK AND PONAPE in the Caroline Islands of Micronesia (see Figure 1), a place called Kachaw is the source of some clan ancestors and, especially, of politically important immigrants. Kachaw also appears as a place in Carolinian navigational lore. Until very recently, at least, most Micronesian scholars have accepted as fact that Kachaw is the island of Kosrae (Kusaie), situated about 560 km east southeast of Ponape. This identification has led to historical inferences about the role of Kosrae in Ponapean and Trukese prehistory. Critical examination of the linguistic and contextual evidence, however, indicates that in traditional Micronesian lore Kachaw referred to something quite different, namely the sky or a region of sky. It is as such that Kachaw was important in Trukese and Ponapean cosmology, religion, and legends of origin. Before I develop this argument, let me summarize how Kachaw is talked about in Trukese and Ponapean lore.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_965_FmTrukL] We have assumed that performing arts and oral traditions were transmitted by the community as a whole and performed on a part-time rather than full-time basis. This remains in need of confirmation.
♠ status of full-time entertainment specialists ♣ ♥
♠ Access to education ♣ all people ♥
♠ Publicly funded or subsidized education ♣ absent: 1886-1914 CE; present: 1915-1948 CE ♥ Religious and ritual knowledge was transmitted by ritual specialists to their adepts and kin rather than publicly funded and organized: 'Ritual practices were conducted by their own specialists. They included spirit mediums, breadfruit summoners, fish summoners, healers, masters of spells, masters of sorcery, builders, navigators, diviners, and most importantly the masters of magic and ritual relating to war and politics. Their knowledge was private property passed down to their children and junior lineage mates.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_966_FmTrukL] 'Major ceremonies were those associated with death, communicating with good souls of the dead, summoning breadfruit, and making food presentations to chiefs. Ritual was also associated with divination, curing, warfare, political meetings, house building, and courtship.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_967_FmTrukL] Diviners accepted payments from apprentices (often kin) in exchange for secret knowledge: 'There are systems of knowledge which are subject to special rules of their own. [Page 56] For example, to learn knot divination a pupil must pay the diviner ( sowupwe) even if the latter is his own father or mother’s brother. An jitag (a sort of lawyer, general, diplomat and orator all rolled into one, who occupies the most prestigeful position in Trukese society) is alleged never to teach his own children as much as he teaches his sister’s children. This contention does not, however, appear to be supported by the genealogical connections of the past jitag of Romonum Island. Despite special rules governing specific forms of incorporeal property, their over-all organization is analogous to that of corporeal property and does not require a new conceptual framework to make them intelligible.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_968_FmTrukL] Spirit mediums were an exception to this rule, as their expertise did not rely on knowledge per se: 'All religious practitioners as well as craftsmen and magicians are owners of the knowledge necessary to exercise their specialties. The Trukese make no distinction between them and other skilled personnel. There is one important exception to this rule, the spirit medium ( wäättwa or wään ëny). His (or her) position is not based on knowledge so much as on having been possessed by a spirit. This spirit is in no way classed as the medium’s property, nor can it be inherited automatically by a son or lineage mate. The position of a spirit medium, therefore, is different from that of a property holder, except as he uses his abilities to diagnose illness.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_969_FmTrukL] Public schooling (elementary schools) was introduced by the Japanese colonial administration: 'Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese. Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_970_FmTrukL] 'The Japanese administration followed a policy of starting their educational and other socio-economic programs for the natives at the district centers and spreading outwards. The government school system for natives was initiated by establishing a three-year elementary school near the district administrative center on Dublon Island. This school was staffed by Japanese male teachers with Trukese assistants. The latter at first served as interpreters and helped with the discipline. Students were selected on a quota basis from the various islands of the lagoon. Apparently only boys were selected at first, although girls were soon added.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_971_FmTrukL] 'Eventually other three-year elementary schools were established on the other large islands of the lagoon and on one of the Mortlock Islands, a group of atolls to the south of Truk, while a higher elementary school of two additional grades was established at the district center on Dublon Island for selected graduates of the lower schools. Lower school attendance was then made compulsory within Truk Lagoon.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_972_FmTrukL] Some trade schools were also established: 'A further step on the educational ladder was eventually provided with the establishment of a trade school for carpenters at Koror, Palau, a thousand miles to the west. Promising graduates of the higher elementary schools were selected from all over the mandated territory to attend this school. Later a small agricultural school was established on Dublon Island, Truk, and, after the Japanese started to alienate “undeveloped” native land for colonization, a surveyor’s school was established in Palau.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_973_FmTrukL] Fischer provides a description of Japanese schools: 'The physical plant of the government schools consisted of the school building itself (classrooms and storerooms), and quarters nearby for the teacher or teachers. The school buildings were designed and built by the Japanese government, although native contributions of building sites and labor were evidently sometimes encouraged. The school buildings were of substantial construction; more substantial, one might argue, than was needed in the mild climate of Truk.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_974_FmTrukL] Secondary and tertiary education become more widespread under American rule: 'Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_975_FmTrukL] We have assumed no extensive school network prior to Japanese rule, despite the presence of Christian missionaries. Further confirmation is needed.
♠ Schools for children? ♣ absent: 1886-1914 CE; present: 1915-1948 CE ♥ Elementary schools were introduced in the Japanese period: 'Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_976_FmTrukL] 'The Japanese administration followed a policy of starting their educational and other socio-economic programs for the natives at the district centers and spreading outwards. The government school system for natives was initiated by establishing a three-year elementary school near the district administrative center on Dublon Island. This school was staffed by Japanese male teachers with Trukese assistants. The latter at first served as interpreters and helped with the discipline. Students were selected on a quota basis from the various islands of the lagoon. Apparently only boys were selected at first, although girls were soon added.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_977_FmTrukL] 'Eventually other three-year elementary schools were established on the other large islands of the lagoon and on one of the Mortlock Islands, a group of atolls to the south of Truk, while a higher elementary school of two additional grades was established at the district center on Dublon Island for selected graduates of the lower schools. Lower school attendance was then made compulsory within Truk Lagoon.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_978_FmTrukL] Some trade schools were also established: 'A further step on the educational ladder was eventually provided with the establishment of a trade school for carpenters at Koror, Palau, a thousand miles to the west. Promising graduates of the higher elementary schools were selected from all over the mandated territory to attend this school. Later a small agricultural school was established on Dublon Island, Truk, and, after the Japanese started to alienate “undeveloped” native land for colonization, a surveyor’s school was established in Palau.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_979_FmTrukL] Fischer provides a description of Japanese schools: 'The physical plant of the government schools consisted of the school building itself (classrooms and storerooms), and quarters nearby for the teacher or teachers. The school buildings were designed and built by the Japanese government, although native contributions of building sites and labor were evidently sometimes encouraged. The school buildings were of substantial construction; more substantial, one might argue, than was needed in the mild climate of Truk.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_980_FmTrukL] Secondary and tertiary education become more widespread under American rule: 'Education was much expanded under American administration, and many Chuukese learned English. Some went to college in Guam, Hawaii, and the United States mainland. The American administration introduced representative government.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_981_FmTrukL] We have assumed no extensive school network prior to Japanese rule, despite the presence of Christian missionaries. Further confirmation is needed.
♠ Universities, “proto-universities”, or other higher education ♣ absent ♥ Elementary schools were introduced in the Japanese period: 'Japan replaced Germany as the ruling power in World War I and was in turn replaced by the United States under United Nations Trusteeship in 1945. In 1986 Chuuk and its surrounding atolls became a state within the newly independent Federated States of Micronesia. Protestant missionaries and traders came in the 1880s and Roman Catholic missionaries after 1900. Japan sought to develop Chuuk economically and introduced elementary education in Japanese.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_982_FmTrukL] 'The Japanese administration followed a policy of starting their educational and other socio-economic programs for the natives at the district centers and spreading outwards. The government school system for natives was initiated by establishing a three-year elementary school near the district administrative center on Dublon Island. This school was staffed by Japanese male teachers with Trukese assistants. The latter at first served as interpreters and helped with the discipline. Students were selected on a quota basis from the various islands of the lagoon. Apparently only boys were selected at first, although girls were soon added.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_983_FmTrukL] 'Eventually other three-year elementary schools were established on the other large islands of the lagoon and on one of the Mortlock Islands, a group of atolls to the south of Truk, while a higher elementary school of two additional grades was established at the district center on Dublon Island for selected graduates of the lower schools. Lower school attendance was then made compulsory within Truk Lagoon.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_984_FmTrukL] Some trade schools were also established: 'A further step on the educational ladder was eventually provided with the establishment of a trade school for carpenters at Koror, Palau, a thousand miles to the west. Promising graduates of the higher elementary schools were selected from all over the mandated territory to attend this school. Later a small agricultural school was established on Dublon Island, Truk, and, after the Japanese started to alienate “undeveloped” native land for colonization, a surveyor’s school was established in Palau.' [MAJIDBENAM_REF_985_FmTrukL] Fischer provides a description of Japanese schools: 'The physical plant of the government schools consisted of the school building itself (classrooms and storerooms), and quarters nearby for the teacher or teachers.
